column2: Eli Cohen of Quakerstown, Pa., is "just about" 8 years old and almost always articulate. Occasionally, he lapses.

BOSTON -- November is the pious month. In November, politicians, editorialists and sometimes historians spout platitudes as if Plymouth Rock were Old Faithful. It would be better this grim year to remember certain realities of the American experience that began with the Pilgrims.

A reputed Mafia leader, three state policemen and an alleged gambler were found guilty in Federal Court here last night of conspiring to protect organized gambling operations in Rockland and Westchester Counties.

CALETONES, Chile, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba went to work today on the production line at the huge El Teniente copper mine, where the Chilean Government recently nationalized millions of dollars of private United States investment.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -President Nixon was reported today to be contemplating a personal appeal to President Agha Mohammad Yahya Khan of Pakistan to release Sheik Mujibur Rahman from prison and to seek by personal negotiations a peaceful solution to the crisis in East Pakistan.

In 1839 Lord Macaulay reviewed Gladstone's "The State in Its Relations With the Church." In that book, Gladstone, then still a Tory, contended that Government should propagate religious truth. Macaulay's review argued for the liberal position that Government ought to be neutral on religious questions because it was illsuited to decide them. Churches and other institutions could much better promote society's spiritual interests, and Government would do well to respect that division of labor.
" Significant progress" was reported yesterday in the contract negotiations between the city and its firemen.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 24 -- Pakistan, uncertain whether she would get the necessary support from the big powers, was still reluctant today to call for a meeting of the Security Council to consider her charges of a largescale Indian invasion of East Pakistan.
LONDON, Nov. 24 -- Fist fights and window smashing erupted tonight outside Parliament as hundreds of angry trade unionists clashed with the police.

There they are, Grandpa, Grandma, and the children, immortalized by Norman Rockwell around the Thanksgiving table. They've surely come over the river and through the wood and any minute now somebody is going to yell "Hurrah for the pumpkin pie!"
When Thomas Clementi, a slightly built 19-year-old Brooklyn youth, saw three husky men tormenting an elderly man early last Thursday, he told them to stop.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 24 -Plans for the $12-million Sarah M. Scaife Gallery, to be erected as an addition to the Carnegie Institute and Carnegie Library of Pittsburgh, were announced today.

RAVENNA, Ohio, Nov. 24 -After calling only five witnesses, the state suddenly rested its case today against the first of 25 persons indicted in the 1970 campus disorders that resulted in the killing of four Kent State University students by the Ohio National Guard.
DETROIT, Nov. 24 -- Henry Ford 2d unveiled a plan today to build a $500-million complex of buildings aimed at revitalizing downtown Detroit.

DETROIT, Nov. 24 -- Sales of domestic cars continued at a record rate during the second 10-day period in November, running about 5.4 per cent ahead of the previous peak for a Nov. 11-20 period set in 1965.
Another third-period scoring outburst -- this time for six goals -- elevated the Rangers to an 8-3 victory over the St. Louis Blues last night.
" War is wrong, an unmitigated evil," the late Mahatma Gandhi once said. "No cause, however just, can warrant the indiscriminate slaughter that is going on. . . ."

BONN, Nov. 24 -- In the face of an industrywide lockout that will close metalworking plants in the southwestern industrial belt of West Germany tomorrow night, the metalworkers union decided today to delay extension of its strike.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 24 (AP) -Two building trades unions in the Cincinnati area have asked that scheduled pay increases for their members be cut nearly in half to meet President Nixon's wage guideline of 5.5 per cent.

YERINGTON, Nev., Nov. 24 -- Residents of the small town of Fernley, Nev., have won a major victory in their fight against a cement company that polluted the air with thousands of pounds of dust and dirt daily for 19 months.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Millions of Americans today will eat turkey with all the trimmings and not even bother to wonder why. This is the trouble with today's Thanksgiving. Americans have forgotten the traditions and history that have made it what it is.
Nineteen of the season's debutantes, who are provisional members of the Junior League of New York, were honored at the league's 22d annual Debutante Ball at the Plaza last night.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 24 -- Lead ers of an African mediation mission returned to Israel today, fresh from their latest talks in Cairo. They conferred promptly with Premier Golda Meir and Foreign Minister Abba Eban.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -The Atomic Energy Commission announced rulings today allowing construction work to continue at four nuclear power plants while surveys of the probable environmental effects are being completed.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UPI) -- The business of scheduled United States airlines showed a sharp upturn in the third quarter, the Air Transport Association reported today.
District Attorney Frank S. Hogan announced yesterday the indictment of a second and third man in the murder of two New York City policemen last May.
Most bond prices continued to sag yesterday, primarily reflecting large amounts of unsold inventory and the prospect that more financing was on the way.

GENEVA, Nov. 24 -- The director general of the international organization that oversees the world's trading relations called today for the quick removal of the "more dangerous and irritating restrictive trade measures."
LONDON, May 24 -- The agreement between Britain and Rhodesia's white rulers was greeted with relief in London today by those who saw an end at last to a decade-long diplomatic headache.

The board of Philip Morris, Inc., declared a quarterly dividend yesterday of 31 cents a share on its common stock, payable Jan. 12 to holders of record Dec. 17. The increase of 1 cent, slightly under 4 per cent from the previous 30 cents a share, is within the Phase Two guideline, published Nov. 15, which allows a maximum rise of 4 per cent.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 24 -An East Coast pair clung to the lead they had established last night in the blue ribbon pair championship of the American contract bridge league's fall Nationals. Robert Lipsitz of Alexandria, Va., and Marvin Rosenblatt of Bristol, Conn., totaled 435 1/2 points at the end of the first semi-final session.
New York State's two controversial welfare demonstration projects were formally approved yesterday by Elliot L. Richardson, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, to take effect Jan. 1.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UPI) -- Warned by a Commerce Committee report that the world can no longer consider the oceans the "universal sewer of mankind," the Senate voted 73 to 0 today to curb the dumping of waste materials in waters beyond the territorial jurisdiction of the United States.
Perhaps the reason there is such a strong response to articles about small-investor distress is because there are 31 million investors in the stock market.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -Senator Vance Hartke, Democrat of Indiana, moved today to extend for two years, until July 1, 1975, the period in which the National Railroad Passenger Corporation is barred from dropping any of its Amtrak trains.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UPI) -- Mike Mansfield, the Senate Democratic leader, said today that Congress might refuse to pass a new tax bill if President Nixon vetoed the cur rent one because of its rider providing for taxpayer support of Presidential candidates.

Pro football has two games on television today, overlapping the No. 1 college contest, Nebraska at Oklahoma, Channel 7, 2:50 P.M. At noon from Detroit, Channel 4, it will be the Kansas City Chiefs against the Lions, two second-place teams that can ill afford a loss.
One policeman was killed and another seriously injured in Brooklyn last night when an oil truck slamed into the rear of the police car.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 24 -- China urged today that the General Assembly shelve a Soviet proposal for a world disarmament conference. This brought a charge by the Soviet Union that China and the United States were engaged in a "duet of negativism."

TOKYO, Nov. 24 (AP) -Higher radiation levels have been detected in the atmosphere over Japan and Hong Kong, and scientists believe they are the result of China's detonation of a nuclear device Thursday.

MOSCOW, Nov. 24 -- Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin presented the Government's new five-year plan to the Supreme Soviet (parliament) today and called on the United States to "give up its attempts to discriminate against the Soviet Union in trade, financing and shipping."
BOSTON, Nov. 24 -- A contempt order against Mrs. Idella Marx, mother-in-law of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg, was vacated today by the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit.

CALCUTTA, India, Nov. 24 -- India acknowledged today for the first time that her troops had crossed into East Pakistan to battle Pakistani forces, but said they had done so only once -- last Sunday -- and then only "in self-defense."

Prices of soybean and grain futures on the Chicago Board of Trade improved yesterday with the news that the Nixon Administration may use a TaftHartley back-to-work order for a 90-day cooling-off period to break the deadlock in the Atlantic -Gulf Coast dock strike.
Strong endorsement for the controversial low-income housing project just started in Forest Hills, Queens, came yesterday from 16 civic and community groups that work in Queens and Long Island.
A 30-year-old man who had a record of narcotics arrests was fatally stabbed early yesterday on the sidewalk outside the Strand Hotel at 206 West 43d Street.

Teledyne, Inc., the diversified, West Coast manufacturer of electronic, specialty-metal, and aviation products, reported yesterday net income for the fiscal year ended Oct. 31 of $56,179,000, or $1.63 a share, on sales of $1,101,872,000. This compared with $61,864,000, or $1.84 a share, for the preceding fiscal year, when sales were $1,216,448,000.

ROME, Nov. 24 -- Students and the police clashed violently here and in Milan and about half of Italy's high-school teachers stayed away from classes today, further disrupting a strained education system.

The strike that halted milk distribution to stores in New York City in Westchester County and on Long Island for a day ended last night when the city's largest distributor, Sealtest Industries, reached agreement with Local 584 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 24 -Mrs. Nancy Halliday Duff of La Jolla, Calif., a former Assistant United States Attorney for the Southern District of California, was married here this afternoon to John Hart Ely of New Haven, professor at the Yale Law School.
MADRID, Nov. 24 -- Foreign Minister Maurice Schumann of France has told members of the Spanish opposition that the "attitude" of the Franco Government makes it impossible for him to see them.
Owners of 2,000 Bronx apartment buildings agreed yesterday to give their service employes a $12-a-week increase, thereby averting a strike.
The ranks of the boardroom faithful were noticeably thin at brokerage firms yesterday. One manager explained that it was probably because of the Thanksgiving holiday.

The giving of thanks and the getting of heartburn -- or, for some, a not - so - traditional square meal -- will unite New Yorkers for today, and they can expect it to rain at least a little on their parade.

I've read and enjoyed a number of Mr. Stewart's suspense novels -- published under the pseudonym of Michael Innes -- but I never found them suspenseful. Though they had many other virtues -- erudite irony, a fine sense of place, richly idiosyncratic characters, acute observation -- they were almost static enough to mock their genre.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 --- Herbert Stein, the man named by President Nixon today as chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, is an economist who has a reputation of being something of an ideologue but who turns out in practice to be a pragmatist.

Life magazine announced yesterday that it would cut 1.5 million from its 7 million circulation guarantee with the Jan. 14 issue. It will also seek to raise the cost to advertisers of reaching readers and increase subscription rates.

In advocating a burial -- albeit a decent one -- of the U.N., Jeffrey St. John (Op-Ed Nov. 13) builds his case on the proposition that the U.N. Charter was "clearly compromised when a founding member, Taiwan, was expelled." Apparently, Mr. St. John can no longer accept the fiction that the Government at Taipei represents the real China, which has now been expelled.

The Gun Control Act, which became law after the murders of Martin Luther King and Robert Kennedy, was an inadequate measure but acceptable as the first step toward reducing this nation's homicidal slaughter. But the Administration, Congress and the sportsmen's lobby have contrived to regress rather than move forward from that initial step.

Historical: For centuries, the Indian subcontinent has been torn by bloody clashes between Moslems and Hindus. When independence was granted from Britain in 1947, the Moslem League headed by Mohammed Ali Jinnah won a demand for a separate state to give Moslems protection from predominantly Hindu India. Because the Moslems were concentrated in two distinct regions, Pakistan was created in two parts, East and West, separated by 1,000 miles of Indian territory.
TOKYO, Nov. 21 -- In the big Black Book from Which President Nixon was briefed on international economics this year, the main challenger to American well-being is listed as "Japan Inc."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -Sixty-one years after the death of Mary Baker Eddy, the Christian Science Church she founded has nearly succeeded in getting Congress to pass a private bill that would give special copyright protection to her principal work, "Science and Health With Key to the Scriptures."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -Representatives of Italian, Polish, Hungarian and other urban ethnic communities spoke out today against "political manipulation" of American ethnic groups.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -Paul W. McCracken, who has been chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers since the start of this Administration, resigned today, effective Jan. 1.

The Board of Estimate gave its approval yesterday to a Lindsay administration plan for a mixed housing development on Manhattan's East Side, rejecting an unusual appeal from the largely white neighborhood for an increase in the number of low-income apartments in the project.
DALLAS, Nov. 24 (AP) -Political activist and peace groups from throughout the nation met today to decide whether they should challenge Republicans and Democrats in next year's Presidential election.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -The Price Commission reduced for the first time today the amount of a price increase asked by a company. It allowed the Chrysler Corporation a 4.5 per cent increase on its 1972 model automobiles. Chrysler had asked for a rise of 5.3 per cent.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Military induction of all draftees in seven California counties was halted today by two Federal judges pending a judicial review of the new Selective Service Act.
If you're in the stock market the chances are very strong that before long you'll be hearing from your broker about something new he has to offer: life insurance.

Mayor Lindsay celebrated his 50th birthday yesterday, shaking hands with the policemen who guard his office, at an after-work party with staff members, at an off-the-record meeting with City Hall reporters and at a familyonly dinner at Gracie Mansion.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -The Army has told five highranking officers, including a two-star general, that it plans to demote or reprimand them as a result of an enemy attack on a fire base in South Vietnam last March that resulted in 33 deaths and 76 injuries.
The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York revised upward yesterday the number of lay and religious teachers it said were on strike.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Nov. 24 -- The six-year struggle between Britain and her rebellious territory of Rhodesia neared an end today as a constitutional settlement was agreed upon.
LIMA, Ohio, Nov. 24 (UPI) -Thirty-one employes and former employes of the Lima State Hospital for the Criminally Insane have been arrested on charges of mistreating inmates physically or sexually.

Stock prices finished slightly higher yesterday, after initial early gains were carved away as neatly as a Thanksgiving turkey. Exchanges will be closed today in observance of the holiday, but the market will reopen tomorrow.

Toby Armour's regular yearly visits from Boston assure us of her continued special performing skill. Her company's concert at the Cubiculo Tuesday evening reinforces the opinion that there are few dancers who can choreograph pieces for themselves that move so unhurriedly and yet purposefully at their own deliberate pace.

State Supreme Court Justice George Postel -- already the defendant in a suit brought by newsmen in state court here -was ordered yesterday to explain in Federal Court next Tuesday why he should be permitted to continue to bar the public from the trial of Carmine J. Persico.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24 (UPI) -- First-period goals by Johnny McKenzie and Phil Esposito powered the Boston Bruins to a 2-1 National Hockey League victory over the Philadelphia Flyers tonight.
The New York Times Company announced yesterday that it had agreed to acquire two daily newspapers in Florida from Indian River Newspapers, Inc., for cash. The amount was not disclosed.
Matt Snell, the valuable Jet running back who suffered two severe injuries within 11 months, is finished for the present and a question mark for the future.
ANACAPA ISLAND, Calif., Nov. 21 -- On this starkly beautiful island, the traditional nesting grounds for pelicans, only eight chicks were hatched this year.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 24 -- Following, in unofficial translation, are excerpts from the address of Chiao Kuan-hua, head of the Chinese delegation, before the General Assembly and the response by Yakov A. Malik, the chief Soviet delegate:

DACCA, Pakistan, Nov. 24 -About half of the United Nations relief force in East Pakistan was evacuated today and others were being called in from the field as fighting between Indian and Pakistani forces continued to be reported in three areas.

The New York Public Library's Manuscript Division has turned up this historical rediscovery: the first Thanksgiving proclamation. This document ordaining a day of thanks and prayer in the Berkeley settlement in Virginia was issued in 1619 -- before Governor Bradford established the famous celebration in 1623 for the Plymouth Colony in Massachusetts.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -Senior Pentagon officials said today that the Administration was considering providing Israel with short-range missiles rather than Phantom fighterbombers if Soviet shipments of modern weapons should threaten to tip the balance of power in the Middle East in favor of Egypt.

Investigation Commissioner Robert K. Ruskin said last night that Deputy Sanitation Commissioner Frank J. DuVal and "a number of Sanitation Department police personnel" were questioned yesterday in Mr. Ruskin's investigation of activities in the Sanitation Department.
SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Nov. 24 --A 10-year-old boy may have let President Nixon's announcement on his trip to China out of the bag tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -Richard Nixon has always been at his best as a campaigner when he has had a controversial target to attack -- whether it was officials "soft on Communism" in 1946 or opponents tax on law and order in 1968.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that President Nixon "expects definite progress to be made" at the meeting in Rome next week of the Group of 10 leading industrial nations, which will be tackling the problem of world monetary uncertainty.
Earl Williams of the Atlanta Braves was voted the National League's rookie-of-the-year yesterday in a two-man race with Willie Montanez of the Philadelphia Phillies.

John Misha Petkevich, the American amateur champion, and Mrs. Sonya Klopfer Dunfield, the 1946 world professional titleholder, were among the figure-skating stars who took part in a tuneful dress rehearsal at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

The bright tunes of George M. Cohan and the stirring marches of John Philip Sousa reverberated through the Lower Plaza at Rockefeller Center yesterday as 101 highschool musicians played for a lunchtime audience.

A three-judge special panel siting in Federal Court in Manhattan yesterday dismissed a suit by New York City policemen challenging their Taylor Law penalties that resulted from a strike last Jan. 14 to 19.

Confucius asked his disciple, "What do you do when you see a little baby crawling near a well?" The disciple answered, "Master, no time for argument. I will rush to the baby and rescue it from the danger." Confucius was delighted, "You are right. That is what is called human nature."

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 25 (Reuters) -- Stan Smith of the United States, the favorite to win this year's Pepsi Tennis Grand Prix, reached the third round of the South American open tournament today. Smith beat Joaquin Loyo Mayo of Mexico, 6-1, 6-2, 2-6. 6-3.

When Terry Daniels regains consciousness on the evening of Jan. 15, he will awake to a unique distinction. He will be the only artisan skilled at needlepoint to have fought for the heavyweight championship of the world.
There was little opportunity for the Rangers to sit back and admire their record yesterday, following the 8-3 rout of the St. Louis Blues on Wednesday night.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (UPI) -- One of every four Americans over the age of 65 lives in poverty, and the trend will accelerate, the Senate Committee on Aging said today.
WOODBRIDGE TOWNSHIP, N. J., Nov. 25 -- A 24-hour rebellion by inmates at the Rahway state prison ended tonight with the release of the warden and the last of five guards who had been held hostage.

LOUISVILLE, Nov. 25 -- The Kentucky Colonels, never trailing, posted their fourth straight victory and the 10th in their last 11 games by turning back the New York Nets, 133-117, at Convention Hall tonight.

Arthur S. Bechhoefer's Nov. 8 letter re-emphasizes the importance of the transfer of human capital and skills from developed to developing countries as a form of aid far more effective than military aid and bilateral loans.

RENO, Nov. 25 -- Authorities in four Western states were searching a 500-mile corridor of mountains and river valleys tonight for a hijacker who parachuted from a jet airliner with $200,000 in ransom money.
Union and Westfield, two of New Jersey's best teams, completed unbeaten seasons yesterday.
LONDON, Nov. 25 (AP) -Nearly half of Carnaby Street was auctioned off for $8.5million today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- An association of career diplomats is planning to seek a Federal Court injunction here to bar Frank J. Shakespeare Jr., director of the United States Infornation Agency, from altering a 25-year-old promotion system.

HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S. C., Nov. 25 -- In cold and wind that reminded him of his football playing days at the University of Colorado, Hale Irwin led the opening round of the $110,000 Heritage Golf Classic with a 68 today.
In the menus below, the dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe:
Joe Namath's countdown for his possible return to action on Sunday -- against San Francisco at Shea Stadium -- went into a "hold" pattern yesterday when the Jets' practice was canceled.

Your Nov. 9 editorial "United States and World Law" suggests, in respect of Congressional action regarding Rhodesian chrome, that President Nixon take advantage of a "loophole pointed out by Prof. Stephen Schwebel of Johns Hopkins University.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 25 -- The field was tightly bunched going into the final session of the blue ribbon pair championship play at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall National Championships here tonight.

CALCUTTA, India, Nov. 25 -There were few clear elements today in the murky situation surrounding the crisis on the Indian subcontinent, where a major Indian-supported offensive by Bengali insurgents against the Pakistani Army has been under way in East Pakistan since last weekend.
WARSAW, Nov. 25 -- Czechoslovakia holds her first national elections in seven years tomorrow in an apparently uneasy and uncertain mood.
The 10 per cent import surcharge was at least partly responsible for producing a record contraction in trade financing during October, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said yesterday.
Donald Duck couldn't come. Neither could Snoopy. Or Linus the Lionhearted. Or even Smokey the Bear.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Four major oil companies have agreed to pay $4.5-million to property owners whose beaches were fouled by oil from the oil platform blowout off Santa Barbara in January, 1969.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 25 (AP) -- Howard Hughes's executives disclosed today that they had sold a narrow piece of land on the Las Vagas Strip, the first property relinquished since the billionaire recluse made his headquarters here in 1966.

TRENTON, Nov. 25 -- The seven lawyers on a team named by Gov. William T. Cahill to represent the public interest in rate-increase applications by public utilities have shared fees totaling $466,000 over the last 18 months.
YUCCA FLAT, Nev., Nov. 25 (UPI) -- Radiation has leaked into the atmosphere from an underground nuclear detonation at the Nevada test site, the Atomic Energy Commission reported today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 23 -- In the past few weeks cargo ships loaded with American jeeps, trucks, air-conditioners, plumbing equipment and bulldozers have sailed for home. Several thousand happy G.I.'s have passed the heroin tests and flown back to "the world."

CAIRO, Friday, Nov. 26 (UPI) -- The semi-official newspaper Al Ahram said today that President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt had sent a message to President Nixon warning that any American surface-to-surface missiles sent to Israel would be a "very serious escalation" of the Middle East conflict and "something which Cairo cannot permit."

In the Brooklyn household of the Robert Kimmel Smiths, it is mama who leaves the house each morning, paper tucked under her arm, to go off to a long day at the office, while papa stays at home and does the marketing, takes the children to the dentist, and often cooks the dinner.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Nov. 25 -- The British-Rhodesian settlement offers new legal rights and economic possibilities to the black majority here, but political power remains a dim and distant hope.

A representative of the president of Harvard recently sent a letter to Congress opposing an education bill amendment that would have denied Federal funds to colleges and universities that practice sex discrimination in their admission policies.
LONDON, Nov. 25 -- Britain's prestigious Booker Prize was awarded today to V. S. Naipaul, the Indian writer, for his latest novel, "In a Free State."

RAHWAY, N.J., Nov. 25 -- One of the hostages taken in the prison rebellion at the state prison in Woodbridge said tonight that he was treated with care in a cell and protected from some inmates who were speaking of killing the guards.

CableRep, thought to be the first national advertising representative for cable television systems, is almost a year old. And while so far it has only managed to pick up one advertiser, great days are acomin'.
LINDEN, N. J., Nov. 25 -- An explosion rocked a processing plant of the E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. tonight, seriously injuring one employe and shaking houses and buildings for miles around.

As expected, the October sales gain for leading chain and mail order companies in the country, was down from September and lower than in any month since March of this year, according to a survey by The New York Times.

PARIS, Nov. 25 -- Even though the world monetary crisis is far from settled, there is a surprising convergence of views in Europe's financial markets over the figures that would be involved in any currency realignment package.
Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).

Since astrology seems to be enjoying a spurt of popularity these days, the New York Philharmonic could be said to have taken a topical turn Wednesday night in giving its first complete performance of Gustav Holst's "The Planets" in 50 years.
A busing program involving 215,000 pupils, or 27 per cent of the city's 1.1 million public school children, has been proposed for the complete racial integration of the school system.

If a gainfully employed labor union member -- the breadwinner of a family -- goes on strike, not having been discharged, abused or otherwise mistreated, but simply because he wants or needs more money (and who doesn't in these inflated times?) it seems ridiculous that the family unit should receive public relief funds.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Nov. 25 -- President Nixon directed Attorney General John N. Mitchell today to seek court orders to send Atlantic and Gulf Coast longshoremen back to work for an 80-day coolingoff period.
A leading medical publication has reported that vitamin E has "no established value in preventing or treating any common human disorder."

NORMAN, Okla., Nov. 25 -Bob Devaney, coach of college football's No. 1 team, unbeaten Nebraska, termed his defense "excellent" against Oklahoma today even though it yielded 31 points and 467 yards to the offense.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 25 -- Foreign aid experts have seen it happen many a time. A well-meaning company or government agency builds a highly automated factory, to make plastic sandals, for example, in an underdeveloped region.

ACHILL SOUND, Ireland -- The English are wrong in thinking the Irish have no humor. They are the most humorous people alive -- unconsciously. A recent example of this was offered by the family of Mr. Cahill, the I.R.A. leader. No sooner was he off to America, to put the bite on absentee patriots there, than Mrs. Cahill, mother of seven, applied for public assistance.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Nov. 25 -- The United States may ask the United Nations Security Council to consider the dispute between India and Pakistan, or support such a move by another country, the Western White House said today.

BONN, Nov. 25 -- Highly placed sources here said this evening that the German negotiations on filling in the details of the Berlin agreement that was signed in September by the Big Four are expected to be completed next week.

Assemblyman Frank G. Rossetti, the New York County Democratic leader, is likely to have his Assembly seat eliminated when the Legislature meets in special session next month to reapportion legislative districts according to 1970 Federal census figures.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 25 -- In a gesture to meet United States criticism of its allegedly protectionist common farm policy, the E.E.C. is proposing that as of next year the six-nation unit should store surplus production of wheat.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -Women of Italian, Polish and Russian-Jewish origin have had fewer children than white women generally, according to a Census Bureau study released today.

Only a few weeks ago the warden of the maximum-security facility known as the Rahway Prison Farm complained that overcrowding made it impossible to achieve the administration's proclaimed goal of rehabilitation for the 1,143 inmates.

Theater people are traditionally pessimistic optimists -- that is if they are not optimistic pessimists. It is said that a man once walked past Sardi's with a banner saying: "The end of the world is coming."

WATERLOO, Iowa -- When Marvin Heideman lived in Duluth, Minn., his next door neighbor was Gordon Roberts. Mr. Roberts was no ordinary neighbor. He was in business, mainly groceries, and Marvin delivered milk to Mr. Roberts's grocery store.

TORONTO, Nov. 25 -- A Carleton University geologist who used to work for the Standard Oil Company of California has accused the oil industry of spawning unjustified optimism about the likelihood of finding huge oil and natural gas fields in the Canadian Arctic and offshore Atlantic.

A committee of the Community Service Society of New York charged yesterday that 1971 was "the year the Governor and thte Legislature abdicated their joint responsibility for the burning issues of crime, correction and drug abuse."

" Why us?" This question underlies the protests that come from Forest Hills and Lindenwood -- white, middle-class communities strongly opposed to the construction of low-income housing projects in their midst.
Who can remember when ladies and gentlemen (the words are used advisedly) would no more have been without a supply of visiting cards than they would have been without shoes?

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 25 -- American service-men in South Vietnam celebrated Thanksgiving quietly today, with 241,000 pounds of turkey, 4,500 cans of cranberry sauce and the feeling that this would be their last Thanksgiving in Vietnam.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass. -- In an extensive review of the Supreme Court, Prof. Paul A. Freund of the Harvard Law School has urged Congress to help define the guarantees of the Bill of Rights.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24 -Paul Strand is one of the legendary names in the history of American photography. His early accomplishments reach back to the era of Alfred Stieglitz, in whose gallery "291" Mr. Strand first showed his work in 1916.
MOSCOW, Nov. 25 -- The Soviet Union announced today an ambitious program of expansion of its natural gas industry that may ultimately have a significant impact on the growth of Soviet-American trade.

ATLANTA, Nov. 25 (AP) -Jimmy Poulos, a sophomore, plunged over from the 1-yard line with 14 seconds remaining tonight as Georgia stormed to a 28-24 comeback football victory over Georgia Tech in a nationally televised battle of bowl-bound teams.

WOLF CREEK, Mont. -High in the foothills of the Rocky Mountains some 35 miles from Helena, the capital of this sprawling farming and ranching state, Wes Baldry, 52 years old, tended his sheep on Thanksgiving Day as he has winter and summer, night and day, weekends and holidays for the last two years.
ROCHESTER, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Two churches here were extensively damaged by bombs early today.

The debate that has raged over the implications of ethology for human behavior has not been altogether uplifting. Some of the claims of the ethologists -- or at least their popularizers -- have been both grandiose and reductive; while the reasoning of the opposition has often dipped to subhuman levels.

BONN, Nov. 25 -- Half a million West German workers were on strike tonight or locked out of their factories and hundreds of thousands more faced imminent dismissal as a wage dispute in the automobile industry spread to other parts of the country.

Not too many orchestras from Eastern European countries tour the United States. On Wednesday night at Carnegie Hall the Budapest Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Gyorgy Lehel, made its first New York appearance.
Pat Sullivan, Auburn's strong-armed quarterback was named the 1971 winner of the Heisman Trophy last night as college football's top player.

NORMAN, Okla., Nov. 25 -Unbeaten, top-ranked Nebraska scored a touchdown in the final 98 seconds today to outlast Oklahoma, its national challenger, 35-31, in a college football classic that surpassed expectations for Thanksgiving Day excitement.

GENEVA, Nov. 25 -- The United States called today on the world trading community to set its sights on another major international assault on trade barriers once the European Economic Community completes its expected expansion in 1973.

Fifteen Gotham Ball debutantes who had tradition down to a T yesterday -Thanksgiving and turkey -- attended the 22d annual ball at the Plaza's Grand Ballroom, where shortly before midnight they were presented to Terence Cardinal Cooke.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Because no funds have been forthcoming from private sources, the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts has asked Congress for an extra $3-million to finish the center honoring the late President.

Every professional football fan has heard of Minnesota's Purple Gang and the Fearsome Foursome of Los Angeles. They are defensive stalwarts whose destructive prowess has spread, if not fear, respect throughout the National Football League.

DETROIT, Nov. 25 -- Tony Davis, serving the last two months of an armed robbery sentence in a former convent that has been converted into a halfway house here, is slowly getting his life together again.

Kittiwake, whose Florida antecedents seemed utterly out of place on the windswept tundra that was the Aqueduct Race Track yesterday, showed no concern for her surroundings as she won the $56,800 Firenze Handicap.

Dr. Norman E. Borlaug, a Nobel Prize plant-geneticist, has missed a chance to bring scientific clarity to the controversy now raging over the use of DDT. WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -President Nixon's rating among union members' families, while still largely negative, has not changed significantly since the wage-price freeze began, the Gallup Poll reported today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -State Department officials said today that the effort by the North Atlantic alliance to begin an early dialogue with the Soviet Union on mutual troop withdrawal in Europe had apparently run into Kremlin procrastination.

By the overwhelming vote of 350 to 5, the House of Representatives has approved a bill that will increase the level of cancer research funding while retaining the National Cancer Institute as a component part of the National Institutes of Health. Parents at Public School 140 in the Southeast Bronx were still working yesterday to restore what they could of the damage done by five successive nights of break-ins by thieves and vandals over the Thanksgiving weekend.
Winnie Ruth Judd, convicted of the "trunk murder" of a friend in 1931 and sentenced to be hanged, was freed yesterday by the Arizona Board of Pardons and Paroles.
The city's 18 municipal hospitals, already hard-pressed financially, have been ordered to cut back their programs by 5 per cent.

David Merrick's first Broadway show of the season will be the Stratford National Theater of Canada's production of "There's One in Every Marriage," the George Feydeau comedy opening Jan. 3 at the Royale Theater.

Senator Jacob K. Javits charged last night that conservatives were trying to capture "the political soul" of President Nixon by undermining and opposing his attempted rapproachment with China and the Soviet Union and his domestic economic and welfare programs.

The 1971 Christmas shopping season got under way this month on an uncertain note in New York City as seven of the city's largest stores reported widely ranging sales results during November.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Nov. 29 -- California's 19 publicly supported state colleges won the legal right to be called eventually "California state universities" when Gov. Ronald Reagan signed the bill in his office today.

DETROIT, NOV. 29 (UPI) -The Ford Motor Company, following the General Motors Corporation, has signed a license agreement to explore the development of the Wankel rotary engine, it was announced today.

Joe Namath received more treatment at Shea Stadium yesterday, but it wasn't quite the same as the beatific treatment he received from the fans Sunday when he electrified them with his first appearance in 20 games.

LONDON, Nov. 29 -- The British Government today welcomed the Opposition's proposals for talks that could lead to a united Ireland.

CALCUTTA, India, Nov. 29 -- An Indian spokesman said today that there had been "no reaction so far" to President Nixon's message. But he added that Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's statement in a speech in Rajasthan state yesterday "should be a good indication to all of us."

The Carrier Corporation, which manufacturers air-conditioning equipment, achieved record sales, earnings and orders booked in the fiscal quarter and year ended Oct. 31, the company reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- A report cited in Congressional testimony says that some preparations for colds and coughs contain the nasal decongestant PPM although safe dosage levels have not been set by the Food and Drug Administration.
GENEVA, Nov. 30 (Reuters) -- I.O.S., Ltd., said its total net loss in the third quarter amounted to $4.8-million, in contrast to a $300,000 loss in the second quarter.
The Health Services Administration made public yesterday the names of two restaurants and one delicatessen that it said had serious health code violations.

GENEVA, Nov. 30 -- The affluent nations could ease their monetary problems by channeling newly created financial resources to the poorer countries to purchase more products of the industrial world, United Nations experts said today.

TOKYO, Nov. 30 (Reuters) -- Japan had a surplus of $133-million in her balance of payments for October due to active export trading, according to revised figures released by the Finance Ministry today. But this was a sharp drop from a $247-million surplus a year earlier.
The Leasco Data Processing Corporation said yesterday that it had completed arrangements to borrow $85-million from 20 domestic and international banks.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Dec. 1 -- About 15,000 Government troops have reportedly begun a thrust against enemy forces in the Central Highlands of South Vietnam near the Cambodian border.
Members of the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association ratified a new contract with the city yesterday that will give them $,1710 in pay increases during its 27-month term.

At the end of the first day's session of the Group of Ten finance ministers in Rome, the United States and its major trading partners appear well on the way toward a resolution of the monetary crisis that has threatened the economic stability of the Western world and Japan.

Irving B. Kahn, the long-time head of the Teleprompter Corporation, was sentenced yesterday to five years in prison on charges that he had obtained an exclusive cable television franchise by bribing Johnstown, Pa., officials.

RAVENNA, Ohio, Nov. 30 -The first of the Kent trials ended today with the jury finding Jerry Rupe guilty of the misdemeanor charge of obstructing firemen during the 1970 riots at Kent State University. But the jury failed to reach a verdict on three more serious charges against him.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 30 (UPI) -- South Vietnam instituted new ground rules for news coverage of military operations today and threatened to expell correspondents for violations.
The artist in ancient times inspired his fellow citizens, entertained them, educated them, helped them live more fully.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 30 (AP) -The Government rested its case today in the bribery-conspiracy trial of Representative John Dowdy, Democrat of Texas, and shortly afterward a Federal judge denied all defense motions for dismissal of charges.

The 1,500-seat movie theater, the Reade, now under construction in the basement of One Astor Plaza, the 53-story building on the former site of the Astor Hotel, will not open on Dec. 21 as previously announced.
The strike of lay teachers in local Catholic schools, whose function it is to guide and teach our youth, has disclosed that a teacher's initial pay is $6,600 a year.

The city has charged Consolidated Edison with 22 separate air-pollution violations as a result of the utility's refusal to limit the use of coal-fired boilers at Arthur Kill, S. I.

Last night television focused its documentary eye on two "sensitive" facts of New York life. One, on WCBS-TV, was "The World of the Male Hustler." The other, on Channel 13/WNET and far more sensitive, was "Hogan: Mr. D.A.," an investigatory portrait of the city's, perhaps the country's most famous investigator.

The National Sugar Refining Company has elected Donald E. Liederman as chairman of the board. He succeeds Nathan Bilder, who will continue as president and chief executive officer. Mr. Liederman is president of Haven Industries, Inc., which owns about 55 per cent of the outstanding National Sugar stock.

Prices of copper futures here yesterday were 1.4 cent a pound higher at the start of trading in line with London copper prices. But they soon declined as the futures sold off, primarily due to trade selling, to 3/10 cent a pound below Monday's levels.
LIVERMORE, Calif. -- Here are three examples: the secrecy of the Kremlin, the secrecy of Washington, and the secrecy of The New York Times.

A White House official declared yesterday that Canada was not paying her fair share of North American defense costs. A policy adviser from Ottawa replied that in Canada there was a feeling that there were "a lot of other things on which money can be better spent."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Walter Dunbar, executive deputy commissioner of the New York State Department of Correctional Services, told a Congressional committee today that he was the official source of reports that hostages' throats had been slashed and that one hostage had been castrated during the inmate rebellion at Attica. The reports were erroneous.
Stock prices staged a rally that erased a mid-session sinking spell yesterday as hopes remained alive for a solution to the international currency crisis.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Cazzie Russell scored 22 points, including a key free throw with 10 seconds left to lead the Golden State Warriors to a 106-103 victory over the Milwaukee Bucks in a National Basketball Association game tonight.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The American Medical Association voted today to give the nation's medical students voting power in the organization's policy-making decisions.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (Reuters) -- Henry A. Kissinger, foreign affairs adviser to President Nixon, said today that the United States was approaching the question of international monetary reform with the attitude that a solution must be found on a cooperative basis.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -President Nixon selected Lieut. Gen. Robert E. Cushman Jr. today to be the next Commandant of the Marine Corps.

A tentative agreement on a side issue was reached yesterday between the striking Federation of Catholic Teachers and the Association of Catholic Schools, but they remained as far apart as ever on salary -the key stumbling block.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 30 -- The Composers and Lyricists Guild, charging motion picture and television producers with failure to bargain in good faith, has scheduled a strike beginning at midnight tonight.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -Details of the first in a series of nutritional guidelines for processed foods were made public today by the Food and Drug Administration.

A pornography raid on four Times Square bookshops led to the arrest last night of 14 employes or operators, including two men allegedly connected with organized-crime syndicates, according to the police.

Nothing could be better calculated to bring out the absurdities under the surface of French sophistication than the case of Gabrielle Russier. She was a 32-year-old teacher of French literature in a Marseilles high school, who, in 1969, had an affair with a 16-year-old student and was arrested for it.
WARSAW, Nov. 30 -- The foreign ministers of the seven Warsaw Pact nations began a two-day strategy session here today to plan for talks leading to a proposed European security conference.
The chairman of President Nixon's Council of Economic Advisers warned yesterday that labor was in danger of pricing itself out of the market in nations all over the world.

A Supreme Court jury in the Bronx last night acquitted a suspended patrolman, Louis Farina, of a charge of keeping $50,000 in stolen cash that allegedly had been turned over to him on a Bronx street in May, 1970.
The credit markets continued to play cat and mouse with investors yesterday, tempting them with yields on new issues that seemed just a wee bit less than enough to make them buy.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Nov. 30, (Reuters) -- The ruling Colorado party still held a narrow but apparently winning lead over the National party today as the counting of votes in the Uruguayan presidential election continued slowly and amid charges of irregularities.
The Hanna Mining Company announced yesterday that it plans no changes in its base prices for Lake Superior natural iron ore and iron ore pellets in 1972.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 30 -- The University of Notre Dame and St. Mary's College terminated today their sixmonth-old plan to merge.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -The House of Representatives approved overwhelmingly tonight a bill to limit campaign spending by Presidential, Vice-Presidential and Congressional candidates for the first time in American history.
A State Supreme Court justice in Sullivan County overruled the State Harness Racing Commission yesterday and lifted a ban against televising races from Monticello Raceway to New York City.

NEW DELHI, Nov. 30 -- A large combined force of Indian infantry and tanks was fighting in East Pakistan for the fourth day today. In size and duration the engagement is the gravest so far in the fighting between India and Pakistan.

The Getty Oil Company announced yesterday that in accordance with its tender offer for the common stock of the Mission Corporation at $120 a share, it has elected to purchase all the 313,913 shares of Mission common stock tendered.
A new liberalized correction code to govern operations of the city's jails will be law early next year, the chairman of the City Council's Public Safety committee predicted yesterday.

Berenice Bramson gave a pair of very well received recitals here in the mid-1950's, but does not seem to have been heard from since. A teacher at the Mount Kisco School of Music, the soprano returned to Carnegie Recital Hall on Monday night under the school's auspices, and it is a pleasure to report that she has lost none of her skill and taste as a singer.

YONKERS, Nov. 30 -- Herve Filion, the reinsman who seems to be in the right spot at the right time, will drive six horses at Yonkers Raceway tomorrow night. If the 31-year-old native of Angers, Quebec, clicks with one of his charges, five of which are regarded as contenders, he will have achieved his goal of 500 winners in a single season.

TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 30 (Reuters) -- Iranian troops landed today on three disputed islands strategically situated in the Persian Gulf. The Trucial State of Ras al Khaima immediately protested that two of the islands, Greater Tunb and Lesser Tunb, had been invaded and occupied.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 30 (UPI) -- Plans for a "World Baseball Classic" next September among the champions of three United States minor baseball leagues and "probably" the champion of the Mexican League and the champion of the Japanese League were announced today.
Not even a 26-point lead with 20 minutes to play could preserve the New York Knicks' winning streak last night as they lost to the Seattle Super-Sonics, 110-109, at Madison Square Garden.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has tentatively decided to ban the sale of automobile tires that do not comply with Federal safety standards.
Robyn Smith, who continues to be an impressive advertisement for equal rights for women jockeys, had triple cause to celebrate at Aqueduct yesterday.
Sam Fox, a music publisher who pioneered in producing the scores of film music, died yesterday in San Francisco. He was 89 years old and in recent years had made his home in Miami Beach, Fla.

A suit seeking to block the exchange of 125 acres on Staten Island for the Willard Hotel property in Washington was dismissed yesterday by Federal Judge Jacob Mishler in Brooklyn.

There was some sage advice in yesterday's horoscopes for Ralph Gary (Rocky) SymondsThompson, the New York Giants' rookie running back, who is better known by his third and fifth names.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The National Association of Securities Dealers expelled two member firms today, charging both had violated net-capital rules and that one had also violated other regulations.

NEW DELHI, Nov. 30 -- Prime Minister Indira Gandhi called on the Pakistanis today to demonstrate their desire for peace by withdrawing their troops from East Pakistan, where Indian-supported Bengali insurgents are battling the Pakistani Army.

Operations of Gulf and Western Industries, Inc., for the first fiscal quarter, which ended on Oct. 31, resulted in record earnings despite slightly lower sales, the diversified manufacturing and service company reported yesterday.

A 65-year-old retired taxi driver and his wife were killed with an axe in the Inwood section of Manhattan early yesterday morning, the police said.

Adolph J. Toigo, chief executive of Lennen Newell and one of the few sole owners of an agency of any size, will sell two-thirds of his stock to key executives, in order to get the company out of its financial troubles.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -The chairman of the Price Commission, C. Jackson Grayson Jr., asked landlords today to postpone rent increases on residential properties even if present Federal regulations allowed them.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it would begin reporting hourly volume in warrants on its ticker tape as of Jan. 3. At present only the total warrant volume appears on the ticker at the close of the market each day.

The John V. Lindsay Associations -- a loose assortment of liberal Republicans and Democrats, some city officials and other Lindsay supporters -- are becoming the Mayor's chief dispenser of political patronage across the city.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- A State Department campaign of "spontaneous" letters and petitions to help win Senate confirmation for a controversial diplomat has aroused misgiving in Congress.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 30 -President Salvador Allende Gossens, who says his Government is based on the working class, is running into significant labor opposition.

An overhaul of the city's welfare administration, which has brought in 22 management and systems experts in the last three months, was made known yesterday with appointment of a new deputy human resources administrator Arthur H. Spiegel.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed today new rules that would require mutual funds to disclose more about how they vote in takeover fights involving the companies they have invested in and on other matter relating to involvement in the affairs of their portfolio companies.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -President Nixon authorized the Export-Import Bank today to extend credits for the sale of United States goods to Rumania. This ended a three-year ban on American Government-backed credits to Communist-bloc nations.

PARIS, Nov. 30 (UPI) -- Max Fernet, who played a key role in setting up United States-French cooperation against narcotics traffic, is retiring as head of the national investigating police, but authorities said today that his action had nothing to do with a current scandal in the United States.

GRENOBLE, France, Nov. 25 -- Three years after the student revolt and general strike that shook France in May and June of 1968, most of the 23,000 university students in this capital of the French Alps have fallen into political apathy while the potentially far-reaching university reforms that followed the upheaval go all but ignored.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -The Nixon Administration declared today that 38 states had inadequate programs for certification of nursing homes and warned that the states must measure up by Feb. 1 or face a possible loss of all Federal Medicaid funds.
The rally on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the-counter market continued into its fourth day yesterday as both markets made substantial gains in active trading.

The Port of New York, limping back to life under pressure of a temporary court order after eight weeks of strike shutdown, has permanently lost one of its commercial mainstays. WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -A gift of Israeli art to the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts was dedicated today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -Democratic leaders, who have been hard pressed to agree on an alternative to the Nixon Administration's law-and-order approach to crime, began to find common ground today in the form of a broad Federal program to compensate victims of crime.

George Carlyle had his 18-year-old son, Kenneth Thomas Carlyle, arrested 11 days ago for allegedly punching him in the eye. The father told Manhattan Criminal Court Judge Jerome Vale that he suspected his son of being a drug addict.
WARSAW, Dec. 1 -- A twoday meeting of Warsaw Pact foreign ministers ended here today with no indications of the results of their talks on preparations for a European security conference.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Senator Henry M. Jackson will announce tomorrow that he will not enter the New Hampshire primary next March 7 and will concentrate instead on the Florida primary the following week, sources close to the Jackson campaign said tonight.

Hawthorne who has been named vice chairman and will undertake special assignments on long-range planning and development.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The Ford Motor Company agreed today to pay the Government $10,000 in civil penalties for delivering to dealers last summer 207,500 of its 1972-model cars and trucks before receiving certification that they met Federal emission standards under the Clean Air Act of 1970.

A 51-year-old customer in a coin-operated laundry in South Ozone, Queens, was shot and killed and another customer was wounded late yesterday afternoon when a youth opened fire when none of the 10 customers inside would give him money.

David C. Adams was appointed chairman of the National Broadcasting Company at yesterday morning's monthly meeting of the board of directors. He succeeds Walter D. Scott, who will remain as a director. Mr. Scott two years ago had advised associates of his plans to phase himself out of his job.

An enraged band of students at a yeshiva in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn mauled an apparent burglar last night after he allegedly set fire to a torah, or handwritten Biblical scroll, worth $10,000, the police said.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Dec. 1 -Four members of Congress lectured the owners of the 24 major league teams for one hour today and warned that baseball "must" restore a club to Washington by 1973.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas ordered the Government today to stop drafting men in the Los Angeles area into the Army until some time next year.
