PARIS, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Baron Guy de Rothschild of the banking family gave a fancy-dress party tonight and his chateau glittered with the bejeweled elite of the international society. The display was topped by Elizabeth Taylor, the actress, in diamonds worth an estimated sum of $3-million.

NOROTON, Conn., Dee. 2-The Noroton School, a socially prestigious Roman Catholic secondary boarding and day school for girls operated by the Society of the Sacred Heart in Noroton, Conn., will close its doors in June, 1972.

The counsel for the Municipal Loan Program warned two and a half years ago that mortgages for which the city was giving money to loan applicants should be more carefully checked, but he was overruled by his superiors, a City Council committee was told yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Senate-House conferees on the big tax-reduction bill have given President Nixon one new weapon to use in forthcoming foreign trade negotiations but otherwise have eliminated all "protectionist" trade provisions added by the Senate.

A New York policeman was found guilty of perjury last night on charges that he had lied to a Bronx grand jury about a series of meetings with Bronx gamblers to determine how much they should pay for protection from arrest.
GENEVA, Dec. 2 -- An I.O.S. spokesman here declined tonight to comment on the Federal suit. He said the headquarters here had not yet been in touch with the company's lawyers in the United States.
PARIS, Dec. 2 -- William J. Porter, the American delegate to the Vietnam peace talks, pressed North Vietnam again today to permit "a normal flow of mail" from American prisoners held there.

Your Nov. 23 editorial on the Forest Hills conflict is marked by its inconsistency. On the one hand, The Times states that it is desirable that housing for low-income citizens "be moved out of the imprisonment of existing slums into an environment of dignity and hope."

A 12-year-old student at Joan of Arc Junior High School was struck on the head by a filing cabinet that was dropped from the sixth floor yesterday afternoon and was admitted to St. Luke's Hospital in serious condition.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- President Nixon pledged today to seek reform of school financing in America to reduce the tax burden on property owners, especially the elderly.
LONDON, Dec. 2 -- A 24-year-old soprano from New Zealand scored a triumph as the Countess last night in a new production of Mozart's "Le Nozze di Figaro" at the Royal Opera House.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The Senate confirmed Dr. Earl L. Butz as Secretary of Agriculture today, 51 to 44.
There are times when Josephine Hughes wonders whether the whole thing is worth it.

The British Petroleum Company, Ltd., realized a 74 per cent increase in third-quarter earnings on a sales gain of 26.7 per cent, the report from London headquarters disclosed yesterday. The results for the nine months ended with September showed earnings up 108.5 per cent and sales 30.3 per cent ahead of last year's figures.
Michael Edmonds, who is 11 years old, has rescued a runaway spider monkey from the upper branches of a maple tree in Riverside Park.

A top executive of the General Motors Corporation urged fellow business leaders here yesterday to work for greater public understanding of the profit system "before hostility and indifference lead the Government to further limit freedom of enterprise."

City officials and local Democratic members of the State Legislature charged yesterday that Governor Rockefeller and the Republican legislative leadership had gone back on their word to support a transit-fare package agreed on here.

NEW DELHI, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The lower house of the Indian Parliament approved a constitutional amendment today to reduce maharajas to commoners by abolishing their $6.4-million in annual privy purses and many other princely privileges.

In his Nov. 22 Op-Ed article on the Kennedy assassination David W. Belin writes of "the susceptibility of human nature" to fall victim to the "mystique of conspiracy" in accounting for the public interest in the "assassin sensationalists." Mr. Belin then proceeds to "pounce" on one aspect of the case: namely, the immediate arrest of Lee Harvey Oswald.

In a quarter of a century, even Bach changes, or at least our view of him does. The Bach Aria Group, founded in 1946 when Bach's ensemble music did not often appear in concert halls, has been taking a slightly different approach to the composer in recent years.

In light of the two letters dealing with the Mideast in your Nov. 20 column and with the visit of Israeli Premier Meir to Washington in search of weapons and diplomatic support, the American public should be aware of the potential ramifications for our nation in both the explicit and implied commitments we have in that region.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Two liberal mavericks on the House Appropriations Committee -- Representatives Robert N. Giaimo and Silvio O. Conte -- successfully challenged the patriarchs of the House today by winning unexpected approval of funds for a subway in the District of Columbia.

OSLO, Norway -- In this time of great diplomatic bargaining, shifting power patterns and kaleidoscopic changes on the international scene, the only region where one can reckon there will be no fundamental transformation is Eastern Europe.

BOCA RATON, Fla., Dec. 2 -- The Securities Industry Association moved past its final organizational hurdle this week as the Investment Bankers Association, in a vote announced today, decided overwhelmingly to dissolve itself and become part of the new group.

" An organization that is close to a political administration is bound to have advantages that others don't have," Alex Rose, vice president of the Liberal party, said yesterday of the controversial John V. Lindsay Associations.

COMMACK, L. I., Dec. 2 -- Dean, Hiltzek, an 18-year-old sophomore at Columbia, took the lead in the senior men's competition as the North Atlantic figure skating championships started today at the Long Island Arena.

MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 2 -- More than 200 protesters demanded yesterday the suspension of a Nassau County policeman who shot and killed a 16-year-old black Freeport youth last week after chasing a stolen automobile in which the youth was riding.
You talk to the average small businessman and he may tell you that the nation is still in the throes of a major recession -- with a possible depression on the way.

E. B. White, author, essayist and a longtime pillar of The New Yorker magazine, received yesterday the National Book Committee's bronze Medal for Literature and $5,000 at its annual meeting at the Library and Museum of the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center.
The Board of Education has asked the State Public Employment Relations Board to classify the city's 900 school principals as "managerial employes," thereby exempting them from collective bargaining.

The Federal Government filed a lawsuit yesterday seeking almost $75-million from Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., and its former head, Bernard Cornfeld, on a complaint that they had illegally speculated in gold.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 2 (UPI) -- Only minor skirmishes were reported today in the 11-day-old South Vietnamese sweep through the rubber plantation country of Eastern Cambodia.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The Democratic plan for financing the 1972 Presidential campaign with Federal tax revenue was dropped today by a Senate-House conference committee at the suggestion of Representative Wilbur D. Mills.
The Dallas Cowboys, hoping for another chance in the Super Bowl, could come a cropper in Texas Stadium tomorrow afternoon against the New York Jets.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Secretary of the Interior Rogers C. B. Morton said today that Interior Department approval of the controversial Trans-Alaska oil pipeline should be given by the end of January, but said later that he did not mean he definitely would approve the project.

In the first direct attack on Mayor Lindsay's record as a Presidential campaign issue, a high New York campaign aide of Senator George McGovern declared yesterday that the McGovern forces were scrutinizing the Mayor's City Hall performance and expected that it would be a "national issue."
When Chalk, Nissen, Hanft, opens its doors Monday they will not be at 666 Fifth Avenue as they have been for three years but at 245 Park Avenue in office space owned by Clyne Maxon, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The State Department said today that it considered as "closed" an incident with Chile over the public remark by a White House aide that he had obtained the "feeling" on a Latin-American tour that the Socialist regime of President Salvador Allende Gossens would not "last long."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- United States business plans a fairly large increase in investment in plant and equipment in the fourth quarter of the current year and the first half of next year, over the levels that prevailed up to September, the Commerce Department and the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.
Controversy has become a way of life for the Boston public schools. Their neglected facilities and obsolete pedagogical practices have long been under fire from educational reformers.

In a record turnout, Uruguay's voters demonstrated emphatically that they have not given up on the country's democratic system and greatly prefer the two traditional parties to a leftist coalition similar to the one now governing Chile. The Frente Amplio (Broad Front), embracing Communists, Socialists, radical Catholics and others, made a respectable showing; but even in Montevideo, where it had hoped to elect a mayor, the Front trailed the governing Colorado party by 50,000 votes.

The Thomas Betts Corporation announced yesterday the election of J. David Parkinson as executive vice president. Formerly corporate vice president, Mr. Parkinson will continue in his present capacity as president of the Thomas Betts Company, the company's major operating division and as head of two subsidiaries. Thomas Betts International, Inc., and Westline Products.
It took Augustus C. Long just about 15 months to develop himself and the board of Texaco, Inc.

SAO PAULO, Brazil -- A wave of prosperity, building for five years, has broken over the cities of Brazil, flooding them with new cars and bringing them new pastimes and new consumer's way of life modeled directly on the "American way."

Erich Leinsdorf is largely occupied these days conducting "Tristan und Isolde" at the Metropolitan Opera. Perhaps that is why the program in which he led the Boston Symphony Orchestra in Philharmonic Hall Wednesday night was relatively brief and unchallenging.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 2 -- Despite an undercurrent of pressure from physicians and medical associations in various nations, the World Psychiatric Association has apparently decided that it cannot issue a statement condemning the use of psychiatry as a tool for political repression.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Dec. 2 -- Avery Brundage and his threats of Olympic expulsion will all but be forgotten tomorrow when the 1971-72 skiing season begins here with a women's 1 1/2-mile downhill race to a finish line above the clouds.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Dec. 2 -- Thousands of Cambodian Government troops were reported in disorderly retreat today as a major military campaign north of the capital collapsed in the face of heavy North Vietnamese attacks.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 2 -- American pilots here said today that a North Vietnamese MIG fighter fired air-to-air missiles at an American Air Force B-52 bomber over the Ho Chi Minh Trail network in Laos about 10 days ago, but missed and was chased back into North Vietnam.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2 -- Last Saturday the Knicks played one of their finest games of the National Basketball Association season to edge the Chicago Bulls, 100-99, in New York. The victory was an exhilarating one for the Knicks because it extended a winning streak to seven games and came against the team with the third best won-lost record in the league.
ORLANDO, Fla., Dec. 2 -- Terry Dill, who made Muleshoe, Tex., a household word among golfers when he joined the pro ranks a decade ago, led the Walt Disney world open today with a 65.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Despite the threat of a Presidential veto, the Senate approved tonight, 63 to 17, a compromise plan creating a vast new system of day care and other services for the nation's children.
Differing forecasts of future earnings results were offered yesterday by two large real estate investment trusts.

It took Rhode Island 30 minutes of playing time last night to live up to its preseason ranking as one of the top teams in the East. But once the taller, stronger, talent-laden Rams matched their offensive strength with their aggressive defense, they overpowered Manhattan in the first game of the opening double-header of the Madison Square Garden college basketball season.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Following is a summary of the major provisions of the tax bill, which was approved in its final version by a Senate-House conference committee today.

Joel Myers, the ski-minded meteorologist at Penn State University, predicted yesterday that a sizable snowstorm would hit the metropolitan New York area starting at dawn tomorrow. He said the chances of it materializing were about 90 per cent.

Hunters and fishermen are marvelously inventive when creating excuses for their failure to bring home fish or game, but one of the more remarkable tales in this genre, remarkable because it is true, came to me the other day from my brother, Dan.

Mike Freeman, who trains for Alfred Vanderbilt, waited for the right day to run his boss's Cold Comfort. With the temperature as low as it was at Aqueduct yesterday, Freeman, who had scratched Cold Comfort several times recently, sent the 4-year-old filly into the feature race on the program, a six-furlong purse for fillies and mares, and she responded perfectly.
The Price Commission and the Pay Board are both giving evidence this week of renewed determination to keep above-limit price and wage increases from wrecking the anti-inflation program.

ANDREWS AIR FORCE BASE, Md., Dec. 2 -- Secretary Connally said tonight that the United States had been "quite forthcoming" in its stand at this week's monetary negotiations in Rome and had "retreated" from its original position in the interest of reaching agreement.
The Beecham Group, Ltd., made yesterday one of the biggest British take-over bids in years by offering to acquire the Glaxo Group, Ltd., for stock valued at approximately $737-million.
Eliot Fremont-Smith has resigned as editor in chief of the general books division of Little, Brown Co., the 135-year-old Boston publishing house now part of Time Inc.

The city's Parking Violations Bureau, which has handled almost as many summonses as there are New Yorkers in its short life span, was described yesterday at a legislative hearing as irksome at best and unconstitutional at worst.

Indicating impatience with the leaders of the Legislature, including those of his own party, Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that he had "no alternative" to calling a special session of the Legislature this month on the state's fiscal crisis.
Federal agents announced yesterday the seizure of three tons of marijuana at a Long Island City, Queens, warehouse and the arrest of three young men described as the wholesale distributors.
DETROIT, Dec. 2 -- Who would want a power plant in his community, particularly one with nuclear power?

With very active buying by grain exporters and commission houses, prices of corn futures rose on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday. At the close, prices were up 1/2 cent to 1 1/8 cents a bushel, at about the highs of the day.

New Yorkers in four pilot neighborhoods will soon be able to take complaints about garbage pickups, park cleanups, police protection and social services to a new city government authority in their community, under a decentralization plan close to being completed by the Lindsay administration.
COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Dec. 2 (AP) -- Rain washed out the first round of qualifying for the Texas 500-mile stock car race today, leaving Jackie Oliver of England in a state of nervous exhaustion.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Diplomatic informants here said today that the $100-million effort of the United Nations relief agency in East Pakistan is "grinding to a halt" and that the agency has abandoned 162 new trucks, bought with international relief funds, at Chittagong because of fighting in the area.
The over-the-counter market outperformed the American Stock Exchange yesterday as most counter issues advanced while the exchange finished mixed.
A House of Commons committee recommended a 106 per cent pay rise for Queen Elizabeth II and hefty raises for other members of the royal family.
Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).
MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 2 -- The constitutional right of a public employe to determine the length of his hair, side-burns, mustache and beard was upheld in State Supreme Court here today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The Senate voted unanimously today to put broad powers and $1.5-billion behind a coordinated Federal campaign against illicit drugs.

Drivers for the Bee Line bus system voted yesterday to continue their wildcat strike in support of a suspended bus driver and union official, forcing 20,000 Nassau County residents to use cars or the Long Island Rail Road for a second day.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Premier Golda Meir of Israel conferred privately with President Nixon for two hours today in an effort to reconcile the differences between their Governments.

Joseph Papp, whose dream envisions shirt-sleeved audiences filling theaters bereft of box offices, showed up in white tie and tails at the Broadway opening of "Two Gentlemen of Verona" Wednesday night.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- An American company announced today that it had received Commerce Department approval to exhibit its aerial navigation equipment at a Swedish trade fair in Peking next April.
The state's highest court agreed yesterday to hear, on the first day of its January term, the case of five local reporters who are seeking access to the trial of Carmine 2. Persieo.

PARIS, Dec. 2 -- The dollar fell today to new lows in trading in Europe and Japan following the monetary meeting in Rome at which the United States said it might consider a formal devaluation for the first time since 1934.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The Selective Service System has all but halted inductions throughout the nation this month because local boards have called up draftees faster than anticipated, a spokesman said today.

NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 2 (UPI) -- A Navy pilot apparently blacked out at the controls of his jet today and the plane streaked across the southeastern United States, from Mobile, Ala., to Virginia, before crashing in the Atlantic Ocean 250 miles off Norfolk.

CIVITAVECCHIA, Italy, Dec 2 -- This old and somewhat scruffy port city has been shaken by an environmental scandal that landed the Mayor in prison for 30 hours, pitted the administration against the courts and exposed what many saw as bureaucratic indifference to public-health emergencies.

The overwhelming decision of the Senate to extend for one year, to April 30, 1973, the Administration's authority to control the economy represents a victory for national necessity over the temptation to play partisan politics with the stabilization effort.
Asbestos workers have been found to develop serious lung disease after two decades of breathing air containing asbestos fibers in amounts long considered "safe."
NEW DELHI, Dec. 2 -- Prime Minister Indira Gandhi declared today that the "so-called big nations" could not "give orders to Indians."
There's no doubt that Clifton McNeil, the former Giant, will be trying to prove to the Giants that they made a bad deal in trading him to Washington, when the teams meet in the capital on Sunday.
WARSAW, Dec. 2 -- Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans said today that the United States had "set its sights on a substantial increase in trade with Poland."

SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 2 -- The two big United States copper companies whose major properties were nationalized without compensation in July have started an appeals process in a special Chilean court against the Government's decision.
Two Queens policemen were arrested yesterday on charges of taking $200 to release two burglary suspects.
Two residential Brooklyn communities of $60,000-to-$100,000 homes are going to court in hopes of blocking construction of a 904-unit middle-and low - income apartment complex in their midst.

PARIS -- After World War II, most Rumanian intellectuals of the older generation suffered from a guilt complex which the Government twisted to its advantage. In fact, very few writers were Communists or even leftists before the war; those who had been were quickly disillusioned by the flagrant discrepancies between Marxist theory and Stalinist application.

Directors of Omega-Alpha, Inc., and the Transcontinental Investing Corporation announced yesterday they have agreed on modifications of terms for a proposed merger of Transcontinental into Omega-Alpha.

A lawyer was sentenced in Federal Court here yesterday to eight years in prison for the illegal possession of nine $100,000 United States Treasury bills stolen from the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company.

IRVING, Tex., Dec. 3 -- If the Jets can keep Joe Namath as protected as a rare gem tomorrow, the quarterback and his receivers could have a sparkling game of catch on the Tartan turf of Texas Stadium.
SRINAGAR, Kashmir, Dec. 3 (Reuters) -- Six Pakistani Sabrejets made a low-level bombing raid on Srinagar Airport today and attacked another nearby area, Indian officials said.

DETROIT, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Erwin Mueller, taking over for Bob Lanier, injured center, in the third period, tossed in 16 points tonight to provide the spark that enabled the Detroit Pistons to top the Houston Rockets, 113-112. The Pistons snapped a five-game losing streak.

In a rare display of bipartisan unity, the New York Congressional delegation yesterday endorsed a statement calling for speedy action by Congress on Representative Wilbur D. Mills's substitute for President Nixon's revenue-sharing program.

WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Dec. 3 -- In complete control once the second half got under way, the New York Nets snapped their four-game losing streak with a flourish tonight by defeating the Carolina Cougars, 134-122.
TOKYO, Dec. 3 -- Premier Elsaku Sato dismissed his defense minister and named a successor today, giving Japan its fourth such minister in the last six months.

The Hertz Corporation, an affiliate of the RCA Corporation, announced yesterday the elections of Ronald J. Perman as chairman and chief executive officer and Gerald Shapiro as president and chief operating officer.
Democratic members of the State Assembly held an unofficial hearing here yesterday to look into the affairs of the State Narcotic Addiction Control Commission.
CLEVELAND, Tenn., Dec. 3 AP) -- Two men, wearing ski masks and armed with shotguns, robbed a bank guard of more than $100,000 today, an official of the Cleveland Bank and Trust Company said.
BONN, Dec. 3 -- West Germany's spreading industrial malaise has begun to touch some of the giant industries of the Ruhr.
This year may become the city's wettest since the Central Park weather station was established in 1868.

WASHINGTON -- While her deep purple robes and bronzed Navajo features distinguished 71-year-old Lenora Collins from most of the delegates here this week for the White House Conference on Aging, she suffers a dilemma common to many of the country's 20 million elderly: maintaining a healthy diet on a budget.

GENEVA, Dec. 3 -- Robert L. Vesco, head of the Investors Overseas Services mutual-fund group, is retiring at the end of the month as a director of the Overseas Development Bank of Geneva at the request of the Swiss Federal Banking Commission, a member of the commission said today.

A 40-year old professor of law at Fordham University was named special guardian yesterday of all human fetuses between the 4th and 24th weeks of gestation scheduled to be aborted in the municipal hospitals here.

Peace, not revenge, was the message circulated yesterday by leaders of the Ghetto Brothers street gang in the South Bronx as they mourned a member fatally struck down Thursday as he was trying to be a peacemaker.
A suspect in this week's robbery of $16,000 from an upper Manhattan bank and the theft of weapons from a Yonkers armory was arrested yesterday in New Jersey.

UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 3 -- No formal request for a Security Council meeting on the Indian-Pakistani conflict was forthcoming here today, although the 10 elected, nonpermanent members of the Council met privately to discuss the crisis.
BERLIN, Dec. 3 (AP) -- East Germany said tonight that it considered completed the talks it held with the West German and West Berlin governments on the four-power Berlin accord.
DETROIT, Dec. 3 -- A major scandal involving Federal mortgage programs in Detroit has left the Government the owner of thousands of decrepit homes and may cost up to $200-million in Federal funds.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The Senate Armed Services Committee, troubled by the increasing costs of weapons, began hearings today on the procurement procedures of the Defense Department.

In an effort to halt work on the controversial low-income housing project in Forest Hills, Queens, opponents filed a complaint yesterday accusing Mayor Lindsay and Simeon Golar, head of the city's Housing Authority, of "fraud" in pushing the project.

BONN, Nov. 3 -- The omission of any reference to troop cuts in Europe from the Warsaw Alliance's latest call for a European security conference surprised and disappointed members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, diplomatic sources said today.

LONDON, Dec. 3 -- One of the odd advantages of that constitutional anachronism, the British House of Lords, is that its members, representing no one but themselves, can escape partisan simplicities and speak their minds. And so, the other day, Lord Goodman treated his noble colleagues to a rare examination of the limits on morality in politics.

With more than 400 works by Sargent in its bins, the Metropolitan Museum of Art has chosen about one in 10 for an exhibition of water-colors (and a few drawings) that show how a fashionable portrait painter relaxed.

The move to reinstate 31 former New York City teachers who were dismissed almost two decades ago for allegedly subversive views or membership in subversive organizations is a belated effort to repair unconscionable damage to their careers. It is also an essential action to erase a shameful chapter in the school system's history, which was rendered no less offensive by the fact that it reflected a national mood of hysteria.
Most people would never use the word homey to describe the glamorous decor that Jay Steffy has devised for the new headquarters of Warner Bros. Records, Inc.
The United States and the Soviet Union are said to be ready to sign an agreement in the next two months that could lead to a joint manned space flight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Barry G. Cohen, an electrical engineer, has built a business around an infrared microscope for which he was granted a patent this week. Research Devices, Inc., Elizabeth, N.J., of which Mr. Cohen is president, makes instruments that enable police agencies to detect counterfeits and forgeries.

More than $90,000 in cash left in the trunk of a passenger car by employes of a check-cashing company was stolen yesterday when the car was driven off while the three men assigned to the job were cashing checks for Trans World Airlines employes at Kennedy International Airport.
The RCA Corporation announced yesterday that it was phasing out its magnetic products business in line with its withdrawal from the computer industry.

ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 3 -- Turkey's Premier. Nihat Erim, resigned today after more than half his Cabinet had resigned over policy differences. The collapse of the Government renewed the threat of a direct military takeover.

YONKERS, Dec. 3 -- Rum Customer's quest for a spot among harness racing's "millionaires" was frustrated tonight. The heavily favored 6-year-old was beaten a neck by Bossman Lobell, the $17-for-$2 third choice in the $20,000 Meadow Skipper Pace at Yonkers Raceway.

The Borough Presidents of the Bronx and Manhattan reported agreement yesterday on allowing Marble Hill's 6,800 residents to have a plebiscite on whether to make their community legally part of the Bronx.
NEW DELHI, Dec. 3 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's radio speech to the nation tonight:
DETROIT, Dec. 3 -- New-car sales in November continued at a record rate, but some slowing was expected this month.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Dec. 3 -- Anne-Marie Proell, an 18-year-old Salzburg salesgirl won the women's downhill, the opening race of the Alpine ski season today, a day after she said she wouldn't win.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The nation's unemployment rate edged upward in November to 6 per cent of the labor force despite another good gain in the number of people employed, the Labor Department reported today.

Despite last-minute pleas from groups of the elderly and two City Councilmen, the Rent and Housing Maintenance Commissioner, Benjamin Altman, said yesterday that he was powerless to extend the deadline for the filing of rent-increase exemptions by the elderly beyond last midnight.
Chris-Craft Industries, Inc., yesterday mailed a letter to its stockholders attacking two leaders of the proxy fight against management, Richard Kelly and David Cohen.

In reference to your recent editorial regarding regulation of strip mining for coal, we should like to add a few neglected points that may shed a different light on the strip-mining controversy. The statement "Conventional underground mining also has its adverse effects, but with careful planning those ill effects are much more easily controlled" implies that, with care and money, there is a ready alternative to strip mining.
Alex Webster will coach the New York Giants next season, Wellington Mara, the club owner, said yesterday. There was no formal announcement, and no actual contract signing

Mrs. Spiro T. Agnew showed none of her husband's penchant for loaded language as she spoke at a breakfast at the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Agnew, who came to New York with the Vice President for a National Association of Manufacturers meeting, seemed more inclined to low-key remarks on various subjects.

The belief of many traders that the new Secretary of Agriculture, Earl L. Butz, would increase Government support prices of gains, led to increased volume, and prices for grain and soybean futures on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- During the debate on the House floor recently on legislation limiting campaign spending, Representative Bertram L. Podell, Democrat of Brooklyn, described how local party leaders were interested in talking about only "one qualification" when they asked if he was interested in running for Congress in 1968.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Saturday, Dec. 4 -- Pakistan charged last night that the Indian Army had attacked at least four points along West Pakistan's border. The Pakistani Air Force and Army have been given orders to penetrate India as deeply as possible, a Government spokesman said.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The Internal Revenue Service held today that tenants were legally entitled to withhold rent increases from landlords who refused to produce the records justifying them.

MOSCOW, Dec. 3 -- Four days of talks by United States business leaders here this week were described today as having been useful in exposing top American corporate leadership to high Soviet officials.

The people who run the new Amtrak system can learn how it's done simply by reviewing a few case histories of American railroads. The Chicago North Western Railway Company, which used to serve my home town of Escanaba, Mich., offers a perfect example.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Dec. 3 -- Ten more players -- including Dave Roberts and Wayne Granger -- were traded today as professional baseball ended its winter business meetings after the most bullish manpower market in the history of the major leagues.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The Senate began debate tonight on President Nixon's nomination of Lewis F. Powell Jr. to the Supreme Court and scheduled a vote on him at 4 P.M. Monday.

Mr. Simmons would have us allow logging in order to "improve" the esthetic qualities of the area and promote conservation.

When Eddie (Popeye) Egan's image on celluloid caught up with him yesterday, he did not attempt to back away from it with fancy word-splitting about the difference between appearance and reality or metaphor and fact.
MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 3 -- A three-day wildcat strike by rivers of the Bee Line bus system ended today when the drivers agreed to return to work in time for the evening rush hour.

Roosevelt and the Alliance for Progress, begun by John F. Kennedy. He said these policies had "lumped the Latin-American countries together as banana republics."

BUFFALO, Dec. 3 (UPI) -- Walt Hazzard's free throw with four seconds left on a technical foul called against Cleveland for too many time-outs gave the Buffalo Braves a 91-90 victory tonight and cracked the Cavaliers' five-game winning streak.

MONTREAL, Dec. 3 -- The Quebec Securities Commission today refused to upset the temporary removal of a stockbroker, Harry W. Andrews, as chairman of the Canadian Stock Exchange. The exchange, thus, apparently has decided to continue its investigation into the affairs of Mr. Andrews's firm, Holland, Andrews, Perrier Co., Ltd.

A 58-year-old man was arrested on the Lower East Side last night for allegedly attempting to bribe a policeman who had caught him, the police said, with possession of untaxed cigarettes and obscene materials.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Premier Golda Meir of Israel said today that there were still "some differences of opinion" between the United States and Israel on the Middle East despite her lengthy conversations yesterday with the Nixon Administration.
Three more retail chains reported yesterday strong gains in November and year-to-date sales, following similar reports by others on Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Key officials of both the Republican and the Democratic parties made new commitments today to work for the goal of increased representation of women at the Presidential nominating conventions next year.

BHARSHALA, Pakistan, Saturday, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Pakistani troops, led by two Russian-made tanks, fought a sharp battle more than six miles inside Pakistan yesterday but were forced back by heavy Indian artillery fire.
A Westchester County auto salesman has been charged with grand larceny in a purported "pyramid scheme" in which he allegedly sold Lincoln and Mercury automobiles for as little as half price.

Vincent R. Sombrotto, president, and other officers of Branch 36 here of the National Association of Letter Carriers were removed from their posts yesterday, and the local was put under the direction of a trustee.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- William D. Ruckelshaus, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, announced today proposed emission standards for industry on three hazardous air pollutants -- asbestos, berryllium and mercury.

ATLANTA, Dec. 5 -- Oakland and Atlanta, both harboring Super Bowl hopes, put on an excellent demonstration of the art of giving today, but Oakland was just a little more excellent at it and that's why Atlanta won, 24-13.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 5 -- A hundred feet of sidewalk and a dozen police from the 17th Precinct kept the peace today between rival Pakistani demonstrators marching outside the United Nations.
NEW DELHI, Monday, Dec. 6 -- India today recognized the East Pakistan rebel movement as the government of that area as Indian troops continued to advance into the eastern province of Pakistan.

RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 5 (AP) -- An air safety investigator said today that an Eastern Airlines DC-9 involved in a collision yesterday had been cleared to land at the Raleigh-Durham Airport when the accident occurred.

Applications are being sought in the New York City area by the National Urban Fellows, a nationwide program designed to meet the shortage of urban administrators and to open leadership opportunities in government, especially for minority-group members.

FOXBORO, Mass., Dec. 5 -- Sabotaged by four fumbles and a Disneyland dwarf, the Miami Dolphins were upset, 34-13, by the New England Patriots today after eight consecutive victories. Liora Sarch, a gifted young pianist who was born in Israel, was raised in Venezuela and at present lives in New York with her husband, Kenneth Sarch, the violinist, made her debut at Alice Tully Hall yesterday, afternoon.

Either from nervousness, or surprise at being so close, the Vancouver Canucks failed repeatedly to convert in front of the Ranger goal last night and became another Madison Square Garden victim, bowing by 6-3.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Dec. 5 -- Pakistani troops were reported today to be advancing along the cease-fire line in Kashmir, the Himalayan state whose status has been the subject of two previous Indian-Pakistani wars.

MILESTONE, Miss. -- It was cool for the Mississippi Delta, but Walter Caesar Jr. perspired heavily and bits of cotton clung to his broad, black face as he moved an ungainly mechanical cotton picker back and forth across his 26 acres of ripened cotton.

FORT LEE, N. J., Dec. 6 -Giuseppe Antonio Doto, known in life as Joe Adonis, was buried here today, accompanied to the wind-chilled Madonna Roman Catholic Cemetery by members of his immediate family.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Otis Taylor scored touchdowns on two spectacular plays and Jan Stenerud kicked four field goals tonight as the Kansas City Chiefs beat the San Francisco 49ers, 26-17, in a battle of first-place teams.

JACKSON, Miss., Dec. 6 (AP) -- An official of the Democratic National Committee says the Justice Department will be asked to look into charges by blacks that they lost some contests in the recent general elections because of fraud and intimidation.

HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Dec. 6 -Suffolk County Executive-elect John V. N. Klein has embarked on a comprehensive study of the county's "fiscal crisis," that he said today could lead in January to a one-cent-on-thedollar increase in the county's sales tax.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The South Vietnamese command said that air strikes had killed 18 enemy soldiers from 7 to 25 miles inside Cambodia in a corridor between the Chup and Mimot rubber plantations. Both plantations are reported to be base areas for Vietcong and North Vietnamese divisions.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 6 -- The Tennessee Valley Authority issued a new and tougher set of rules today under which companies that supply the agency with 16 million tons a year of strip-mined coal must work to reclaim the scarred earth.
Spurred on by the prospect of major increases in postal rates, the Magazine Publishers Association is Planning a test of an alternate delivery system in Oklahoma City.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Senator John V. Tunney of California will endorse Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine for the Democratic Presidential nomination on Wednesday, authoritative sources said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama said today that "the second best thing" for him as a 1972 Presidential candidate would be to deadlock the Electoral College and exact policy commitments from President Nixon as the price of his re-election.

CALCUTTA, India, Dec. 6 -East Pakistanis in Calcutta, the headquarters of the secession movement, celebrated India's formal recognition of that government today with happy processions, sloganshouting and dancing and singing. But the five-member cabinet itself was nowhere in sight -- a situation typical of this group of uncharismatic politicians waiting for a man in a West Pakistani prison to show them the way.

If you still don't believe that statistics can lie, ask the New York Giants. They have learned, in the most painful way, how misleading blind numbers can be.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Eight sailors who sought sanctuary in a San Diego church in October when the carrier Constellation sailed for Southeast Asia were given "general discharges under honorable conditions" today, the Navy said.

TOKYO, Dec. 6 -- The yen was traded today at its highest rate since it was floated on Aug. 28, 324.70 yen to the dollar, as a result of the heavy sales of American currency in the Tokyo foreign-exchange market. Turnover amounted to $148,790,000.

BERLIN, Dec. 6 -- The East Germans and the West Berlin city government remained deadlocked today on the issue of visiting privileges for West Berliners in the East, but Western officials said that they expected that a fresh approach would be made soon.
NAVEN, Ireland, Dec. 1 -In a secluded house here, a chunky English-born Irishman quietly directs the terrorist tactics of the Irish Republican Army Provisionals in Northern Ireland.

MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 6 -Nassau County Executive Ralph G. Caso said today that the county would sue in State Supreme Court here this week to prevent the cities of Glen Cove and Long Beach from "illegally usurping" the county's right to a one-cent-on-the-dollar increase in the sales tax in their jurisdictions.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Continuing to brand India as the "main aggressor" in the war with Pakistan, the United States suspended a large part of its economic aid to New Delhi today.

ALBANY, Dec. 6 -- "Maybe that's the trouble," Governor Rockefeller told a gathering in New York City the other day. "This is the 13th year."

NEWARK, Dec. 6 -- Thomas J. Whelan, former Mayor of Jersey City, and Thomas M. Flaherty, former City Council President there, pleaded guilty today in Federal Court here to charges of income-tax fraud.

There were several plus factors to Rose Bozin's debut in Carnegie Recital Hall late Sunday afternoon. One was the imaginative programing: the soprano's choice of material included a number of songs requiring various instrumental combinations and the contrasts in timbre were most effective.

Any concert that concludes with Berlioz's Rakoczy March played on four harps automatically scores a high point in unusual if not bizarre programing. But the four women of the New York Harp Ensemble had several other surprises for their Carnegie Recital Hall concert Sunday night.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 6 -Thanksgiving began normally for Florence Falk. She roasted a turkey for her husband, Richard, the Albert G. Milbank Professor of International Law and Practice at Princeton University, and for her son, Dmitri, 2. But when she opened a jar of baby food for her infant of seven months, Noah, she found a worm on top.

A cheerful new central children's room with open stacks, earphones, a rare-book room and a story-telling room will open tomorrow at the Donnell branch of the New York Public Library at 20 West 53d Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The Senate confirmed today the nomination of Lewis F. Powell Jr. to the Supreme Court by a vote of 89 to 1 and immediately began to debate the more controversial nomination of William H. Rehnquist.

At first glance, Senator Edward M. Kennedy looks mighty good in the latest Gallup Poll of Democratic Presidential possibilities. Muskie.

The most-wanted man in the world of bridge is no doubt Britain's Harold Franklin, who passed through New York yesterday on his way to Las Vegas. Tournament organizers all over the world seek him out to benefit from his experience and expertise in the specialized art of directing tournaments.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Dec. 6 -- Attorney General John N. Mitchell announced today a series of steps that, he said, will help the country's prisons go beyond merely detaining prisoners toward actually rehabilitating them.

DPF, Inc., formerly the Data Processing Financial and General Corporation, announced last night the resignation of Ryal R. Poppa as president, chief executive officer and a director, effective Jan. 1. He agreed to remain as a consultant for one year.

On Saturday, a woman shopper brought her children to Bonwit Teller's 721 Club, which, until then, had been a traditional haven of harried men Christmas shoppers. The woman got loaded at the club, which one habitue refers to as "the only place you can get a decent drink on Fifth Avenue."

The Community Advisory Committee to the Off-Track Betting Corporation announced yesterday that it would work for the legalization of the numbers racket, which is thought to be a $500-million annual operation in New York City.

The city's Office of Midtown Planning and Development yesterday proposed closing Madison Avenue from 42d to 57th Street to all but bus and emergency traffic next spring and creating a pedestrian mall there graced by trees, sidewalk cafes, decorative pavements, bus shelters, drinking fountains and new forms of lighting.

School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner directed yesterday that high school diplomas be awarded on the basis of educational standards and not be denied, withheld or delayed to punish a student for poor conduct in school.

Maryland and Minnesota dropped their football coaches last week without so much as a "thank you" and began looking for the men who will coach their teams back to national prominence. They are dying in greater numbers now; and still the Council is blocked, by great-power rivalry, ideological conflict, hypocrisy and indifference, from taking even a modest first step to end the bloodshed.
