WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- A pelting rainstorm briefly sidetracked today a 75-page, minute-by-minute scenario complete with maps and diagrams for the three-day state visit of President Emilio G. Medici of Brazil.
AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Three United States women defeated Anzac rivals today in the $44,800 New Zealand open tennis championships.
The city's offtrack betting corporation announced plans yesterday to begin its first fullscale wagering on out-of-town tracks by taking bets on racing at Tropical Park in Miami starting next Monday.

Justice Goldberg misconstrues when he states in his Nov. 17 Op-Ed article that he "would reject that strain of political self-protection that underlies theories of judicial restraint." I thought that judicial restraint is intended to include just the opposite, the rejection of political motivation as a factor in determining individual cases.

An indictment charging two former Federal narcotics agents with extortion and conspiracy was dismissed in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday after the Government said there was "no realistic possibility" of convicting the two in an impending third trial.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The Board of Governors of the United States Postal Service today named one of its members, Elmer T. Klassen, to become Postmaster General on Jan. 1.

BONN, Dec. 7 -- The deadlock between East Germany and West Berlin on fixing final details of the four-power accord on Berlin has laid bare a conflict between East and West German interests, in the opinion of experts on both sides.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Dec. 8 (AP) -- South Vietnam is preparing to release scores more North Vietnamese and Vietcong prisoners of war during forthcoming holidays in the hope that Hanoi will reciprocate by freeing American prisoners, official sources said today.

DALLAS, Dec. 7 (Reuters) -Ling-Temco-Vought, Inc., said today a registration statement is being filed with the S.E.C. for a proposed exchange offer to holders of six different classes of company warrants.
When Vern Studdard woke up in Baylor Hospital in Dallas last Saturday evening, he thought he had a broken leg.
RAVENNA, Ohio, Dec. 7 (AP) -- The state dismissed today for lack of evidence the 20 remaining cases against persons indicted in the Kent State University disorders of May, 1970.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 7 -The old venomous Cold War rhetoric is back again at the United Nations -this time between Ambassadors Yakov Malik of the Soviet Union and Huang Hua of China -- but somehow even the vindictive daily slanging matches between the Communist giants seem a little out of date.
Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, the citadel of the American cultural Establishment, announced yesterday that for the first time it is opening its doors to neighborhood performing artists.

In a three-hour meeting at the International Hotel in Kennedy International Airport, shareholders of the Chock full o'Nuts Corporation yesterday upheld the selection of the company's board of directors and defeated a number of proposals made by dissident stockholders.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court refused today to disturb a New Jersey law providing for free transportation to school for many students of private and parochial schools.
The winter of Spider Lockhart's discontent may have started some time in the summer when his name was left out of the New York Giants' 1971 press guide.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Spot checks on subsidies by the Department of Agriculture have turned up apparent irregularities on a number of big farms in California, including one owned by the administrator of the subsidy program.

The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company showed a 22.4 per cent increase in operating earnings in the fiscal year ended Oct. 31 on a sales gain of 6.4 per cent, the company reported yesterday from headquarters in Akron, Ohio. Earnings in the final fiscal quarter were up 25.7 per cent while sales rose 10.8 per cent from the year-earlier level.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -Walter E. Fauntroy, the District of Columbia's nonvoting delegate in Congress, announced today that he would run in the District's Democratic Presidential primary next May 2 as a favorite-son candidate.
CALCUTTA -- In the East, India reported the capture of key East Pakistani cities, virtually assuring control of half the province.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The Administration's two top environmental officials and its top economic official repeatedly assured the House Public Works Committee today that President Nixon wanted "a strong" water pollution control bill.

GEOGRAPHY -- The state of Jammu and Kashmir, to call the disputed territory by its official name, has an area of 86,024 square miles, making it slightly smaller in size than Britain. It is bounded on the northeast by the Sinkiang region of China: on the northwest by Afghanistan, on the east by Tibet, on the south by India and on the west -its longest border -- by Pakistan.
A $100-million Federal program to build a short takeoff and landing airliner combining hard-to-combine virtues -speed, quiet, safety and profitability -- has moved into the final design stage.

Not yet ready to relinquish first place in the National Basketball Association's Atlantic Division, the Boston Celtics ran the New York Knicks into submission at Madison Square Garden last night and scored a 105-97 victory.

Where lyricism, color and delicacy were in demand, Mari Tsumura's playing came close to perfection, in her recital at the Rogers Auditorium in the Metropolitan Museum of Art Monday night. The 23-year-old Japanese violinist, who won the Merriweather Post contest in 1967, in Washington, is as pretty as a picture, and she performs that way.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Vessels in the Navy's newest class of nuclear attack submarines will be named for cities, with the lead ship to be the Los Angeles, it was announced today.

Gov. Ronald Reagan of California and Dr. Frank Boyden, 92-year-old headmaster emeritus of historic Deerfield Academy, were among those honored at the colorful National Football Foundation's Hall of Fame Awards dinner at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel last night.

Hank Bauer was manager of the Orioles when a trade with the Reds brought Frank Robinson to Baltimore. "He's a ballplayer," a man said to Bauer, "but didn't he get a kind of name for himself in Cincinnati?"

The recent self-serving "Sir Galahadto-the-rescue" letter by T. Lawrence Jones, president of the American Insurance Association, seeking to place his organization on the side of the angels in the controversy regarding no - fault automobile insurance once again points up the hoax which he and others are trying to perpetrate on the public.

Leaders of a recently formed federation of mental-health associations and other groups said yesterday they would go to court to try to prevent further cuts in the budgets for state mental institutions.

A New York Representative has accused the Lindsay administration of reneging on an agreement that it would fight police corruption in return for the Congressman's support during the 1969 mayoral campaign.

Fansteel, Inc., said yesterday that it had been approached by the Tool Research and Engineering Corporation regarding a possible purchase of Fansteel stock by Tool Research for $12.50 a share. Based on the 2,048,609 common shares outstanding of Fansteel, the transaction, if Tool Research decided to buy all the Fansteel stock, would have a value of $25,607,612.

SEATTLE, Dec. 7 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department's refusal to release surplus food to the poor and unemployed in the Seattle area was "arbitrary and capricious," a Federal District Court judge has ruled.
SANFORD, Fla., Dec. 7 -There's a piano in the club car, a movie in the diner, the conductors wear maxi skirts, and at the end of the line, your car is waiting for you.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Two retired generals who were losers in the presidential election nine days ago fought a pistol duel today. Each man fired two shots but missed.

President Nixon's declaration of "absolute neutrality" in the Indian-Pakistani conflict fails to conceal Administration policies, which have, in fact, been obviously biased in favor of the Government of President Yahya Khan in Islamabad.

NEWARK, Dec. 7 -- Civil Service employes of this financially distressed city enjoy higher pay, shorter working hours and greater fringe benefits on the whole than workers in comparable jobs in private industry here, a study by the United States Department of Labor said today.

MARIETTA, Ga., Dec. 7 (AP) -- Two members of the Atlanta Falcons football team, Bob Berry, the quarterback, and Randy Marshall, a defensive end, were arrested last night in a raid on Mr. Marshall's apartment.

With only one dissenting vote, the Senate has confirmed the nomination of Lewis Powell to the Supreme Court. In this decisive manner, the Senate has shown how false was the imputation that it would not approve a Southerner or a conservative. When a nominee is a man of professional stature, wide experience, and with a fundamental belief in the basic guarantees of the Constitution, no regional bias or philosophical disagreement bars his way.

NEW DELHI, Dec. 7 -- In her first major offensive of the four-day-old war, Pakistan began a large-scale tank and infantry attack today against Indian troops guarding a key road in southwestern Kashmir, India reported.

WARSAW, Dec. 7 -- Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader called today for "practical steps" by the West in response to the Warsaw Pact's call for a European security conference next year.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

World attention has been so heavily focused on the struggle over the devaluation of the dollar and the revaluation of other currencies that some crucial economic issues involved in the confrontation between the United States and its trading partners and allies have been relatively submerged.
Consolidated Edison won a temporary restraining order yesterday allowing it to continue full use of its controversial coal-burning Arthur Kill generator in Staten Island.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Dec. 7 (AP) -- The faculty of the University of Vermont College of Arts and Science voted unanimously last night to create a teaching position for Michael J. Parenti, who was ousted Saturday as a political science professor.

OSLO, Norway -- The late King Haakon of Norway, who was forced to flee this country in 1940 when it was occupied by German invaders assisted by the Quisling fifth column, told me in 1949 that he had personally urged his Government to abandon its long tradition of neutrality and join the then new North Atlantic Alliance.

Eleven of the 150 women who have reigned for brief periods as "Miss Subways," and whose photographs have enlivened subway cars over the last 30 years, got together yesterday at Johnny Angel's restaurant in midtown Manhattan to lunch and reminisce.
Despite the fact that he lost that day to Ken Rosewall, Rod Laver recalls the outfit he wore to the World Championship of Tennis in Dallas on Nov. 26 rather fondly.
CHICAGO, Dec. 7 -- Chicago's giant public school system, the nation's third largest, did not close today.
LONGHAI, South Vietnam -- "Airborne! Airborne!" the Cambodian recruits holler in English as they crawl and wiggle in the mud under a long stretch of barbed wire.
RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Dec. 7 -- Pakistan today announced rules for foreign correspondents covering the war with India.

SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 7 -- Premier Kim Jong Pil and the president of the major opposition party differed in separate interviews today over the necessity of the state of national emergency declared yesterday by President Park Chung Hee.
A rally in the last hour of trading enabled the American Stock Exchange and the overthe-counter market to finish higher yesterday after both markets had been declining earlier.
Family Court Judge Nanette Dembitz scored the Department of Social Services yesterday for allegedly failing to report suspected cases of child abuse before they came to court.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 7 (AP) -Representative John Dowdy was hospitalized today after he complained of feeling ill at his trial on bribery conspiracy charges in United States District Court.

Pay increases for the city's firemen would total $2,150 during the new but still unratified 30-month contract, sources close to the negotiations said yesterday. The agreement, if finally approved by the union membership, the city administration and the national Pay Board, would raise a fireman's pay to $14,300 in the final stage of the contract.
The Circle Line agreed yesterday to install federally approved "on board" sewage treatment facilities on its fleet of sightseeing vessels by next Dec. 1.

CALCUTTA, India, Dec. 7 -The Indian Army reported a victory in Jessore tonight that virtually insured it of control of about half of East Pakistan, and the army chief immediately issued a call to the Pakistani forces there to surrender to save their lives.
At the age of 62, Lady Fleming is a frail freedom fighter.

The new Broadway musical, "Wild and Wonderful," is wet, windy and wretched. It opened last night at the Lyceum Theater. I shall always try to remember it, and to use it as a yardstick to measure the future.

Even if the four-month strike of New York Telephone Company workers were to end at one, a State Public Service Commission report made public by Governor Rockefeller yesterday said that telephone facilities might not be adequate for the busy season next January, February and March "or the winter busy season of 1973."

CAIRO, Dec. 7 -- The Libyan revolutionary regime announced tonight that it was nationalizing operations of the British Petroleum Company, Ltd. in retaliation for what was termed Britain's "conspiracy" in the Iranian occupation last week of three islands in the Persian Gulf that are claimed by Arab emirates.
The stock market staged a sharp rally in the final 90 minutes of trading yesterday to turn a drowsy, profit-taking session into a peppy, forwardsurging performance.

Rain, mud, fog and short fields of bad horses added up to another dreary day at Aqueduct yesterday, raising the question: Why do top jockeys who by now are "working for Uncle Sam" continue suffering here when they could be sunning themselves in Florida?
LONDON -- The war in Vietnam has been a multiple turning point; also a shock to all established habits of political thinking.

Christmas season on Fulton Street in Brooklyn, one of the city's oldest shopping lanes equally noted for its human mix and its customer loyalty, is as frantic, as congested and as lustily spirited as ever. But this year, after only 10 shopping days in the season, there are two differences, one related to the weather and the other to competition.

ENFIELD, Conn., Dec. 7 -- The Irish Ambassador came to Padraic Colum's bedside here today to pay his country's compliments. So did members of the American Irish Foundation, with a gift of $2,500 and a scroll hailing Mr. Colum as "Poet, dramatist, storyteller, collector of folklore and critic . . . a master writer held in esteem, wherever literature is cherished."
TWICKENHAM, England, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Tom Neville, an American Rhodes scholar playing with a dislocated shoulder, led Oxford to a 21-3 rout of Cambridge in their traditional rugby match today.

A long and close association between the New York metropolitan area and the American Contract Bridge League will end in about a year. At a meeting of the league board of directors in Phoenix, Ariz., last month, the league made a not-unexpected decision to move its operations from Greenwich to Memphis.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7--Senator James L. Buckley said today that the White House was "actively" studying the controversial lowincome housing project being built in Forest Hills, Queens, and had expressed some "concern" about it.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -Representative John M. Ashbrook said today that he was weighing the possibility of primary challenges against President Nixon next year on behalf of a right-wing group disen chanted with Administration policies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -In any other year since war was declared on poverty in 1965, today would have been a time for cheering in the corridors of the Office of Economic Opportunity. After all, the House had, after the now-familiar disagreement and photofinish vote, just approved and sent to the President another twoyear extension of the controversial antipoverty program.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- President Nixon welcomed President Emilio G. Medici of Brazil at the White House today as the latter began a three-day state visit here.

The outstanding individual feat of the year in pro football was the 247 yards gained by Willie Ellison of the Los Angeles Rams on Sunday against the New Orleans Saints. Not only did that set a single-game rushing record for the 51-year-old National Football League, but it also projected 26-yearold William Henry Ellison of Houston into the category of something special.
BRUSSELS, Dec. 7 -- Ten European members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization announced today that they planned to increase their defense budgets in 1972 by a total of well over $1-billion.
Phil Brito, who made his New York debut in 1943 at La Martinique, the West 57th Street nightclub, returned to 57th Street Monday evening. This time he was in Carnegie Hall.
The Board of Estimate yesterday advanced the city's plan to purchase and renovate Yankee Stadium in an effort to keep the Yankees from leaving New York.

The likelihood of curtailed exports if the war between India and Pakistan is prolonged, and talk of trade sanctions the United States might impose against India, involving food and grain, preoccupied traders in soybean and grain commodity futures yesterday.

Without a trace of rancor, Joseph Medure, a postal clerk who was once a private first class, tossed a floral wreath into the East River yesterday from the fantail of the destroyer Moale at Fort Schuyler in the Bronx, and the ceremony was over.

The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation announced yesterday the signing of a new sevenyear credit agreement with banks in its existing credit lines. The company said the new agreement would allow the borrowing of up to $75million on a revolving basis until Dec. 31, 1973, and on a five-year term loan afterward.

Councilman Matthew J. Troy Jr., Queens County Democratic leader, disclosed the finances of his organization yesterday at a news conference and again called on the Mayor to order the John V. Lindsay Associations, the Mayor's political organization, to disclose their finances.
In "A Bio in Song," the first in this season's "Matinee Series" presented Monday nights and Tuesday afternoons by Lucille Lortel at the Theater de Lys, Irving Caesar plays Irving Caesar.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 7 (AP) -About 700,000 Master Charge cardholders in five states are being notified of changes in billling information and the method of applying interest, following settlement of a damage suit in Federal District Court here.

Carmine J. Persico was acquitted last night on two counts of conspiracy to commit criminal usury. Eight other charges "fell by the wayside" with the verdict, which was reached after more than 11 hours of deliberation.
Gen. Emilio Garrastazu Me dici has become, in 25 months of government, the most popular of the three army generals who have ruled Brazil with practically unlimited powers since 1964.

STANFORD, Calif., Dec. 7 (AP) -- Two bombs ripped the Stanford Linear Accelerator Center today causing what officials estimated as up to $100,000 damage to the world's largest device for atomic particle research.

The following books were weeded out of an enormous pile of oversized books that I read my way through in search of some possible gift suggestions (which appeared in this column on Monday). The books included below struck me as noteworthy in one way or another, but I am not at all sure that everyone would want to give or receive them as gifts.

PARIS, Dec. 7 -- As the mark soared at one point today some 13 per cent above its old parity, the Bonn Government under rising pressure from industry served notice that it would actively intervene to roll the rate back.
PARIS, Dec. 7 -- The British and French Governments today set a pricing policy for their supersonic jet aircraft, the Concorde, that favored airlines that took the first options.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 7 -- The General Assembly meeting today on the IndianPakistan conflict is the sixth in United Nations history called under a resolution known as Uniting for Peace. Its aim is to permit the Assembly to act when the Security Council is paralyzed by vetoes.

The first winner of the Europe Prize for Statesmanship is Prime Minister Heath of Britain. The award, bearing a cash gift of 300,000 Deutschemarks (about $85,000), will be made to Mr. Heath for his work toward carrying Britain into the Common Market and toward unifying Europe.

ABU DHABI, Dec. 7 (AP) -The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries opened today the first salvo in a new round of demands for higher oil prices and greater control of the companies operating within the members' borders.

BAKU, U.S.S.R. -- In many ways Ahmet Aliyev is a typical Azerbaiyani. He makes more money than most, but like many other young men he loves the fiery, temperamental play of his local soccer team, he is proud of the new apartment developments sprawling around Baku and he knows how to get things done.

The United States Court of Appeals ruled here yesterday that there was "no merit" in a draftee's contention that Army inductions were invalid for the 90-day period following the enactment of the Selective Service Law Sept. 28.

ANAHEIM, Calif., Dec. 7 -Del Rice, the first player to sign a major league contract with the Angels, was named today to manage the California baseball team. Rice, a 49-year-old former catcher, received a one-year contract calling for $55,000.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -The United States Commission on Civil Rights declared today that minority group students in five Southwestern states were receiving an inferior education.

The McGraw-Hill Book Company has acquired world publishing rights to a 230,000-word transcript of taped reminiscenses of Howard R. Hughes, the Texas-born multimillionaire long considered to be the most determined hermit in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Dec 7 -Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, assured by President Nixon that the United States did not wish to "gobble up" Canada, said today that it was up to Canadians to decide what type of foreign investment they would accept.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Dec. 7 -- Chief Justice Warren E. Burger called upon the nation's prison administrators tonight to start "communicating" regularly with their prisoners and to let the prisoners "regulate some limited part of their lives, however small."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Passenger train service between New York and Chicago along the old New York Central route through Buffalo and Cleveland was threatened with extinction again today when Amtrak made a final demand for subsidy support from the five states served.
Eighty-four members of Pratt Institute's faculty called on the board of trustees yesterday to remove Henry Saltzman as president and designate an interim administration.
The credit markets gained strength yesterday as a wide range of fixed-income securities -- taxable and tax-exempt, long-term and short-term -- all attracted investors.

More than $230,000 richer than he was on Jan. 1, Lee Trevino held a Dubonnet on the rocks in one hand, a black cigar in the other and said here yesterday: "Next year I'm going to go home on Sunday nights."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- A Senate-House conference committee agreed today on legislation to sponsor a muchexpanded research attack on cancer. The bill authorizes $1.6-billion over the next three years to permit scientists to broaden their efforts and capitalize on many recent scientific advances.

State Welfare Inspector General George F. Berlinger said yesterday that he had submitted 62 cases of apparent welfare frauds to local commissioners, including the case of a Suffolk woman who worked part of the time as a welfare employe while being overpaid $15,141 as a relief recipient under another name.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 7 -- The Organization of African Unity urged Israel to day to clear the way for a re sumption of negotiations with Egypt by reaffirming that she did not seek the annexation of Arab territory.

YONKERS, Dec. 7 -- Around the Yonkers Raceway, George (Buddy) Regan is being compared with the late Hirsch Jacobs of thoroughbred racing as a trainer without peer when it comes to spotting a "good claim."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The Atomic Energy Commission announced today a major reorganization of its internal structure -- the first in a decade -that gives increased emphasis to civilian - oriented programs, rather than those directed toward military objectives.

On Nov. 29 six officers of the Newark Teachers Union went to jail for leading the 1970 strike in the face of a court injunction. In a few weeks, as the spirit of Christmas grows stronger, 186 more teachers will also be imprisoned in the Essex County Penitentiary for their participation in the strike.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The Price Commission granted the nation's largest steel producer an average price increase of 3.6 per cent today, substantially less than had been expected.
The annual Alfred L duPontColumbia University Survey of Broadcast Journalism declared yesterday that in its hour of greatest influence the electronic medium was in "a state of siege."

FORT MEADE, Md., Dec. 7 -The military judge at the courtmartial of Col. Oran K. Henderson denied today a series of defense motions that sought the dismissal of all charges against the 51-year-old combat officer.

ROME, Dec. 7 -- Left-wing radical youths today proclaimed school strikes, scuffled with the police and with neoFacists, and paraded in the streets shouting slogans accusing the official Communist apparatus of collusion with capitalism.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -Critics of William H. Rehnquist vowed today that they would talk until their arguments caught the Senate's attention, and his supporters charged that a filibuster had begun.
Lured by 5-cent hot dogs and 5-cent ice cream cones, New Yorkers yesterday crowded the opening of a shop-lined arcade linking 51st and 52d Streets.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- A A Federal district judge denied today a suit by two Congressmen to compel the release of all or part of the still classified segments of the Pentagon Papers.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7 -- The Cook County Democratic Central Committee endorsed Edward V. Hanrahan today for a second four-year term as the county's state's attorney despite a Criminal Court indictment pending against him land 13 other persons in a case involving a police raid on the Black Panthers two years ago.
RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Dec. 7 (Reuters) -- Pakistan said today her forces had thrust 10 miles into Indian territory in Kashmir and blunted a major Indian offensive farther south in West Pakistan.
A shareholders' attempt to block approval of a Las Vegas investment by Metro-GoldwynMayer, Inc., was dismissed yesterday by Judge Sylvester J. Ryan in Federal District Court here.

The president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis warned yesterday that the nation may well have to accept temporarily higher interest rates in 1972 if President Nixon's Phase Two policy is to succeed in controlling inflation.

The Association of Stock Exchange Firms and the Investment Bankers Association announced yesterday that Robert M. Gardiner would become the first chairman and chief executive officer of the new Securities Industry Association to be formed Jan. 1 upon the merger of the other two groups.
Homer A. Jack's recent letter indicates the need for clarification of the United Nation's new procedures for investigating serious human rights problems.

The Appellate Division, reversing a State Supreme Court ruling, held yesterday that the City Department of Health could not enforce meat-labeling regulations that differed from or were more stringent than Federal or state labeling laws.

Senator Henry M. Jackson, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for President, announced yesterday that he would seek Federal legislation requiring states "to submit detailed programs for achieving trial of criminal cases within 60 to 90 days."

A vast, H-shaped pedestrian mall that would straddle the heart of midtown Manhattan and transform almost all existing patterns of vehicle and pedestrian movement in the area was proposed yesterday by the City Transportation Administration.

It was compost heaps vs. chemical fertilizers at the Department of Consumer Affairs yesterday as Commissioner Bess Myerson began two days of hearings into whether "health" foods are any healthier, more "natural" or more "organic" than ordinary foods.

Allegheny Ludlum Industries, Inc., announced yesterday the election of Robert J. Buckley as president and chief operating officer. He was president of the Ingersoll Milling Machine Company. Mr. Buckley replaces Roger S. Ahlbrandt who was elected chairman and will continue as chief executive officer. E. J. Hanley, formerly chairman, was elected chairman of the finance committee.

" This persistent fiscal crisis is, perhaps, the most fundamental of all the city's problems," says a useful report released yesterday by the Commission on StateCity Relations. Entitled wryly "A Study of Studies," it is a terse compilation and comparison of the eight major fiscal studies of New York City's government conducted by various groups and commissions over the last couple of decades.

WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Dec. 7 (AP) -- Roger Brown scored half of his 22 points in the final period to lead the Indiana Pacers to a 119-114 victory over the New York Nets tonight in an American Basketball Association game.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 7 -The Syrian President, Lieut. Gen. Hafez al-Assad, today dismissed as "Zionist propaganda" claims that his regime persecuted the 4,000 Jews still in Syria.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Dec. 7 -- The General Assembly approved tonight a resolution urging India and Pakistan to stop fighting and pull back their troops.

OTTAWA, Dec. 7 -- Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's statements that he had won "fantastically new" assurances respecting Canadian "independence" were received enthusiastically by Trudeau supporters in Ottawa, but with skepticism by some others.

There was no Wieniawski on Rolf Schulte's program at Town Hall Monday night. No Sarasate, either, or Paganini. The 22-year-old German violinist, who was making his New York debut as a result of winning a Young Concert Artists audition here, plainly wanted to be judged as something other than just another flashy fiddler.

Prime Minister Trudeau, a man not usually given to inflated rhetoric, says President Nixon in their White House talks offered him "a fantastically new statement" of United States respect for the political and economic identity of Canada. Mr. Nixon said things to him "unequalled by any other President in speaking about Canada," Mr. Trudeau told a news conference.
HOUSTON, Dec. 7 -- Mayor Louis Welch was elected to a fifth two-year term today on a platform of city growth and tough law enforcement.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The White House, defending its position on the war in the Indian subcontinent, asserted today that the United States was actively promoting a political settlement -- including some autonomy for East Pakistan -- when India attacked Pakistan without justification.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 5 -- A leading cardiologist has suggested that heart attacks and arteriosclerosis, which affects millions of older Americans, might be owing in part to damage originally caused by common virus infection suffered as children and young adults.

After reading your open letter to Gloria Steinem (Mary Mebane [Liza], Oct. 29, 1971) I felt I had to reply for a couple of reasons -- because I am a black woman and because I am a personal friend of Gloria's.

In a move to "serve more effectively all areas of the broader public," the Metropolitan Museum has elected three new trustees, two of whom break with the traditional image of the board as a monied Manhattan elite.

MOSCOW, Dec. 7 -- The Soviet Union announced today its spacecraft Mars 3 had released a descent capsule equipped with television, that made a soft landing last Thursday on the surface of the planet and briefly transmitted signals before contact suddenly ceased.
Actions by corporate directors yesterday saw quarterly dividend declarations chopped by two companies, the omission of payment by another and increases of 1 cent and half a cent by two others.
A national survey of racial attitudes provides "little evidence for the existence of a white backlash" among white ethnic groups.

More than a dozen children in a Queens school bus escaped without serious injury yesterday despite the fact that the bus overturned after being in a collision with a passenger car and knocking down a metal streetlight pole.

Both Elie Siegmeister and Benjamin Lees write solidly and effectively for the voice in very different ways. Since the two composers' styles contrast so vividly, the program of their songs Monday night in Carnegie Recital Hall was a striking one.
LONDON, Dec. 7 -- A prominent British art historian has claimed the discovery of a lost Titian masterpiece in a British country house.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 7 -Mrs. Martinez de Peron, third wife of Argentina's exiled dictator, Juan D. Peron, arrived here today to try to unify the faction-ridden Peronist movement.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Dec. 7 -- With the war between Pakistan and India reaching a critical phase, Pakistan's President tonight appointed a civilian Prime Minister and Deputy Prime Minister whose immediate task is to plead Pakistan's case before the United Nations.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Attorney General John N. Mitchell asserted today that the Justice Department had no intention of softening its enforcement of antitrust laws.

In a secret and potentially significant postscript to the defeat of the $2.5-billion transportation bond issue, the committee that spearheaded the probond campaign has been advised to consider disclosing its corporate contributors.

New Jersey court and prosecuting officials said yesterday that they fully expected Edgar H. Smith Jr. to attempt to retract his confession to the murder of a 15-year-old Ramsey high school girl in 1957.
Your Nov. 13 editorial on the Highway Trust Fund reveals the same kind of shortsighted refusal to face facts that you attribute to me as a so-called political ally of the "voracious highway lobby."

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 7 -A government study to be published soon will report that waste dumped into the Mississippi River may be threatening aquatic life in the Gulf of Mexico and human health in southern Louisiana.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Enemy forces kept up pressure near Pnompenh today with rockets, guns and mines. In the eastern part of the country, however, South Vietnamese forces met little resistance.
The new breed of young, black magazine publishers appears to be doing all right with its ventures, and at least two new magazines are in the wings.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee unanimously approved today legislation that would impose Congressional restrictions on the war-making powers of the Presidency.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Dec. 7 -- A new communications satellite is awaiting launching here to provide one more link in a global system that is dramatically altering the way men and nations keep in touch.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 7 -- A consumer organization is suing the Bank of America, charging violations of the Federal Truthin-Lending Act and asking damages that, according to the plaintiff, could total more than $1-billion.
Efforts were under way yesterday to determine the whereabouts and condition of an American woman reported jailed in Jessore, East Pakistan.
A 28-year-old Brooklyn patrolman was arrested yesterday on charges of taking $3,400 from a woman seized during a narcotics raid. He was later suspended from the force.
Mayor Lindsay's Commission on State-City Relations blamed state stinginess yesterday for much of New York City's financial problems.
The Arena Stage production of "Moonchildren," a new play by Michael Weller, will be brought to Broadway on Feb. 21 by David Merrick, in association with Martin Rosen and London's Royal Court Theater.

A 30-year-old prisoner who had been under psychiatric observation at the Bronx House of Detention for Men since Nov. 1 was found hanged with his belt in his cell early yesterday.

Prices of cotton No. 2 futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed a little lower to unchanged yesterday, following the Agriculture Department's revision downward by 161,500 bales of its 1971 cotton-crop estimate. The news was bearish because traders had expected an even larger drop.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- A foreign aid appropriation bill that would provide $2.67-billion in economic and military assistance was passed by the Houe of Representatives today by a vote of 214 to 179.

Western Pacific Industries, Inc., marketed yesterday 1.3 million units, one share and one warrant, at $19.50 a unit through an underwriting group managed by Dean Witter and Bear and Steams.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- William H. Rehnquist said today that he was expressing the views of the late Justice Robert H. Jackson -- not his own views -- when he wrote a memorandum in 1952 saying that the "separate but equal" doctrine underlying school segregation was "right and should be reaffirmed."

MOUNTAIN HOME AIR FORCE BASE, Idaho, Dec. 9 -- A few of the spectators at a special court-martial exploded with joy, shouting "Wow" and pummeling the back of a young airman today as he was cleared of charges of illegally distributing peace literature at this fighter plane base in southwestern Idaho.

ROME, Dec. 9 -- The Vatican published a pronouncement by Pope Paul VI today strongly restating the Roman Catholic Church's prohibition against married priests in its dominant Western branch, the Latin Rite.
The following letter, signed by fifty commissioned members of the Medical Corps, was read by Senator Mansfield on the Senate floor Wednesday. The Senator withheld the names.

The Army announced yesterday that it had dismissed murder and assault charges against Brig. Gen. John W. Donaldson, who, as an infantry brigade commander, was accused of killing six South Vietnamese civilians.

A rabbi from the Forest Hills section of Queens who has been one of the strongest supporters of the controversial low-income housing project for this middle-class area suggested yesterday that the size of the project be reduced.

Mayor Lindsay named a three-member mediation panel yesterday to assist negotiators for the Transit Authority and subway and bus workers in their efforts to negotiate a new contract before their present agreement expires on New Year's Eve.

The Herbert H. Lehman papers, a permanently endowed collection of the public and private papers and memorabilia of the former Governor and United States Senator, will be dedicated at Columbia University this afternoon.

WINTER BLOOD. By John Roc. 511 pages. Trident. $7.95. Friends of John Roc's "Winter Blood" will say that it was published in a bad hour, that the glare-surrounding the publication of Bernard Malamud's "The Tenants," also about a black and a white working out their destiny in a sleazy tenement marked for destruction, put "Winter Blood" in the dark. It can't be helped though.
The election of Rabbi Benjamin M. Kahn as executive vice president of the 500,000-member B'nai B'rith was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9--The Senate today approved a bill to create an 11-mile Connecticut historic riverway, covering some 23,500 acres in the southern part of the state.
AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Francoise Durr of France had an emotional clash with an umpire, Sue Butcher, today in the Benson and Hedges women's singles tennis quarter-finals.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Governor Rockefeller said today that the goal of a Senate-passed bill to stop the discharge of all pollution into the nation's waterways by 1985 would be "totally impossible" to achieve.

DACCA, Pakistan, Dec. 9 -- Indian planes, apparently trying to bomb the Dacca airport, hit an orphanage here today. Authorities said they feared as many as 300 of the children had been killed and were buried under tons of rubble.

DETROIT, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Production at domestic auto plants rose this week as the Ford Motor Company's Dear-born assembly lines resumed five-day operations after a week's shutdown, Automotive News reported yesterday.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 10 -- Gov. George C. Wallace said today that be had asked Senator James O. Eastland, Democrat of Mississippi, chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, to investigate the actions of a Federal district judge who struck down an Alabama law dealing with the busing of schoolchildren.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- William D. Eberle, the President's special representative for trade negotiations, will head the United States delegation to the trade talks with Japan in Honolulu.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The Senate completed Congressional action today on a 75-year extension of the Christian Science Church's copyright protection on the basic writings of its founder, Mary Baker Eddy.
Federal environmental officials warned New York and New Jersey yesterday that national clean-air requirements for 1975 would not be met by plans being drawn up by the two states.

OSLO, Norway, Dec. 10 -- Norway's Nobel Committee presented to Chancellor Willy Brandt its 1971 Peace Prize here today in a ceremony that was heavy with symbolism for the German and Norwegian nations and for the recipient himself.

DETROIT, Dec. 10 (UPI) -- The Ford Motor Company announced today that it was increasing the prices of its 1972 model cars by an average of 2.6 per cent, or $90, effective with vehicles shipped to dealers Nov. 30.

Jewish organizations claiming to represent the vast majority of the 400,000 Jews in Queens joined yesterday in strong opposition to the controversial low-income housing project for the Forest Hills section of Queens.

Samuel Barber's "Antony and Cleopatra," the work that opened the Metropolitan Opera House at Lincoln Center in 1966 and went over with a now-historic thud, made a considerably more pleasant sound when the New York Philharmonic presented scenes from the opera Thursday night.

Humanitarian and political reasons support India's military action against her South Asian neighbor. The broad objective is to punish a Pakistani regime that had lost legitimacy by its genocidal treatment of millions of its Bengali citizens, forcing survivors to find refuge in an already strained India.

The trustees of Hanover College, a small liberal arts college in Hanover, Ind., are suing Donaldson, Lufkin Jenrette, Inc., a New York brokerage and money-management firm, for the alleged mishandling of its endowment fund.
The New York Telephone Company told negotiators for striking telephone installers yesterday that it saw no purpose in continuing negotiations without a Federal mediator.

President Nixon explained his veto of the child development program by calling the plan too costly, administratively unworkable, professionally ill-prepared and designed to undermine the American family. The sweeping nature of this attack cannot obscure the fact that the concept of child care and development enjoys broad popular support across most of the traditional divisions of politics, class, economics and race.
It is amazing how much variety you can find collecting American silver spoons.

NASHVILLE, Dec. 10 -- The Black Congressional Caucus, the two black medical colleges and the black medical and dental associations began today the country's first National Conference on the Status of Health in the Black Community.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -President Nixon signed the tax measure today, hailing it as a "responsible bill" that would grant some tax reduction to "practically every American" and create new jobs.

FORT MEADE, Md., Dec. 10 (AP) -- Closing arguments in the court-martial of Col. Oran K. Henderson will begin next Wednesday and the case will be submitted to the jury Thursday afternoon, the judge announced today.

A "fill-in" race, the December Handicap, has proved so popular with horsemen that it will have to be run in two divisions on today's program at Aqueduct. The one-mile event was thought up only a fortnight ago in order to present a stakes event on the final Saturday of the extended local season, which ends Wednesday.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 10 -- After 100 deals of the 140-deal challenge match here, the Italian Blue team held a commanding lead of 68 international match points, 229 to 161, over the Dallas Aces.

JERUSALEM -- Nothing could be more inaccurate than to assert that the rights of the inhabitants of Jerusalem have been adversely affected by anything done or planned by Israel. Their rights to peaceful life and development, and to a voice in Jerusalem's affairs, have been fully respected -- and, indeed, advanced -- only since June, 1967.
DACCA, Pakistan, Dec. 10 -- Some of the double-decker buses continue their daytime passenger runs around Dacca, but on Government business and under a camouflage coat of mud.

The golden dream of an oil bonanza from the Alaskan North Slope grew tarnished yesterday for the Marathon Oil Company. The Ohio based concern announced that it was writing off its unamortized lease investment of $15.1-million in its 13 tracts in the area.

The New York Mets finally gave up on Nolan Ryan's wandering fastball yesterday. They traded the 24-year-old pitcher and three prospects to the California Angels for Jim Fregosi, six times the American League's all-star shortstop.
The long-dormant controversy over protecting Staten Island's greenbelt flared up again yesterday when conservation groups assailed the state's proposed Richmond Parkway extension.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Dec. 10 -- In his gloomiest assessment so far of the military situation in East Pakistan, the military command spokesman said tonight that Pakistani troops, outnumbered 6 to 1 and "overstressed on the ground," were continuing resistance against an enemy who possessed "overwhelming air support."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The State Department announced today that the United States had promised Portugal up to $435-million in economic and social development credits in return for the use of air and naval bases in the Azores until 1974.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -President Nixon has promised his chief Senate lieutenant that he will not veto the campaign spending bill now taking final form in a Senate-House conference.
The United States Steel Corporation increased prices late yesterday by an average of 7.7 per cent on a variety of products used in the automobile and appliance industries.
Roving bands of teen-aged youths beat, rob and threaten elderly persons in the East Village, making them virtual prisoners in their own homes, residents of the area complained yesterday.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Dec. 11 (AP) -- North and South Vietnamese forces reportedly battled for nine hours yesterday deep inside Cambodia in the heaviest fighting of the Saigon command's three-week-old offensive across the border.

On Dec. 11, 1946, there was born perhaps the most successful -- and surely the most appealing -- of all agencies created by the General Assembly of the United Nations. This was the International Children's Emergency Fund; today, a quarter century later, it is alive and well into its maturity, and known universally as UNICEF.

NEW DELHI, Dec. 10 (UPI) -- India is sending a Foreign Ministry official to Moscow tomorrow for high-level consultations amid reports of Chinese warnings to India to heed the call of the United Nations General Assembly for a cease-fire in her war with Pakistan or face consequences.

MILWAUKEE, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Kareem Jabbar scored 18 of his career-high of 55 points in the third period tonight, sparking the Milwaukee Bucks to a 120-104 victory over the Boston Celtics in a game between National Basketball Association division leaders.

HONG KONG, Dec. 10--The leadership in Peking has counseled party workers and the Chinese people not to get unduly upset, over the factional split in the ruling hierarchy disclosed by the recent eclipse of Defense Minister Lin Piao and a number of other top military men.
Your editorial "Controlling Rent" (Nov. 29) displays a regrettable unawareness of the arithmetic which renders Minimum Base Rents (M.B.R.) as only a temporary crutch to a limping housing industry.

The tenants council of a Queens public housing project, a State Senator and a clergyman have accused Simeon Golar, chairman of the City Housing Authority, of deliberately misinforming tenants of the Pomonok Houses project by saying that no white families had applied for apartments there and by implying that only black families would be moved in.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The chairman of the American Revolution Bicentennial Commission expressed concern today over what he described as apathy toward the nation's planned 200th birthday celebration.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The Senate confirmed today by a vote of 68 to 26 President Nixon's nomination of William H. Rehnquist to fill the Supreme Court vacancy created by the retirement of Justice John Marshall Harlan.

The Columbia Broadcasting System announced yesterday a major reorganization of its television and radio news division, including the naming of a new executive producer for "The C.B.S Evening News With Walter Cronkite."

INGLEWOOD, Calif., Dec. 10 (UPI) -- Gail Goodrich capped a 32-point performance with 7 points in the last 2 1/2 minutes of overtime tonight as the Los Angeles Lakers equaled Milwaukee's National Basketball Association record of 20 consecutive victories by defeating the Phoenix Suns, 126-117.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 10 -- Twelve days after the Uruguayan general election, an official recount required by law took up its slow pace again today. No one was certain who would be the next President and no one was likely to be certain until mid-January.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 10--The legislators of South Vietnam's lower house finally made clear the results of last August's elections by organizing themselves this week into voting blocs that left the Government forces firmly in control.
The American Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter market ended the week yesterday in a bullish manner as both lists showed good gains in heavier trading.

The United Nations General Assembly adopted on Nov. 22, without opposition, a resolution on the world social situation, recommending far-reaching measures to help the developing countries in their efforts to raise living standards. The resolution deals with many of the problems of underdevelopment that James Reston so admirably analyzed in his recent series of articles in The Times.
ROME, Dec. 10 -- The 1,008member Electoral College remained deadlocked today on the second day of voting to choose Italy's sixth president.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Guerrillas armed with machine guns killed a part-time soldier and a man riding with him today in the village of Clady in County Tyrone.

CALCUTTA, India, Dec. 10 -- Indian troops crossed a major river obstacle today and were poised for a final drive on Dacca, the capital and bastion of the Pakistani forces in East Pakistan, according to Indian military officials.

SEOUL, Korea -- Two months after an agreement with the United States that limited Korean textile exports to the American market, South Korea officials have assessed the consequences of the pact and do not like what they see.

On behalf of the 98 per cent responsible owners of rent-controlled property -- now mostly senior citizens -- we strongly resent the statement in your editorial of Nov. 29 regarding the Vacancy Decontrol Law:
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 8 -Truong Hong Bac normally eats two meals a day but he is down to one now, skipping breakfast to save 27 cents a day.
Ronald L. Ziegler, the White House press secretary, brought a guest briefer along with him last Tuesday for Mr. Ziegler's daily 4 P.M. briefing of newsmen on President Nixon's activities.
LONDON, Dec. 10 -- The British Government dispelled uncertainties today over the controversial Concorde project by giving its firm support to the supersonic aircraft program.
SAN QUENTIN, Calif., Dec. 10 (UPI) -- A plot to smuggle a stolen police riot shotgun into San Quentin Prison, scene of a violent escape attempt in August, was reported today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- A study submitted to the President today by the Commission on Federal Statistics urged that responsibility for gathering and issuing data on crime be transferred from the Federal Bureau of Investigation to an independent agency.

Alvin Ailey has a message of true joy for everyone at the New York City Center. It is called "Mary Lou's Mass," and it was given its first performance by Mr. Ailey's American Dance Theater on Thursday night. It is a celebration of life, jazz and gospel, an assertively happy work that in some ways stands as a companion piece with Ailey's modern classic "Revelations."

Penn State, which will face Texas in the Cotton Bowl on Jan. 1, was presented the Lambert Trophy as the outstanding major college football team in the East yesterday. Joe Paterno, coach of the once-beaten Nittany Lions, accepted the award and a message of congratulations from President Nixon at the annual Lambert luncheon in the Essex House.
The future rather than the present (which means facing the Dallas Cowboys tomorrow) dominates the thinking of those New York Giant fans who can still talk about their team today without sputtering.
A frisky tone pervaded a steadily improving stock market yesterday as some glamour issues boomed to record levels and low-priced issues dominated the active list.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Drafting of men into the armed forces stopped today until tt least late next month. The drafting of men was halted for the usual Christmas-New Year holiday, and Selective Service said the November - December draft call of 10,000 has been filled.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan defended his record on combotting police corruption yesterday, saying that while the Knapp Commission hearings might have hurt his "image" as a prosecutor, his record showed that he had been doing his job.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Dec. 10 -- A prominent journalist, who was a high-ranking member of Nationalist China's ruling party until his arrest 13 months ago, was convicted of sedition today by a military tribunal and sentenced to life imprisonment.

Hilarious, audacious, utterly original - about the work of how many contemporary artists could one honestly apply such a combination of terms? Not very many, you may be certain. But the art of Red Grooms amply qualifies. Mr. Grooms is the real thing -- a comic artist. He has an authentic and very personal comic vision, and he has the visual resources to carry his work in whatever direction his madcap imagination may lead.

State Supreme Court Justice Mitchell D. Schweitzer last night denied every charge of misconduct--ranging from the commission of crimes to a broad-scale violation of the state's canons of judicial ethics--now pending against him before the Court on the Judiciary.

President Nixon put his talks with President Medici of Brazil in the context of the "vitally important" consultations he is conducting with this country's "closest friends" prior to his visits next year to China and Russia. It was the kind of recognition and association Brazil has long sought from Washington.

BERLIN, Dec. 10--East German and West German negotiators announced today that they had reached final agreement on subsidiary arrangements to fill out the framework of the Big Four accord on Berlin and to ease the daily lives of the 2 million people of West Berlin.

LONDON, Dec. 10 -- In the United States the President makes foreign policy. That understanding is fundamental to the constitutional system. In the end the American voice will be heard clearly only when he speaks.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10--The House approved legislation today to continue the economic stabilization program, adding a provision that would return rent-controlled apartments to Federal regulation.
The Mobil Oil Corporation denied yesterday that it knowingly hired members of organized crime to break a fuel drivers' strike last spring.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The White House indirectly urged India today to comply immediately with the United Nations General Assembly's resolution of last Tuesday calling for an immediate cease-fire in the India-Pakistan war.

WASHINGTON -- Once, not too long ago, there was a state dinner here where four women appeared wearing the same style black and white gown. The only difference was in the sizes, which ranged from a 22 1/2 down to a 6. The poor wretches spent the evening in agony and couldn't wait to get home.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 10 -- Pakistan's Foreign Minister, Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, arrived here today to press his country's case. And India's chief delegate, Samar Sen, indicated that his country would not agree to a cease-fire unless a representative of the East Pakistani separatist regime were formally heard at the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Senator Barry Goldwater ignored White House rules today and revealed that Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's national security adviser, was the "White House officials" who defended the Administration's policy toward India and Pakistan on Tuesday.
BERLIN, Dec. 9 -- The old man appeared to waver between confidence and doubt. "If the Americans hold out, we'll be all right," he observed. "Surely they cannot let us down at 5 minutes to 12.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The Federal Reserve Board announced today a reduction in the discount rate from 4 3/4 to 4 1/2 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Representatives of American industry lined up solidly today behind the Nixon Administration in attacking as impossibly tough and costly the water poltion control bill that was passed unanimously by the Sen- ate last month.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (UPI) -- Senator Warren G. Magnuson, Democrat of Washington, said today that food donations from Japan had made the United States Government look "callous and cruel" for refusing two food programs for hungry people in Seattle.

If fear does not yet stalk the halls of the New York City public schools -- as Abraham Lass, former high school principal, claims it does (Op-Ed Nov. 20) -- his grisly portrait of those schools, laced with lurid images of children being pushed down stairwells and youngsters running amok, will surely hasten its arrival.
NEW DELHI, Dec. 10 (UPI) -- Prime Minister Indira Gandhi told 100,000 college students at a rally today that India would keep fighting until Pakistani troops were driven from East Pakistan.

HONOLULU, Dec. 10 (UPI) -- The Hawaii Islanders traded a former major league third baseman, Clete Boyer, to the Taiyo Whales of Japan's Central League for a former Islander, John Werhas, in a straight player deal yesterday. In the past, American players were sent to the Japan league for cash.
Giorgio Tozzi assumed the role of King Marke for the first time with the Metropolitan Opera in the performance of Wagner's "Tristan und Isolde" given on Thursday evening.
PARIS, Dec. 10 -- When the lights went on again tonight, Stan Smith was upset by Jan Kodes of Czechoslovakia, 6-4, 3-6, 6-4, and dropped from the lead in the $50,000 Pepsi Masters tennis tournament.

A behind-the-scenes battle of growing magnitude is being waged by the city's 31 community school boards to enlarge their role in the labor negotiations that the central Board of Education conducts with the United Federation of Teachers and 23 other unions.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Dec. 10 -- North and South Korean Red Cross officials met here today in another weekly session of their "preliminary" talks on how to arrange reunions of families split in the two parts of Korea. There were no signs that Seoul's declaration of national emergency Monday had interfered with the discussions.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 10 (Reuters) -- The General Assembly's Economic Committee tonight called upon the developed countries to "reverse the recent restraints on international trade" and to realign their currencies.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Dec. 11--A United States Air Force jet fighter escorting a B-52 raid over the Ho Chi Minh Trail in Laos was hit and destroyed by an enemy surface-to-air missile, the United States command disclosed today.

The legal odyssey of Edgar H. Smith Jr., who was released from prison after 14 years in death row for the murder of a 15-year-old girl in 1957, has left a trail of unanswered questions about the processes of justice. Paradoxically, Smith was convicted when he protested his innocence and freed when he admitted his guilt. He had gained national fame from a book written in prison as an expose of alleged injustice.

Jerome Lowenthal may seem wrong-headed as a pianist at times, but at least he is never dull. In these days, when a good many pianists are carbon copies of one another, holding the listener's interest is quite a virtue, and it was a big one in the artist's recital in Tully Hall Thursday night.
A $25 check honoring "an outstandingly neighborly act" was among the 150 contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund recorded yesterday.

The game being played by Western political analysts could be called "does he or doesn't he?" The question refers to President Anwar el-Sadat's intentions and whether he means what he says about war with Israel. Most observers think he doesn't mean it because they interpret him from within their own secular, political frame of reference rather than his Moslem one.

The 35-month duel that gave the Bangor Punta Corporation control of the Piper Aircraft Corporation ended yesterday when a Federal District Court judge here dismissed cross suits of Bangor Punta and Chris-Craft Industries, Inc.
DETROIT, Dec. 10 -- The United Automobile Workers is attempting to force its Canadian local to end a walkout at a Canadian aircrft plant that is threatening the jobs of thousands of American workers.

WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Dec. 10 -- A one-hand jump shot by Rick Barry from the top of the foul circle just as the final buzzer was sounding tonight gave the New York Nets a 103-101 victory over the Memphis Pros.
A new mobile-home park for the poor in the devastated heart of Brownsville -- criticized by some as a wire-fenced "concentration camp" -- has received its first tenants.

ITHICA, N. Y., Dec. 10 -- Six black members of the Cornell University basketball team boycotted the squad's game against Syracuse University last night, met behind closed doors today with Coach Jerry Lace and with their white teammates.

Westinghouse Broadcasting Company said yesterday that any replacement of "The David Frost Show" with Merv Griffin on Metromedia stations in New York, Washington and Los Angeles would not affect the show in other areas.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 10 -- The European Economic Community got its cumbersome decision-making machinery into operation today, to try to find a compromise with the United States on demands for eliminating restrictive trade practices.
The New York City Ballet took its public on a trip by increasing the sugar-plum population in a once-only special version of "The Nutcracker" Thursday night at the State Theater.

SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Shane Gould, Australia's 15-year-old Olympic swimming hopeful, recorded world class times to win the 100-meter free-style and the 400-meter individual medley in an interclub meet at Drummoyne Pool today.
DENVER, Dec. 10 -- Key safety devices at more than a score of nuclear electric-power plants around the country have never been tested.
Executive Airlines, Inc., which has been cited by Federal officials as a "model" commuter airline, filed a petition under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act in Boston yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO -- Feminists have pointed out how men benefit from male supremacy, in time, money, satisfaction, and above all, power; but far less attention has been paid to the price men pay for their power. Understandably so: women have been properly preoccupied with the price they pay.

U Thant, Secretary General of the United Nations, entertained six of the leading members of the Chinese delegation at a Chinese banquet lunch yesterday. Like many New Yorkers, he ordered out from a nearby Chinese restaurant, in this case Flower Drum.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Officials of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare denied today any Intent to deceive members of Congress in an interoffice memorandum advising the Secretary to "offer them as few materials as we can get away with."

Arthur Gregor's "Selected Poems" is a gathering made by the poet himself from five previous books; he has added some formerly uncollected poems and a few new one altogether. It thus represents work spanning two decades and presents a graph of the poet's achievement.
TOKYO, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Representatives of the United States and Japanese Governments will hold trade talks in Honolulu tomorrow and Sunday, the Tokyo Government announced today.
GAINESVILLE, Fla., Dec. 10 -- Judge Benjamin M. Tench of the Alachua County Felony Court of Record today declared the first two sections of the Florida abortion law unconstitutional.
BRUSSELS, Dec. 10 -- The United States and West Germany announced today a two-year agreement under which the Germans would pay more of the costs of maintaining American troops in their country.

What a pleasure it is to hear a pop program in which musical values are as important as visual effects and psychic energy. Thursday night at the Bitter End blues singer Taj Mahal and a West Coast rock group named Lamb provided one of those rare evenings in which ability and charisma actually merged.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 10 -Former Representative Allard K. Lowenstein, addressing a conference of 3,000 new voters in Chicago last weekend, said, "Certainly there is no joy in the White House that this thing is occurring."
A favorite market myth is that stock prices feed on inflation -- that they rise even faster than the cost of living.

FREEPORT, Bahamas, Dec. 10 (UPI) -- George Archer, playing with a sore arm picked up in his first appearance on a tennis court, shot a 67 today and took a two-stroke lead after 36 holes of the $130,000 Bahamas national open golf tournament.
. ' A construction union here was ordered by a Federal judge yesterday to stop a strike the Government said was designed to force employers to dismiss black and Puerto Rican workmen.
YONKERS, Dec. 10 -- As Herve Filion's fame in harness racing spreads, he refuses to rest upon his laurels.

The Republic Corporation announced yesterday that it had concluded a five-year credit agreement with domestic and foreign leaders covering some $62-million in debt originally due from the end of 1972 through the end of 1973.

Benjamin Altman, the city's Rent Commissioner, said yesterday that he would not object to the Federal regulation of rent-controlled apartments if costs were also controlled and tenants were assured of proper maintenance and the same protection they now get.

The State Commissioner of Human Rights, Jack M. Sable, announced yesterday that eight life insurance companies, handling 80 per cent of the policies in the nation, had agreed to increase their minority-group and women workers in higher-paying categories.

The number of United Nations members is increasing every year. On Sept. 21, three small states -- Bahrein, Bhutan and Qatar -- with a total population of 1.5 million, became members. It is ironic, that other once-independent states are not members.

William J. Casey, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, indicated yesterday that the S.E.C. was attempting to establish broad new guidelines covering how brokers issue changed research recommendations to their customers.

The city was divided into 31 separate community school districts after the Legislature passed the School Decentralization Act in 1969. Parents of public-school children and other registered voters in each district participated in elections in 1970 to select nine members for each of the community school boards.

Opeartions of the Dana Corporation in the first fiscal quarter ended Nov. 30 resulted in a net income of $10.2-million, or 74 cents a share, the automobile equipment producer reported yesterday. This more than doubled the $4.1-million, or 30 cents a share shown in the comparable three months last year.

The Raytheon Company announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire the Iowa Manufacturing Company for common stock valued at $43.5-million. The merger has been approved by directors of both companies and is subject to approval of the shareholders of Iowa Manufacturing, which makes a wide range of stationary and portable construction equipment and asphalt - paving equipment.

There's little chance the Jet defense will mistake Mike Monler, New England's left tackle, for Jim Plunkett, New England's quarterback, tomorrow, but if they do, Montler will understand. People have been doing it all season.

New York's Conservative party, disturbed by what it believes to be President Nixon's leftward drift, is at least tentatively withholding its support for his re-election. Its executive committee's announcement to this effect follows preliminary action by an elite band of conservative chieftains, already known as the "Manhattan 12."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 10 -- The Bengali secessionists' aim on East Pakistan is a "secular, democratic state" seeking good relations with all the countries in the area including China, according to Abu Sayeed Chowdhury, the leader of a delegation seeking to state the movement's case at the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The International Business Machines Corporation was granted a patent this week that is impressive in several ways: it is one of the largest ever issued, it protects not only a big computer but special features of several others, and in stead of the usual single inventor there are 18.

Of the four films by Gunvor Nelson currently playing at the Film Forum, two, "My Name is Oona" and "Kirsa Nicholina," have already been shown in a Whitney Museum program and have been reviewed in The New York Times.

TOKYO, Dec. 10 (Reuters) -- Japanese textile makers today started court action to try to stop enforcement of the United States-Japanese agreement on regulating non-cotton textile exports to the American market.

BONN, Dec. 10 -- After 19 days of a strike that shut down almost all of West Germany's automobile industry, the metalworkers union and management settled with a compromise today that could be the pattern for wage negotiations over most of the country.

REDWOOD CITY, Calif., Dec. 10 (UPI) -- A jury of eight women and four men decided today that John Linley Frazier was legally sane at the time he murdered Dr. Victor Ohta and four others and dropped their bodies into the doctor's swimming pool.

JULLUNDER BASE CAMP, Derababa Nanak, India, Dec. 10 -- The Derababa Nanak bridge, a strategic railway trestle that was captured by Indian troops earlier this week, was quiet today. Lime green parrots screeched in the trees and Indian soldiers bathed in the Rawi River beneath the bridge, two miles inside West Pakistan.
LONDON, Dec. 10 -- Britain's experimental hovertrain, designed to carry passengers at speeds of up to 300 miles an hour, made its first public run today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The Congressional. "Tuesday-to-Thursday club" isn't what it used to be.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The Selective Service System withdrew today several proposed changes in regulations governing the draft following complaints from local draft boards and the public.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 10 -- The Ohio House of Representatives passed tonight budget legislation assuring the first personal and corporate income taxes in the state's history. The Senate gave its approval yesterday.

KANSAS CITY, Mo. -- Must we lose the grizzly bears of Yellowstone National Park? Two biologists, Drs. John and Frank Craighead, say this could happen rapidly under a management program which the National Park Service says is "restoring a natural grizzly population" in Yellowstone.

The American Jewish community was told yesterday that "Israel is a long way from self-sufficiency" and that $450-million must be raised in this country to enable the Jewish state to cope with pressing social and economic problems.
Emile Griffith, five times a world boxing champion, had an easy time in beating the fighting school-teacher from the Bronx, Danny McAloon, in Madison Square Garden last night.

The New Democratic Coalition, central organization of the Reform Movement, made public yesterday a "special target list" of 11 State Senators and 16 Assemblymen, all Republicans, whose defeat it would seek in next year's election.
News that the 19-day West German metal workers' strike had been settled stimulated purchases by commission hous of copper futures contracts on the Commodity Exchange in New York yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 10 -- Israel began an intense effort today to persuade members of the General Assembly to delete from a draft resolution on the Middle East any call for an Israeli commitment to withdraw from all occupied Arab territory.

Robert H. A year has passed since Edward Gierek took power in Poland as Communist party chief in the wake of economic riots in three port cities. It has been a largely successful year, and last week at the sixth party congress in Warsaw -- attended by all the Communist bloc leaders, including Leonid Brezhnev of Russia -- Mr. Gierek received what amounted to a vote of confidence.

BRUSSELS -- Despite reaffirmations of allied unity, increasing signs of neglect evinced by the United States toward NATO deeply distress many of its members who rely heavily on American leadership. The State Department of Mental Hygiene has announced plans to establish a residential treatment facility for retarded children and adults at the former Howard Park Central Hospital in the Howard Beach section of Queens.
LIMA, Peru, Dec. 7 -- A glow of optimism has spread through Peru since Nov. 16, when the state oil company brought in a gusher in the western reaches of the Amazon basin.

WASHINGTON -- The Democratic Congress sent the Republican President a tax bill last Thursday. The next day, Mr. Nixon not only signed the bill but went out of his way to praise it, almost extravagantly. Chile has had economic difficulties since the left - wing Government of President Salvador Allende Gossens took power a year ago and began nationalizing large domestic industries as well as foreign-owned copper, iron and nitrate properties. Meat, sugar, coffee and macaroni have been scarce.
