ANN ARBOR, Mich, Dec. 11 -- John Sinclair, a radical poet, serving the 29th month of a nine-and-a-half to 10-year sentence for possession of marijuana, answered a telephone in prison last night and heard 15,000 young people who were protesting his imprisonment roar, "Free John, Free John."
The Kansas City Chiefs are slight favorites to defeat the Oakland Raiders and clinch their division title today in one of the key National Football League games.

Anyone remember a classical education nowadays, when the world was divided into Greeks and Barbarians? It's a commonplace that most tribal groups have names for themselves which mean "us people" or "we human beings." The further out one gets from this "us," the wilder, fiercer, darker (cannibal if not obscene, who knows!) other tribes seem to get, until they may cease to be human altogether and sink into the animal world.
INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 11 (UPI) -- Fred Lewis scored 32 points to lead the Indiana Pacers to a 105-96 American Basketball Association victory over the Floridians tonight.
The 1971 session of the State Legislature "showed a gross disregard for social needs," the Community Service Society of New York, one of the city's leading social service agencies, charged yesterday.

IT would be easy enough to tell you about all of the spectacular things Christopher Walken is doing in the Yale Repertory Theater's new production of Albert Camus's "Caligula" -- and they are all astonishingly right -- but there are two much quieter moments that serve as vital clues to any comprehension of a bizarre emperor who was anything but mad.
PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 11 -- Paced by Brian Taylor's 33 points, Princeton handed Villanova its first defeat of the season, 82-68, before a sell out crowd of 7,550.
Plans for the first continent-wide evangelistic campaign designed to embrace the entire spectrum of Protestant theology from conservatism to liberalism were disclosed here last week.

Like everyone else, Alan R. Shaw of Harris, Upham Co., Inc., has heard the various forecasts that the stock market, as measured by the Dow-Jones industrial average, is headed for either 500 or 1000 or more (it closed last week at 856.75)
It is important that you know the last days in 1971 when you can sell a stock at a gain or loss and get the tax effect in time to claim it for 1971.
The stumbling gourmet of Forest Hills is pleased to report that our thriving little community has still another spot for dining out.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 11 (AP) -- An intensification of surface-to-air missile attacks against United States warplanes and the first shooting down of an American jet in eight months from North Vietnam could trigger a new round of retaliatory blows against North Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (UPI) -- State Department officials said today that North Vietnam had "completely dashed" Nixon Administration hopes that it had decided to improve the condition of the American prisoners of war.
EAST MEADOW, L. I. -- Few people have made a bigger impact in their debut on Broadway than Oscar Esparza, a man whose name never has been in lights.

IN "The Hellstrom Chronicle," producer-director Walon Green zeroed in on some of the world's tiniest -- though not necessarily weakest -- inhabitants. Now he is planning to zero out on something that is bigger than all of us: the world itself. Green's new film is titled, simply, "The Universe." And that's just what it's all about.
Dr. Paul Dudley White's praise of the Chinese Communist revolution for accomplishments in the field of public health (Op-Ed Dec. 5) is naive, unscientific and misleading.

In a year-end report yesterday, the city's Health Services Administrator said his agency was "delivering more for every dollar" than it did a year ago, and had effected dramatic rises in "productivity."

Offshore powerboat racing fans in Miami will be treated to a rare doubleheader today when the third race of the first Americas Cup regatta is followed by the Orange Blossom Grand Prix, a national title race.

Is there any justification for giving Saint-Saens' "Samson et Dalila" today? After seeing the Metropolitan Opera's revival on Friday night, well produced and performed though it was, the answer is no.

OAKLAND, Calif. Dec. 11 (AP) -- A second mistrial was declared today in the manslaughter trial of Heuy P. Newton, the Black Panther leader, in the death of an Oakland policeman in 1967. The jury reported it was "utterly impossible to reach a verdict."

For the Christmas-shopping woman whose husband has everything, a last-minute gift might be a round of golf with Billy Casper, the two-time United States Open champion. The cost? Only $5,000, plus expenses.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey will announce his candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination in mid-January. He plans an all-out primary campaign with major efforts in Florida and Wisconsin.

Remember the 20-cent subway token? It was about the size of a dime -- almost identical, actually, to the German pfennig. Before the slots were changed two years ago to accommodate the 30-cent, quarter-sized token, thousands of pfennigs were tossed into the turnstiles by New Yorkers trying "to beat the system."

NASHVILLE, Dec. 11 -- The first national conference on the status of health in the black community ended tonight with a demand for a countrywide comprehensive health care program and a simultaneous attack on major health concerns of black people.

ON READING (Grossman, $5.95.) by Andr6 Kertdsz is an un-simple set of phoWgraphs of all sorts of people, plus a cow, reading all sorts of writings. Kertz took them in various parts of the world between 1915 and now.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Dec. 11 -- The toss was perfect, the motion was fluent, without a hitch or hesitation, and the whip action on the racquet sent a hard, flat serve across the net and deep into the right hand corner of the service box.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration proposed today that stronger roofs be required on passenger automobiles after Aug. 15, 1977.

ALERT Wagnerites, long fearing the extinction of Homoloudus operahelden (Wagnerian tenor), a large male biped, formerly common in the wings of German opera houses, and characterized by enormous lungs and a woeful mating call lasting for hours, have joyously reported the existence of a truly magnificent specimen in Jess Thomas.

In July, 1969, the Communications Office of the United Church of Christ announced its desire to testify before a Senate subcommittee considering legislation on the renewal of television licenses. Two weeks later, the office received a letter from the Internal Revenue Service warning that excessive activity in the legislative area could lead to a loss of the church's tax-exempt status.

When the Columbia swimming team recorded a 71-42 victory over Lehman College Wednesday, it was the team's first victory since the 1968-69 season. The man most responsible for the squad's turnabout in form is the newly appointed head coach, Don Galluzzi.
Bravo to Ada Louise Huxtable. Her recent articles are good not only for owners of historic houses but also for owners of good modern ones.

FIRST there was Pavlo, who doesn't make it back from Vietnam. He's killed by a hand grenade thrown into a brothel. His family, such as it is, will never miss him. Then there was David, who comes home, all right, but who leaves his heart with a Vietnamese girl and his eyesight in a field hospital.

A performer who can survive a bomb scare and an antagonistic audience must be something special. Singer-songwriter Don McLean came on stage at Columbia University's Wollman Auditorium Friday night and was greeted by listeners who were justifiably angry about the garish, bright spotlights beaming down on them.

A DESPERATE, last-ditch effort is in progress to save the doomed ospreys of Long Island Sound. The experimental project, now in its fourth year, is apparently the first attempt to forestall the death of a pesticide-burdened bird population. It commands attention because there is growing evidence that not just a few but many kinds of birds are similarly threatened.

When "Inside the Blood Factory" was published in 1968, it was clear that in the poetry of Diane Wakoski a new sort of energy had been tapped. A fierce impulse toward confession and autobiography moved through her poems, but it took unexpected detours into an imagery of elusive beasts, colors and bizarre precious stones.

At the present rate that hockey books are popping out of Publisher's Row (wherever that is), it won't be long before vending machines in the DeKalb Avenue Station will start dispensing them. The trouble with this sudden discovery of Canada's national pastime is that hockey doesn't necessarily prepare its players to be authors.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Dec. 11 -- Deborah Youins is an 18-year-old Negro freshman who says the chief reason she enrolled at St. Mary's College here was "to get a Notre Dame degree."

The American Jewish Congress urged Mayor Lindsay yesterday to meet with Forest Hills residents to try to work out changes in the controversial low-income housing project, and "bring an end to the community turmoil."

The New York Urban League has announced that more than 200 black and Puerto Rican families have been able to rent apartments in recent months in Brooklyn and Queens apartment buildings owned by the Lefrak Organization.

Hunter College, part of the public City University system, has quietly embarked this year on a fund-raising campaign with a goal of $15-million in private and Federal funds over the next six or seven years.

Frosty nights bring frosty dawns, when every bush and weed-stem and blade of grass along the brook or riverbank is covered with the glittering filigree of hoarfrost. When it happens, the world is a fantastic place, dazzling in first sunlight. But it is even more ephemeral than moonlight on open water. This wonder that came in the damp, chill darkness will vanish with the warmth of midmorning.

THE Judaic Heritage Society of this city has issued a special medal to mark the joyous season of Hanukkah (Chanuka), which began at sundown last night. This gay holiday period, accompanied by feasts, prayers and gift-giving, is celebrated by Jews in all parts of the world.

A mood of grudging acceptance of the Administration's economic controls program seems to be emerging the nation nearly four months after President Nixon imposed wage and price controls on almost every segment of the economy.

LA PAZ, Bolivia -- An Indian woman dressed in perhaps a dozen skirts, several blankets and shawls over her blouses and equally traditional derby atop her braided hair walked into a North American bank here the other day and asked to "speak with a gringo."

ANCHORAGE, Dec. 11 -- Two scientists employed by the Atomic Energy Commission say that the five-megaton Cannikin nuclear test on Amchitka in the Aleutian Islands National Wildlife Refuge definitely killed from 900 to 1,100 sea otters.

TWO GENTLEMEN OF VERONA, the New York Shakespeare Festival production of a musical adaptation of Shakespeare's comedy, got 10 enthusiastic reviews (Barnes, Times; Watt, News; Watts, Post; Gottfried, Women's Wear; Oppenheimer, Newsday; Raidy, Newhouse Newspapers; Glover, AP; Gaver, UPI; Harris, CBS-TV; Klein, WNEW-TV), one mixed (Sanders, ABC-TV) and one negative review (Bookspan, WPIX-TV).

ALTHOUGH most people find that painting walls and ceilings is a relatively simple do-it-project (due primarily to the widespread use of latex paints and easy-to-use rollers or pad type applicators), many still have not mastered the technique of doing a smooth job of patching cracks and small holes so that they do not show through to mar the finished appearance of the freshly painted surfaces.
The Dallas Cowboys, driving for their sixth straight divisional championship, are heavily favored to defeat the New York Giants by a comfortable margin at Yankee Stadium today at 1 P.M.

Princess Margaret will officially open the International Boat Show at London's Earls Court Jan. 5. The Princess, who does quite a lot of holiday beating, will then tour the exhibition.
The frenetic, often violent, world of hockey has been in a state of virtual tranquility this season following stiffer rules and public outcries against its brutality.
TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The President of the newly formed Union of Arab Emirates has cabled the Shah of Iran pledging willingness to strengthen relations with Iran.
Unless a threatened court injunction blocks it, the Offtrack Betting Corporation will begin accepting separate-pool wagers tomorrow on thoroughbred races at Tropical Park in Florida.

GRETNA, Fla., Dec. 11 (AP) -- Until September, no blacks were registered to vote in this town in northern Florida's Gadsden County. But this week, blacks captured control of the town's government at the ballot box.

PORT HURON, Mich., Dec. 11 -- An explosion in a water tunnel under construction 250 feet underground near Port Huron killed 17 workers today, the authorities said. At least 22 workers escaped, eight with injuries.

Eighteen youths, described as members of a motorcycle gang, were arrested in an early-morning raid yesterday at a two-family house on Staten Island, where the police said they seized 15 guns of various kinds and a number of knives.
ATHENS, Ohio, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Ohio University upset fourth-ranked Ohio State, 79-68, in college basketball today.

LOS ANGELES -- "Students are more reflective these days," a faculty member at Indiana University said recently. "They knew that running down to the courthouse and protesting won't change much, and that sitting by a babbling brook in a meadow won't change much either. They want to be realistically progressive."
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11 -- Dr. Mark R. Shedd was hailed as an enlightened educator with progressive ideas when became superintendent of Philadelphia's public schools in November of 1966.

DACCA, Pakistan, Dec. 11 -- Lieut. Gen. A. A. K. Niazi, military commander of East Pakistan, told newsmen today that "you will see my dead body, or alive I'll go forward." His statement lessened hopes of surrender before the Dacca battle is joined by advancing Indian troops.
Sixteen restaurants, delicatessens and groceries in all five boroughs were named yesterday by the city's Health Services Administration for alleged serious violations of the Health Code.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11 -- Coming from last as he left the backstretch Middletown Stables's Freetex raced to a dead heat with John D. March's Eager Exchange in the Heritage Stakes today at Liberty Bell. The odd result made the 1 1/16-mile race for 2-year-olds the richest race in Pennsylvania history.

PHILADELPHIA -- America has such an insubstantial, even casual, grasp upon its architectural past that any attempt at architectural restoration and restitution is to be applauded. It never ceases to amaze me how much of our history in the streets we have senselessly demolished and how little remains of what was once a rich heritage.

PARIS, Dec. 11 -- The Paris Municipal Council has just made another reluctant surrender to the automobile with somewhat anguished approval of the beginnings of an expressway along the Left Bank, through some of the most historic sections of the city.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally has asked Congress for legislation increasing the number of top-level jobs in his department and promoting several of its top officials to higher rank.

Christmas shoppers basked in balmy weather yesterday as temperatures in the city came close to a record for the day.

MOSCOW, Dec. 11 -- The Theater on the Malaya Bronnaya, a small Moscow house on a quiet side street, has a successful production on its hands -- a hard-hitting play about the profit-oriented economic reform.

One is outside myself, as my eyes search landscapes through train, plane or car windows and I perhaps chat with other passengers over the dinner table. CAIRO, Dec. 10 -- President Anwar el-Sadat has promised the Soviet Union that he will continue to give naval facilities to its Mediterranean fleet -- even after a possible settlement with Israel. The appointments of James W. Walker Jr. and Winsor H. Watson Jr. as executive vice presidents of the American Stock Exchange have been announced by Paul Kolton, president. Both men formerly were senior vice presidents.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- At a time when holiday menus with exotic courses are catching the attention of most foodminded Americans, the Food and Drug Administration is acting as an almost unwilling mediator in a dispute over a far more prosaic product, macaroni.

Connally, to achieve an international monetary agreement in major negotiations to take place here next weekend.

NORTH RUMAILA, Iraq -About 18 months ago, there were only snakes and wild lizzards moving across this vast desert expanse, which is world's richest oilfields.

The hands that knit in pink or blue, the midwife's tone of voice, the joy or disappointment of the parents, "tell" the fetus or newborn infant what it is to expect from life. Buoyed by the Federal Reserve's decision Friday to cut the discount rate and full of hope that an international currency settlement will be reached this week, the credit markets are confident that they can handle all the financing that is scheduled.
A group of 18 leading economists attacked the Administration's international economic policy yesterday, and warned that the world could be sliding into a "new mercantilism."

COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Dec. 12 (UPI) -- Richard Petty, completing the greatest year of any driver in NASCAR history, captured the $80,000 Texas 500 by half a lap from Buddy Baker of Charlotte, N.C., in a Dodge. It was Petty's 21st victory in 1971.
BRUSSELS, Dec. 12 -- Calm has overtaken the new-issue side of the Eurobond market while secondary trading activity has picked up and prices for straight dollar debt continue to hold firm.
Despite the threat of a Federal injunction, the Offtrack Betting Corporation will go ahead today with plans to take wagers on thoroughbred races at Tropical Park in Florida.

CALCUTTA, India, Dec. 12 -Pakistan relented today on letting foreigners leave Dacca, and the evacuees arrived in India saying that the Bengali population was fleeing the East Pakistani capital in droves as Indian troops moved in on the city.

Losing the battle, the war and a large portion of what remains of their already decimated squad, the New York Giants absorbed a 42-14 pasting from the Dallas Cowboys yesterday at Yankee Stadium pretty much according to form.

PARIS, Dec. 12 -- In a climactic match that had been anticipated all week, Ilie Nastase of Rumania defeated Stan Smith of Pasadena, Calif., tonight to win the $15,000 first prize in the Pepsi Masters tennis tournament.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Monday, Dec. 13 -- The United States urged the Security Council last night to call upon India to accept forthwith a cease-fire and a mutual withdrawal in the Indian-Pakistani war.

PENNSAUKEN, N. J., Dec. 12 -- The third top-winning dog in America for 1971, a Doberman pinscher, Ch. Dolph von Tannenwald, was named best of 1,277 dogs at the 39th annual show of the Camden Kennel Club at Ivy Stone Inn today.
In a further effort to turn its assets into cash, Lennen Newell has sold its Pacific division to employes.

MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Bill Martin, a 29-yearold furniture dealer from Clark, N. J., captured the Americas Cup power boat championship today, roaring across the finish line five miles ahead of Vincenzo Balestrieri of Rome.

BARROW, Alaska -- It was four below zero and the wind was taking fierce nips at the carcasses of eight caribou stowed on the roof of the two-story green frame cottage a couple of hundred yards from the awesome, iced-over Arctic shore.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 12 -- Steel producers were looking for rising prices and orders last week.

Austin J. Tobin, who has been the executive director of the Port of New York Authority for nearly 30 years, announced yesterday that he would retire at the end of March to allow for "the orderly transfer of executive responsibility to other hands."
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 12 -- Foreign Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan told a cheering throng of Pakistanis today, "We are not cowards, we will fight to the last man if it has to be."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Shortly after Maurice H. Stans took office as Secretary of Commerce, the private foundation that he controls acquired a financial interest in a Thailand paper company that benefits directly from United States Government money and management assistance.

ATHENS, Dec. 1 2 -- The European subsidiary of the Northrop Corporation has installed a $12.5-million radiotelevision network for the Greek Government that will link the whole country for the first time to the state-run broadcasting system and enable it to beam short-wave radio programs to any part of the world.

If you haven't chosen your Christmas presents by now, you might have to give books. And you could do worse Though books have somehow acquired the reputation of being unimaginative gifts, this amounts to a contradiction in terms. When properly chosen, they are among the most imaginative.

NEW DELHI, Dec. 12 (Reuters) -- Vasily V. Kuznetsov, the Soviet First Deputy Foreign Minister, held talks on the Indian -Pakistani war with Prime Minister Indira Gandhi shortly after his arrival today.
FREEPORT, Bahamas, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Bob Goalby carded a steady 70 today and won the $26,000 first prize in the $130,000 Bahama Islands open golf tournament with a 72-hole total of 275.

Five journalists have been named to receive Alicia Patterson Fund fellowships four travel and study in 1972, it was announced yesterday by Joseph P. Albright, president of the fund.
HONG KONG, Monday, Dec. 13 -- One American held prisoner in China since 1952 crossed into Hong Kong today and Peking announced that the sentence of another had been reduced.

In his recent letter Dr. Seymour Frank writes that the Podiatry Society of New York, of which he is president, submitted a detailed plan to the city two years ago to prevent abuses of unjustified prescribing of orthopedic shoes. The City Health Department, he alleges, "rejected our recommendation out of hand."

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 12 -Otis Taylor carried his team, the Kansas City Chiefs, into pro football's playoffs today by making four big pass catches on a final 91-yard drive that beat the Oakland Raiders, 1614.

ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 12 -- Officials at Cornell University announced today that a five-man committee would be set up to study what is now a two-game boycott of the basketball team by six black varsity players. The committee will be given decision-making powers.
The state's 207 legislators will convene in Albany tomorrow to reapportion the Legislature for the 1972 elections amidst charges and denials of secret gerrymandering.

United Air Lines this week plans to file a motion with the Civil Aeronautics Board in support of a 2.8 per cent fare increase sought by Trans World Airlines and which was turned down on technical grounds.
CHHAMB, Kashmir, Dec. 12 -- This village in the Indian section of disputed Kashmir is a shattered ghost town once more, and the earth around it is scorched by battle.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (UPI) -- Most states are shirking their legal responssibility to provide birth control information and devices for low-income women under the Federal Government's illegitimacy prevention program, a Government study said today.

The Alekhine Memorial Tournament, now in progress in Moscow, brought together the chess champion of the world, Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union, and his compatriot, Mikhail Tal, a former world titleholder. The antagonist employed a Sicilian Defense, the line of which is a favorite with Bobby Fischer, the American chess genius who is slated for a title match with Spassky some time before June, 1972.

After playing four Super Bowl contenders in the previous five weeks, the Jets returned to their own level of competition yesterday and defeated the New England Patriots, 13-6, behind a defense that blunted an anticipated passing duel between Joe Namath and Jim Plunkett.
LONDON, Dec. 12 -- An American oil man in London was asked the other day to comment on the nationalization of the British Petroleum Company's assets in Libya.

The Cliff Keuter Dance Company presented four works by Mr. Keuter Saturday night at the American Theater Lab, 219 West 19th Street, under the auspices of Choreoconcerts Choreographers Theater. The program included a premiere, "Gargoyles," and a recent piece "Wood."

There have been so many remarkable space accomplishments since Sputnik I went into orbit in 1957 that the tendency is to be blase about even spectacular new advances. That probably explains the lack of excitement when Moscow revealed that it had successfully softlanded a capsule on Mars and had received data from the Martian surface early this month.

LAJES FIELD, the Azores, Dec. 12 -- President Nixon arrived here shortly before 10 P.M. (6 P.M., Eastern standard time) today for two days of crucial conferences with President Pompidou of France on monetary and trade relations between the United States and the European Economic Community.

" The Decameron," which opened yesterday at the Festival Theater, was shown at the ninth New York Film Festival. The following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared on Oct. 5, 1971, in The New York Times:

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12 -Col. George F. Sawyer, professor of military science at the University of Pennsylvania, issued a statement today expressing the possibility that military and naval science programs could be maintained in some form on the Penn campus.
ROME, Dec. 12 -- The 1,008member electoral assembly in two ballots today failed for the fourth day to choose a new president of Italy.
After a "more than pleasant" 45-year relationship with Edwin Bird Wilson, Inc., the Bowery Savings Bank is moving its advertising account to Ogilvy Mather.

A conference committee of House and Senate is scheduled to meet this morning to iron out differences between the two versions of the bill extending the President's power to control wages and prices to April 30, 1973. The measure is needed to give the Administration sufficient time and authority to follow through with some hope of success on its undertaking to control inflation and restore confidence in the nation's economy.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Dec. 12 -- A Pakistani spokesman said tonight that Indian forces in East Pakistan had warned Pakistani defenders that if they did not surrender, they would be turned over after the war to guerrillas "to be butchered."

NASHVILLE, Dec. 12 -- A black woman from Iowa -"Don't use my name; I took some sick time to come here" -- called to her fellow passengers not to hurry as they got off the bus that had shuttled them from meeting rooms of a conference on black health care to a cafeteria for lunch.

Jule M. Sugarman, the city's Human Resources Administrator and Commissioner of Social Services, charged yesterday that the sstate's Welfare Inspector -General, George F. Berlinger, was engaged in "a political attack on welfare."

The Chinese delegation to the United Nations played host to the Chinese community here over the weekend for the first time since the delegates arrived more than a month ago to replace the ousted Nationalists.

A Washington man who was described by some fellow passengers as drunk allegedly made a vague hijacking threat to a stewardess on a New York-bound Braniff airliner yesterday and was arrested when the plane landed at Kennedy International Airport.

If there is one thing New York Ranger fans like on the Madison Square Garden ice, it is a one-sided game in their team's favor. They got just that last night when the Rangers settled a few things with the Pittsburgh Penguins, winning by 6-1.

HARTFORD -- The goal: an electric power supply essential to man's harmonious relationship to his physical environment and necessary to his future social well-being. To achieve such a supply may require as much as thirty years of intense research effort. The search for such an energy supply should, therefore, be a central purpose for the electric utility industry and the nation over the next generation.
MONTPELIER, Vt.--They used to refer to the building here as "the reconstructed Pavilion Hotel," but slowly the word "hotel" was dropped.

Jacques Delacote, a 29-yearold Frenchman, won the $5,000 first prize last night in the finals of the 10th Dimitri Mitropoulos International Competition, one of the world's most prestigious conducting contests.

New York Hota and the German-Hungarians, two of the best soccer teams in the area, reached the New York final of the United States Challenge Cup yesterday by posting 1-0 victories over the Greek-Americans and Eintracht, respectively.
Housing experts believe that condominiums and cooperatives are one helpful answer to the growing housing shortage in middle income ranges.

With Tristan and Isolde groaning out their frustration and universe-shaking consummation in the Metropolitan Opera's Brobdingnagian production of Wagner's masterpice, it was a pleasure yesterday afternoon to take a charming trip to operatic Lilliput.
VAL D'ISERE, France, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Karl Schranz of Austria won the men's downhill World Cup race at the International First Snow ski tournament today.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 12 -- The Old World champions, appropriately from Italy and representing the Old World, decisively defeated the new world champions, of course from the New World, in the $15,000 challenge match that ended here last night.
David Sarnoff, the hard-driving broadcasting pioneer who rose from a $5.50-a-week office boy to chairman of the RCA Corporation, died yesterday morning. He was 80 years old.

PORT HURON, Mich., Dec. 12--The death toll climbed to 22 today in the gas explosion in a water tunnel being built under Lake Huron, and Federal and state investigators began seeking the cause of the disaster.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., Dec. 12 -- Six teen-agers were killed here this afternoon when the station wagon in which they were riding struck a tree and overturned. Two others are in serious condition at local hospitals.

HONOLULU, Dec. 12--Japan made major concessions here today at the close of two days of trade talks with the United States. The negotiations were aimed at paving the way to a realignment of international currencies when the Group of 10 major currency countries meet Friday and Saturday in Washington.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -Senior Administration officials said today that the Soviet Union appeared to be reinforcing its naval strength in the Indian Ocean. They said that they believed that the move was connected with the Indian-Pakistani war.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Costa Rican national guardsmen used tear gas today to get three hijackers out of a commandeered Nicaraguan jetliner that had stopped hero for fuel. One hijacker was shot fatally, the authorities said.
NEW DELHI, Dec. 12 -- Indian troops in East Pakistan resumed their advance on Dacca today and reached the little town of Narsingdi, 22 miles northeast of the capital, Indian spokesmen said.

MOSCOW, Dec. 12 -- The Soviet Union announced today the completion of the world's largest hydroelectric plant, a Siberian station that has three times the rated capacity of the Grand Coulee Dam in the United States.

ATHENS, Dec. 12 -- A selected group of Greeks voted today to elect 60 members of a "consultative committee on legislation," an advisory body the Government has promoted as a training ground for a new kind of politician.

OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 12 (UPI) -- District Attorney Lowell Jensen pondered today whether to try the Black Panther leader Huey P. Newton for a fourth time on charges of killing an Oakland policeman in 1967.
DACCA, Pakistan, Dec. 12 -Indian troops were advancing on Dacca from three directions tonight and senior Pakistani officers predicted they would reach the East Pakistani capital within 48 hours.

What began as straight situation comedy for the New York Giants is ending as pure daytime hospital drama. A training camp marked by daily disappearances and a daring leap by Charlie Harper out of a first-floor window has led to a final game in which only 35 players will be available to face the Philadelphia Eagles Sunday.

While there was scarcely a dull moment in the Lincoln Center Chamber Music Society's far-ranging and instrumentally varied concert Sunday afternoon in Tully Hall, primary interest centered on the world premiere of Frank Martin's "Poemes de la mort."

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- The Countess in Mozart's "Marriage of Figaro" has experienced the sadness, the humiliation of strayed love. There is nobility in her, a passion restrained by dignity. Musically and intellectually it is a most sophisticated part, expressing Mozart's realistic understanding of human imperfection.

GENEVA, Dec. 13 -- The International Air Transport Association announced today that the basic agreement on reduced fares reached in Honolulu last month by the major airlines that ply the North Atlantic has been completed and formally approved to take effect April 1.

LONDON -- The women's liberation movement is frequently seen as one of a series of radical uprisings: black power, students, women, gay liberation. Such an assimilation obscures one of its crucial defining features. Blacks are in ghettos, students in colleges, homosexuals discriminated against together.

Distillers Corporation - Seagrams, Ld., registered the highest sales and earnings for any quarter in its 44-year history in the three months ended Oct. 31, it was reported yesterday by Edgar M. Bronfman, president.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -Congress took a tentative step toward breaking the adjournment impasse over foreign aid tonight when a House committee prepared a compromise stopgap financing plan designed to win reluctant Senate support.

Waza Roman proved sturdy enough to defeat the odds-on entry, representing Sigmund Sommer, in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 13 -- College newspapers, many of which took a sharp swing toward radical journalism during the campus turmoil of the late nineteen-sixties, appear, for the most part, to have made a conscious move back to objective news coverage.

CANTON, Ohio, Dec. 13 -Mayor Lindsay, who has frequently been embroiled in New York labor controversies, called for a "new doctrine of fairness" for American workers in his first major labor speech as a new Democrat tonight.

The Minnesota Vikings and the Kansas City Chiefs will be the home teams when the National Football League's postseason playoffs begin on Christmas Day, Commissioner Pete Rozelle announced here yesterday.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 13 -- Consumers in this key city on Chesapeake Bay are cautious and even troubled today. They say it in various ways, but the refrain is the same: They are irked by still-rising prices and disturbed by the lack of definition of the latest phase of President Nixon's economic policy.
Stock prices forged ahead yesterday on a broad front. Gains in the popular stock averages were not spectacular, but the breadth of the market's advance was impressive.

Despite a court action in Florida and some costly inaction here by its own computers, the Offtrack Betting Corporation managed to handle $46,657 worth of wagers yesterday on Tropcal Park's thoroughbred races.

GARY, Ind., Dec. 13 -- For the first time in a decade, the skies over Gary these days are clean and crisp. It is now possible to breathe deeply without coughing and see clearly from the lower reaches of Broadway northward to the Indiana Tollway overpass.
BIELAWKI, Poland, Dec. 4 -Boleslaw Rabala is a 27-yearold private farmer, one of 3.5 million in Poland. He has finally received clear title to his 25-acre spread.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Savings of at least $1-billion a year might be realized if political constraints did not prevent the closing of various military bases around the country, David Packard said today as he stepped down as Deputy Secretary of Defense.
LONDON, Dec. 13 (Reuters) -- After six months of monthly surpluses varying from $65-million to $180million, Britain's overseas trade in November ended with a surplus of only $12million.
Washington's renewed efforts to obtain effective intervention by the United Nations Security Council to stop the Indian-Pakistani conflict are once again too little and too late.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (UPI) -- Labor Secretary James D. Hodgson said today that Federal inspectors found violations in four out of every five of the 9,300 work places inspected during the first six months of the new Occupational Safety and Health Act.
Interest rates were lowered throughout the credit markets yesterday in the wake of the Federal Reserve Boards discount -rate reduction and the cut in the prime rate by two large New York banks.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Dec. 13 (UPI) -- Thomas K. Mattingly 2d watched the next to last moon rocket move to its oceanside launching pad today and said the space program was just beginning.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Tuesday, Dec. 14 (Reuters) -- Seventysix people were arrested when disturbances broke out in the main square of Zagreb, capital of Croatia, last night. Several policemen and rioters were slightly injured, Tanyug, the official press agency, said today.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 13 -- George Allen brought his Washington Redskins, including eight ex-Rams, back to Los Angeles tonight on a memorable scalping party. The Redskins tommy-hawked the Rams, 38-24, and clinched a National Football Conference playoff spot.

The Knicks, in an attempt to strengthen their front court while Willis Reed is recuperating from tendonitis of his left knee, obtained Charlie Paulk, a 6-foot-9-inch forward, yesterday from the Chicago Bulls. The Knicks gave up cash and their second-round pick in the 1973 college draft.

Last night, at 8 o'clock, the N.E.T. Opera Theater presented a two-hour British Broadcasting Corporation production of Offenbach's "Tales of Hoffmann." Last month N.E.T. Opera presented its own production of "Stravinsky Remembered," with documentary reminiscences of the composer and a highly imaginative performance of his "Le Rossignol."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The Price Commission said today that in a survey of the nation's biggest businesses, 44 per cent of those answering gave assurances they would try to "hold the line" on price increases.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -Mayor Sam Yorty of Los Angeles needs a strong run in Manchester if he is to do at all well in New Hampshire's March 7 Presidential primary. But a large percentage of the city's Democratic voters are working-class Roman Catholics of French and Irish ancestry and Mr. Yorty's opponents think they have found something that could damage the Mayor's chances among those voters.

DETROIT, Dec. 13 -- James M. Roche, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, predicted today that the economy would expand more vigorously in 1972 than it had this year and that there would be some progress in reducing inflation and unemployment.

Former Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary has agreed to testify at the public hearings of the Knapp Commission, which is investigating whether high officials in the Lindsay administration failed to act on allegations of police corruption.

Y., Dec. 13 -- Two inmates of the Attica Correctional Facility testified before a Federal magistrate inside the prison today that no sooner had they left an interview with newsmen last month in which they complained about harassment and abuse by guards than they were subjected to new threats and mistreatment.
Mrs. Pamela Digby Churchill Hayward Harriman, the English - born third wife of W. Averell Harriman, stepped before Federal Judge Thomas F. Croake to take the oath of allegiance to the United States.
PALO ALTO, Calif., Dec. 13 (AP) -- The father of Mary Ann Harbert, who was released from prison by China, said today that he and his wife had given their daughter up for dead three years ago.

A stockholder's lawsuit seeking to block the proposed reorganization of the American National Insurance Company of Galveston, Tex., was ordered transferred yesterday from New York to Texas Federal Court.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (Reuters) -- A Soviet satellite has for the first time destroyed a target below an altitude of 160 miles, indicating the Russians can now intercept reconnaissance satellites, the authoritative Aviation Week magazine said today.

GENEVA, Dec. 13 -- The International Committee of the Red Cross announced today that it would assist the wounded and prisoners of both sides in the Indian-Pakistani war. A committee spokesman said that India and Pakistan had agreed to accept Red Cross help.

NEW DELHI, Dec. 13 -- "That woman" -- as the Pakistani President, Agha Mohammad Yahya Khan, has several times described Prime Minister Indira Gandhi -- seems assured and comfortable in the role of a national wartime leader.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (UPI) -- Starting a Government move to increase prices that some farm-bloc legislators hope eventually will take up to 600 million bushels of corn off a glutted market, Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz announced today the purchase of 1.425 million bushesl of corn in Middle Western markets.

Potato futures closed 1 to 14 cents higher a hundredweight on the sale of 1,231 lots on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday, in moderately active trading.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13--The Senate approved tonight legislation that would continue authority for economic controls and bring all rent-controlled apartments under Federal guidelines.

HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Dec. 13 -The Suffolk Human Rights Commission charged today that the county's Police Department had refused to investigate nearly 40 cases of alleged police brutality this year, including half a dozen cases in the last two weeks.

MOSCOW, Dec. 13--The Soviet Union unveiled this weekend its latest and largest space tracking ship, the 45,000-ton Cosmonaut Yuri Gagarin, which represents a significant addition to the Russians' deep space communications network.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Dec. 13 -- With Indian troops massing for assaults on Dacca in East Pakistan, there were increasing indications here today that Pakistan's general staff had decided to dig in and fight India to the bitter end.

The Famous Writers School, Inc., a correspondence school based in Westport, Conn., has signed an agreement with the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs promising what the department calls "substantial revisions" in advertisements.

DETROIT, Dec. 13 (UPI) -The Chrysler Corporation and the United Auto Workers broke off discussions today on the feasibility of a short work week after the company refused to test a work week of four 10hour shifts in one of its plants.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Retail sales rebounded strongly in November after a dip in October, preliminary figures of the Commerce Department indicated today.
PEKING, Dec. 13 (Reuters)--Pakistani diplomats continued their contacts with Chinese officials today over the Indian-Pakistani war, Pakistani sources reported.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The Inter - American Development Bank has announced the appointment of Henry J. Costanzo as executive vice president, replacing I. Graydon Upton. The United States Court of Appeals issued a decision here yesterday, involving a Securities Exchange Act provision that, it said, could produce a "marked impact on holders, sellers and purchasers of securities."

The banking system's prime lending rate appeared headed for another general reduction yesterday as two major New York City banks announced 1/4-point cuts, to 5 1/4 per cent, in this key business lending charge.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 13 -- With a special legislative session called by Governor Rockefeller for tomorrow night in Albany on re-mapping Assembly and Senate district lines, a harried staff of a dozen legislative committee aides were still working on detailed maps tonight.

Union steamfitters defied a Federal court restraining order yesterday and continued their four-day walkout at the World Trade Center in a dispute involving how many white and nonwhite workers should be laid off.

The board of the Xerox Corporation named Archie R. McCardell as president yesterday, succeeding C. Peter McColough, who was named chairman.

Beecham offered to acquire Glaxo for stock valued at about $737-million, making it one of the biggest British take - over bids in years.
Despite job freezes and budget crises, the city has more employes on the payroll today than it had one year ago, the Budget Bureau acknowledged yesterday.

The proposal for a Madison Avenue mall, tied to a larger traffic plan for midtown Manhattan, is being greeted as pie in the sky by a public that has been fed little else by politicians in the past.

For the second consecutive day, the New York Coffee end Sugar Exchange yesterday reported the largest trading volume in its history for the world sugar contract No. 11, and for any other single futures contract traded on the exchange.

WASHINGTON -- In early 1968, when it appeared that the Ohio delegation to the Republican National Convention would not go for Richard Nixon, I opposed the organization slate and was elected as a free and independent delegate. At Miami, candidate Nixon received two Ohio votes, mine and the other district delegate who was elected on my independent slate.
COLUMBIA, Md., Dec. 15 -- The customer is unhappy.
Trafalgar Hospital, a 145-bed private nonprofit institution at 161 East 90th Street, has formally sought permission to move to Manhattan's West Side.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Senator Charles McC. Mathias Jr., of Maryland, a liberal Republican who has endorsed the re-election of President Nixon, said today that he was convinced there was no plan to purge him from the party, a move that has been reported in recent weeks.
TRENTON, Dec. 15 -- Gov. William T. Cahill said today that he would probably propose legislation next year providing state aid to private colleges and universities in New Jersey.

BURBANK, Calif., Dec. 15 (Reuters) -- Representatives of Federal agencies and 24 lending banks said today that they were "impressed" by the progress of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation since it received Government guarantees for $250-million in additional private financing in September.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Dec. 15 -- Riding the waves of confrontations and crises that have swept the country in the last few years, the lecture circuit has become big business, with millions of dollars worth of annual bookings and top performers earning six-figure salaries.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- A reported compromise between France and West Germany on the new exchange rate to be established between the franc and the mark indicated further progress today toward an eventual world monetary agreement.

Edward Sulzberger says the landlords need "relief." Mr. Sulzberger's letter (Nov. 12) shows clearly why there is such a divergence in the landlord-tenant philosophy. Landlords want socialism for themselves, but demand that the relief they seek from "tax burdens" not be shared with their tenants.
Pearlie Mae's back in town to promote her latest book, her newest hobby and an old friend, Pearl Baily. It comes to her as naturally as breathing.
It was 10:15 A.M. when The Voice reached Aqueduct yesterday, parking his 1968 Volvo in the lot reserved for working press.

Americans of Arab descent look with considerable concern upon the stanch support accorded by both the mass media and by the Government to Israel and Zionism. The Arabs are called upon to "recognize" Israel (although the Zionists are not so enjoined to acknowledge the rights of the Palestinians, who are a legitimate entity); they are accused of recalcitrance and obstinacy; the Fedayeen are "terrorists"; and so on.

OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 15 -- After spending nearly two years in prison and standing trial three times, Huey P. Newton, the Black Panther leader, today won a dismissal of charges that he killed an Oakland policeman.

VIENNA, Dec. 15 (UPI) -- Soviet and American negotiators at the talks on limit action of strategic arms met for 90 minutes today for their second meeting in two days. They scheduled another meeting for Friday.
Governor Rockefeller gave the principal eulogy at the funeral yesterday of David Sarnoff, the immigrant telegrapher who founded the electronic communications industry.

BOSTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The Boston Celtics got 20 or more points from four of their five starters tonight in a 112-100 decision over the Seattle Super-Sonics in a National Basketball Association game. It was the Celtics' third victory in a row.

Frank (Pancho) Martin left his fans "laughing as he said good-by" to the local season at Aqueduct yesterday. The Cuban-born trainer came through with the record-breaking achievement of sending out five winners on the nine-race card, a feat never before performed in modern thorough-bred racing.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Heidi Ann Fletcher, 21 years old, daughter of Thomas W. Fletcher, the city manager of San Jose, Calif., today pleaded guilty to murder, armed robbery and other charges stemming from the holdup last May of a savings and loan office in which a guard was shot to death.

For 20 minutes last night in Madison Square Garden, the Philadelphia Flyers skated the New York Rangers on even terms. Jimmy Johnson had matched Brad Park's 11th goal of the season, and both scores came on power plays.

NEWARK, Dec. 15 -- The Essex County Prosecutor's office is investigating reports that the Newark Board of Education is paying for a "no-show" night security force, some of whose members have criminal records.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 15 -- Quality rather than quantity is the hallmark of the Knockout Team Championship being contested at the International Hotel here this week.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The White House, seeking to clear up confusion caused by two senior aides yesterday, affirmed its unhappiness today with the Soviet Union's strong support for India but said that the possibility of canceling President Nixon's trip to Moscow was not "a live issue."
Including Judge Otto Kerner, who was charged yesterday by a Federal grand jury in Chicago with conspiracy, perjury and income tax evasion, only four Federal judges have ever been indicted.
State Senator Albert B. Lewis affixed an Alabama license plate to a stolen automobile yesterday outside City Hall with three policemen watching, but nobody stopped him.

YARDVILLE, N.J., Thursday, Dec. 16 -- About 100 inmates rioted late yesterday afternoon at the State Youth Reception and Correction Center here and, later, seized the assistant superintendent and a correction officer as hostages.

In your recent editorial "Times Square Slaying," you speak of ". . . pimps, prostitutes and other social parasites." In what sense are pimps and prostitutes as such any more social parasites than The Times is or other fair enterprises meeting community needs?
MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 15 -- A white Nassau County policeman who shot and killed a 16-year-old black Freeport boy was absolved of any wrong-doing by a grand jury here today.
ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 15--Premier Nihat Erim said today that he was undertaking to govern with a reorganized Cabinet "in complete understanding" with the military commanders.

Governor Rockefeller's tax package for bridging the gap between estimated state revenues and expenditures is generally good so far as it goes. The problem is, regrettably, that the tax package may not go far enough. Even so, it is not yet sure that the state's legislative leaders will approve it.

AMITYVILLE, L.I., Dec. 15 -- A 16-year-old boy fired more than 50 shots into the walls of his house here last night and was found dead, apparently of a self-inflicted shotgun wound, when the police finally broke in after pumping six tear-gas canister into the rooms where the shots were heard, police officials said today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (UPI) -- Democratic party leaders reported today that 25 states were in full compliance with delegate selection standards for the 1972 convention, and that nine others were close.

ATHENS, Dec. 15 -- The commander of a tank battalion who allegedly tried to overthrow the military-backed Government was sentenced to 14 months' imprisonment by a court-martial in Salonika last night.
PALMER, Alaska, Dec. 15 (AP) -- A strong earthquake was recorded last night off the east coast of Siberia's Kamchatka Peninsula, the Palmer Observatory reported.

ALGIERS, Dec. 15 -- The national oil companies of France and Algeria signed an agreement today ending a harsh dispute set off by President Houari Boumediene's nationalization of French oil and gas interests in this country six months ago.

Miss Allegra Kent Taylor and Douglas Argyll Campbell, a stockbroker with offices in New York, Los Angeles and London, were married in London yesterday. The Anglican ceremony in the Chelsea Old Church was performed by the Rev. C. E. Leighton. A reception for some 500 guests followed at Crosby Hall, next door.

Last Tuesday, this column described briefly seven children's picture books -- the best of this year's rather mediocre crop. What follows is what struck me as the best of the children's books published this year that depend primarily on text to tell their stories. They are ranked roughly according to the degree of their sophistication, with the simplest described first.

Environmental groups led by the Scenic Hudson Preservation Conference filed suit in State Supreme Court in Albany yesterday challenging a state ruling that Consolidated Edison's controversial Storm King power plant would not violate water quality standards.

Strongly worded statements were issued yesterday by the chancellors of the City University and the State University, criticizing proposals madeTuesday by the heads of six major private universities who called upon New York State to help them eliminate mountng deficits at their institutions.
There is one word that almost everyone -- no matter how they assess his performance -- uses to describe John J. Burns, and the word is "likable."
LA PLATA, Argentina, Dec. 15 (Reuters) -- Robert Lee Jackson, of Alcoa, Tnn., was sent to prison for five years today for his part last July in the longest hijacking on record.

Brewing operations at the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company's plant in Brooklyn closed down yesterday. And all packaging operations there will halt at the end of this month if the company is unable to find a buyer to run the plant.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Congress voted today to extend unemployment compensation benefits in areas of high joblessness, with the Federal Treasury underwriting the estimated cost of $274-million.

Former Senator Eugene J. McCarthy said yesterday that if the nation's 18-to-20-year-old youths merely waited passively to exercise their newly won right to vote on Election Day and did not remain active in politics, "we might have well been better off without it."

Judge Dudley B. Bonsal told more than 100 union steamfitters who were seated and standing in his Federal courtroom yesterday that he saw no reason for their work stoppage, and that they should go back to work today.

The John V. Lindsay Associations, the Mayor's chief patronage dispensers and a major source of Mr. Lindsay's pre-campaign funds, agreed yesterday to file financial statements to avoid a possible ruling by the State Attorney General that they were violating the state election law.

" Even Dwarfs Started Small," which opened yesterday at the St. Marks Cinema, was shown at the eighth New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared on Sept. 17, 1970, in The New York Times:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Industrial production recorded a large gain in November, only about one-quarter of which was traceable to the end of the coal strike, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 15 -- Edvard Hambro, Norway's chief delegate, reported today the failure of his seven-month effort to settle the financial crisis of the United Nations. He urged that a group be set up by Secretary General Thant to make new proposals before the 1972 General Assembly session.

Morris Mendelson, 49-year-old associate professor of finance at the Wharton School of Finance and Commerce, University of Pennsylvania, has taken a long look at the William McChesney Martin Jr. study of the securities markets and has allowed himself a professorial tsk, tsk.
A State Supreme Court justice yesterday set aside a $6,610,000 damage verdict against Dun Bradstreet, Inc., and ordered a new trial of defamation charges against the credit-reporting agency.

BONN, Dec. 5 -- West Germany's military services, for years the largest in Central Europe, have raised the standards of their training and equipment at a critical moment for the defenses of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization on the Continent.

MIAMI, Dec. 15 -- A Cuban gunboat attacked a Miami-based freighter today in Bahamian waters and took possession of the vessel after wounding the captain and two crewmen, the United States Coast Guard reported.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 15 -- At the end of his first full year of Presidential campaigning, Senator George McGovern of South Dakota has done virtually everything that a candidate hopes to do except what seems the most important thing of all: to demonstrate substantial public support.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the-counter makret moved mostly higher after a lower opening yesterday in moderate trading.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- A United States naval task force of eight ships, led by the nuclear aircraft carrier Enterprise and transporting 2,000 marines, steamed northwest in the Bay of Bengal today toward India and East Pakistan.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Dr. Henry Kissinger can get into and out of China in high secrecy, but lately he can't seem to give a backgrounder without having his cover blown. Maybe he ought to draw the conclusion that he and what he usually has to say are too big to hide.
WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 15 -- The police commissioners of six major cities called today for Federal control of handguns.

DETROIT, Dec, 15 -- The American automobile manufacturers are programing strong first-quarter car production. But Detroit's effort probably won't be enough to create the tens of thousands of new jobs that are associated with an auto boom.

PARIS, Dec. 15 -- William J. Porter, who has been harsh with the Vietnamese Communists ever since he became the chief of the American delegation at the peace talks more than two months ago, was harsh with them again today.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Dec. 15 (AP) -- Defense lawyers said today that the Government had turned over to them a list of 95 possible prosecution witnesses in the coming trial of the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan and sev others on charges of plotting to kidnap Henry Kissinger.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Regulations will be published tomorrow under which Government-paid physicians, dentists and nurses will begin providing health care in city slums and rural areas.

FORT MEADE, Md., Dec. 15 -- Col. Oran K. Henderson was portrayed today as a man who had brought "dishonor, disgrace and humiliation" to the uniform of the United States Army by his alleged concealment of the mass slaying of South Vietnamest civilians by American troops in the hamlet of Mylai 4.
YONKERS, Dec. 15 -- If Rum Customer, a 6-year-old pacer, is to be retired to stud shortly, it will not be as one of harness racing's "millionaires."

PNOMPENH, Cambodia (UPI) Dec. 15 -- Communist forces firing mortar and rocket barrages have cut off some three brigades of Cambodian troops at the forward position of Taing Kauk, 50 miles northeast of Pnompenh, military spokesmen reported today.

BERKELEY, Dec. 15 -- The appointment by the Berkeley City Council of a moderate to its vacant seat, breaking a 4 to 4 deadlock between radicals and moderates, touched off angry criticism yesterday by the radical council members.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Following is the text of the Price Commission's policy regulating charges for health care services during the second phase of the Nixon Administration's economic stabilization program:
" Brooklyn is the only big league town," wrote the droll Eddie Murphy many years ago, "which doesn't have a railroad terminal, a newspaper or a regular left fielder."

Secret Service agents exchanged gunfire with three counterfeiting suspects yesterday as they attempted to complete what one agent described as a "brazen" transfer of a half-million dollars in bogus $10 bills on a Brooklyn street.

Many readers of Senator Margaret Chase Smith's Nov. 20 letter to The Times will be struck by the negativism of her views. She writes that the balance of military power is shifting against this country and that the "enemy," whom she identifies as the Soviet Union, may take over if we let our guard down.

The Offtrack Betting Corporation, shuffling its wares faster than a wheeling-dealing peddler on a street corner, initiated wagering on the superfecta at Monticello Raceway yesterday and today adds Laurel Race Course in Maryland and a nightly television program to its betting line-up.

The double-deck bus -- a New York institution that endowed a ride along Fifth Avenue and Riverside Drive with a special glamour for 46 years until "economics" killed it in 1953 -- may be rolling again on the city's streets within a year.

After threatening to charge as much as $85 a night for the use of school facilities after regular hours, most community school boards have found ways to charge the city's youth organizations little more than they did did last year for such use.

John Kenneth Galbraith yesterday described the Administration's new economic program as the "culminating step in a long but still only dimly perceived" shift to a system in which planning assumes more importance than free - market forces.
John Vesey, the furniture designer and decorator, has been convicted in State Supreme Court in Manhattan of assault in the second degree for severely injuring a 17-year-old boy.
Polite, mild-mannered music-making was provided by the Philadelphia Orchestra at Philharmonic Hall Tuesday night when it played under the direction of a guest conductor, Istvan Kertesz.

LAHORE, Pakistan, Dec. 15 -- This teeming city of 2.3 million in West Pakistan lies 12 miles from the Indian border and war comes to it many times daily. Yesterday, 10 children, 10 women and five men were killed and 28 persons were injured when an Indian bomb hit a suburban railway station.

Following are excerpts from testimony before the Knapp Commission on the second day of its second series of public hearings arising from its inquiry into police corruption here. The commission heard nine days of testimony in October.

By now the ideal Christmas shopper has already stocked up on ties that will never be worn, phials of ether sold as perfume and erector sets with directions written by a Japanese who studied -- briefly -- in our country at U.C.L.A. and apparently majored in black comedy. Once again, the base of the typical American Christmas tree is turning into a white elephant graveyard.
Contributions to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund recorded yesterday ranged from $1 to $1,000, with many donors writing of the special effort they had made to contribute.
ROME, Dec. 15 -- Italy's presidential balloting continued for the seventh day today with two inconclusive rounds of voting by the 1,008-member electoral college.

Rich, unforced and admiring laughter was the background to Nancy Green's concert, "Just Dancing." Tuesday evening at the Cubiculo. Miss Green offered a varied program of solos for the most part choreographed by or for her, in addition to a strikingly good revival of Yvonne Rainer's "Three Satie Spoon."
Bond prices declined and interest rates inched upward yesterday. The heavy supply of new, fixed-income securities being sold this week has proved unappetizing to investors so far.
PHOENIXVILLE, Pa., Dec. 15 (UPI) -- Richard G. Fecteau said today that during his 19 years of imprisonment in China "I was in solitary for so much time I'm not used to conversation."
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 15 -- On a Sunday in May, 1970, northern Peru was rocked by an earthquake that buried entire villages under avalanches. The death toll was 50,000.

PARIS, Dec. 15 -- The builders of the Concorde supersonic airliner today posted a price of $31.2-million for it, a record for a civilian aircraft, and said that the first half-dozen craft would be ready for service by October, 1974.

Directors of the Knight Newspapers, Inc., voted yesterday a two-for-one stock split, subject to shareholder approval of an increase in the authorized shares to 20 million from 10 million. Stockholders will vote on the proposal at the annual meeting April 11.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 15 -- A dispute over the timing of Representative John Dowdy's activities on the day he allegedly accepted a $25,000 bribe centered today on the accuracy of records of votes in the House of Representatives.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 15 -- The Allied Chemical Corporation today demonstrated some major breakthroughs in air-bag technology and its engineers predicted that there was a good chance that they would be used by the auto industry to meet new safety standards in 1976.

DETROIT, Dec. 15 (AP) -- A spokesman for the General Motors Corporation said today that the company had not kept any of the excise tax collected on new cars since President Nixon announced Aug. 15 that he would seek repeal of the levy.
PARIS, Dec. 15 -- Artur Rubinstein was welcomed today to the Academy of Fine Arts, to which he had been elected as an associate foreign member earlier in the year.

ALBANY, Dec. 15 -- Resistance to Governor Rockefeller's "emergency" fiscal program stiffened today within the ranks of his fellow Republicans in the Assembly, as Speaker Perry B. Duryea described the plain as "feathery" and pressed the Governor's office for details.

VIRGINIA BEACH, Va. -- When the soft winds of mid-May touch New England, the first northward migrations of striped bass appear and anglers rejoice, but all too soon, by early November, shorter days and chilling waters have driven the fish offshore and south.

There is genuine tragedy in the idea of a once noted director driven daft and now living disjointedly in the flickering glories of his past, as is indicated by "B. J. Lang Presents," which opened at local theaters yesterday.

CHICAGO -- I am among the few West Pakistanis to have denounced the rigid policies and criminal conduct of our military government. The army intervened in East Bengal to offset the results of Pakistan's first freely held elections, transforming the demand for autonomy into a movement for independence.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 15 -- Pakistan's Foreign Minister, Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, his face streaked with tears, walked out of the Security Council today after accusing it of "legalizing aggression."

Mayor Klaus Schutz of West Berlin spoke candidly when he summed up the intra-German agreements on Berlin as "imperfect in comparison to the ideal, satisfactory in view of the realities." Foremost among the realities was the chronic fear on the part of East Germany's Communist leaders of the impact on the people they rule of greatly expanded contacts with West Berliners and West Germans.

ROME, Dec. 15 -- An authoritative Vatican official declared today that no change could be expected in Peking's basic attitude toward religion and the Roman Catholic Church despite its dialogue with Washington and its membership in the United Nations.

MANCHESTER, Vt., Dec. 15 -- Fred Pabst Jr. has stepped down as president of the Big Bromley ski area. Pabst, former executive vice president of the Pabst Brewing Company, went into the ski business in 1935.
A private City Hall meeting on the controversial bill to require arbitration of labor disputes between the city and some 300,000 unionized employes broke up yesterday without agreement.
The second-highest official in the Police Department appealed to police trainees' wives and fiancees yesterday to try to steer the trainees away from corruption.

NEW DELHI, Dec. 15 -- If the American aircraft carrier Enterprise dares to intervene in the Indian-Pakistani war, a member of the Indian Parliament said today, "the Government should not hesitate to blast it out of the water."

Bernard Gwertzman reports from Washington the attempt of the White House to explain its bungling of efforts to avoid war between India and Pakistan [news story Dec. 8]. White House officials are said to have explained that President Nixon sent two personal messages to India; that Secretary of State Rogers met with the Indian Ambassador eighteen times, and Mr. Kissinger met with the Indian official seven times.

MOSCOW, Dec. 15 -- The Soviet Union today publicly ignored leaked warnings from the White House that continued Soviet encouragement of Indian military actions in East Pakistan could lead to reconsideration of President Nixon's visit to Moscow next May.

John J. Burns, Democratic state chairman, was named national coordinator for the Lindsay '72 Committee yesterday and given the task of drumming up support for the Mayor for the Democratic nomination for President.
PLEIKU, South Vietnam, Dec. 13 -- An American-sponsored program of land reform here is giving far less land than initially intended to the montagnards, the mountain people of Central Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Isn't there anybody left in the United States who feels himself the victim of injustice?

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Dec. 15 -- With the fall of Pakistani forces in East Pakistan seemingly only hours away, Pakistan's central Government here tonight demanded proper treatment by the victorious Indians of prisoners of war and of minority groups.

TBILISI, U.S.S.R. -- In 1839 an anonymous French traveler recorded that this city had 126 tailors, 104 bootmakers, 40 barbers, 4 master goldsmiths, 5 clockmakers, 16 painters and 18 balalaika players, testifying to the Georgian taste for finery and the good life.

The Republic Steel Corporation said yesterday that it would put into effect on Jan. 1 price increases on sheet and strip products that it had originally announced on Aug. 2. However, the price rises on cold rolled sheet products will be held back until Feb. 2.
SESTRIERE, Italy, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Freddy Fuchs of Switzerland, the delegate of the International Ski Federation, today canceled the men's World Cup downhill ski race in Sestriere.

Anyone worried about the future of the American theater should see the new Juilliard Acting Company in action. This company of fourth-year students in the Drama Division at the Juilliard School is presenting (through tomorrow evening) a season of true repertory -- and doing it splendidly.

In a surprise move, Richard O. Kelly, active in the fight for control of Chris-Craft Industries, Inc., resigned yesterday as a member of the independent stockholders committee and withdrew his name as a nominee for director on the anti-management slate.
LONDON, Dec. 15 -- Jordan's Ambassador to Britain, Zaid al-Rifai, was shot and wounded today by a gunman waiting in ambush near a crowded London intersection.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans has accused The Associated Press of a "distorted and dishonest piece of journalism" because of an article disclosing that his private foundation holds an interest in a Thailand paper company that benefits from United States Government assistance.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 15 -- Indian officials said tonight that the commander of Pakistani forces in the besieged city of Dacca had asked for a ceasefire, but that India had demanded a complete surrender of the enemy army in East Pakistan.
DACCA, Pakistan, Dec. 15 -- Pakistan is seeking to negotiate separate terms in the Eastern region so she can continue fighting in the West.

A New York police inspector testified yesterday that he had passed on reports of widespread corruption to the second-highest official in the Police Department eight months before an investigation was begun.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- Optimistic forecasts for business in 1972 prevailed among top business executives taking part today in the annual business outlook luncheon of the First National Bank of Chicago in the Palmer House.

Duke Ellington, back from his tour of the Soviet Union, has moved into the Rainbow Grill for the holidays, bringing with him nine men from his orchestra. The make-up of the group is somewhat unusual -- six saxophones, one trumpet and a rhythm section -- but since it is in the saxophone section that the present Ellington band has its greatest depth and experience, the results are properly Ellingtonian.

WITH INDIAN TROOPS, near Dacca, Dec. 15 -- With Indian troops already looking like a victory column on their march to Dacca, advancing Indian forces are preparing to link up two miles from Dacca for the final thrust on the East Pakistani capital.
VIENNA, Dec. 15 -- Yugoslav Communist leaders asserted today that they had succeeded just in time in curbing a nationalist and secessionist movement in Croatia, the nation's second-largest republic.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -The Defense Department issued a new directive today aimed at improving the nation's worldwide command communications system and making it more responsibe in fast-breaking crisis situations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -Congress apparently broke today the impasse on foreign aid legislation that has been holding up adjournment as the House unexpectedly met Senate demands for a vote on an amendment on Vietnam troop withdrawal.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -Freight traffic on United States railroads during the week ended Dec. 11 was considerably above the volume in the corresponding week of last year. Intercity truck tonnage in the same period also registered an increase.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The United States command announced today that two Americans were killed in action in Vietnam last week, equaling the lowest official weekly toll in nearly seven years.

The principle that you advocate in the recent editorial "Testing Transit Theories" -- that automobile users should subsidize mass transit systems -- is based on the assumption that mass transit's problems are directly attributable to the automobile and its popularity with the American commuter.

Former First Deputy Police Commissioner John F. Walsh admitted in sworn testimony yesterday that he had received a report of widespread police corruption in the Bronx at least six months before any police investigation was begun.
In the menus below, the dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.
WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 16 -The Westchester County Board of Legislators authorized the county today to contract with the state for shipping the county's solid waste upstate for the next 20 years.

Whatever else the evening was, it was a triumph for Leonard Bernstein. The occasion was his 1,000th concert with the New York Philharmonic on Wednesday -- a figure far in excess of any other conductor's in the orchestra's history -- and for about 10 minutes after the conductor's performance of Mahler's "Resurrection" Symphony, the audience went wild.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -Following is the text of a letter dated yesterday, from prime Minister Indira Gandhi, to President Nixon, as issued here today by the Indian Embassy:

The Mead Corporation announced yesterday the election of James W. McSwiney as chairman and chief executive officer. Paul V. Allemang succeeds Mr. McSwiney as president, a position he held since 1968. The company also elected William W. Wommack as vice chairman and as the officer in charge of strategy. Mr. Allemang, like Mr. Wommack, was previously an executive vice president.

FORT MEADE, Md., Dec. 16 -- For almost four months now, Col. Peter Stanislaus Wondolowski, employing a judicious mixture of wisdom, patience and humor, has kept the court-martial of Col. Oran K. Henderson moving steadily toward a verdict.
The stock market's year-end rally for 1971 continued to boom yesterday with glamour issues setting the pace and many blue chips moving up more modestly.
