In order to maintain the orderly liquidation of the December, 1971, wheat futures, the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday limited trading in those futures to liquidation purposes only. They were still deliberating late yesterday afternoon whether to continue the limited trading today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -The nation's financial structure and the Federal agencies that regulate it require a complete overhaul, a Presidential commission has concluded.

HELENA, Mont., Dec. 16 -- A hearing this week before the State Board of Health on a request to lower Montana's strict sulphur emission standards drew a capacity crowd of 450 spectators and witnesses. The majority emphatically opposed the industrysought change.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 16 -- India and Pakistan late being pressed by the International Red Cross to give assurances that they will observe the Geneva conventions.

Seven of the eight teams for the playoffs have been decided and the eighth, Los Angeles or San Francisco, will be determined in their games on Sunday. The 49ers-Detroit contest will be televised here on Channel 2 at 4 P.M.

MILWAUKEE, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Anne Henning of Northbrook, Ill., the woman's world record-holder at 500 meters in speed skating, was clocked in 43.9 seconds in her specialty today as trials opened for the 1972 United States Olympic team.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 16 -- Pakistan's Deputy Prime Minister and Foreign Minister, Zulfikar All Bhutto, declared today that Pakistan should accept a cease-fire with India and should prepare to negotiate a permanent settlement with the insurgents in East Bengal as well as with the Government of India.
A year has passed since the angry workers of Poland's Baltic ports revolted and brought about the replacement of Wladyslaw Gomulka by Edward Gierek. The dividends from that revolt are evident.

NEWARK, Dec. 16 -- The head of a drug rehabilitation program that operated out of the office of Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson was among 55 persons suspected of dealing in narcotics arrested today in a series of raids in the city and seven suburban towns.

Pakistan's Eastern region, seized by India yesterday in support of Bengali secession, is one of the world's most populous, and least prosperous, areas, a vast, humid delta whose more than 70 million inhabitants have a per capita income of only $77 a year.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 16 -- The future of East Pakistan if it becomes an independent country is politically cloudy and economically uncertain.
The American Stock Exchange and the over-thecounter market finished higher yesterday in stepped-up trading.
The exclusive bus lane on the New Jersey approach to the Lincoln Tunnel, a year-long experiment, has been adjudged a success and will become a permanent operation.

The appointment of Fred D. Thompson as general chairman for the 1972 fund campaign of the American Red Cross in Greater New York was announced yesterday by James H. Evans, chairman of the executive board.

CAIRO, Dec. 16 -- The Soviet Ambassador to Egypt, Vladimir M. Vinogradov, stressed in a meeting with Egyptian journalists today that the Soviet Union would back the Egyptians in whatever action they chose to seek recovery of the territory occupied by Israel in 1967.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The House Committee on Public Works delivered a setback to the Nixon Administration today by approving a water pollution control bill that, in its essentials, followed the legislation unanimously passed by the Senate last month.

Mayor Lindsay exchanged perfunctory greetings with Councilman Matthew J. Troy Jr., the Queens Democratic leader, at the annual City Council-City Hall reporters Christmas party last night at Antun's Restaurant in Queens.

Donald Rumsfeld, executive director of the Cost of Living Council, commenting yesterday on a pending case before the Pay Board, said that he "would be surprised" if the contract between the North American Rockwell Corporation and the United Automobile Workers "is approved the way it went in."

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Dec. 16 -- President Agha Mohammad Yahya Khan acknowledged tonight that his forces in East Pakistan had been overwhelmed but pledged to continue the war against India until final victory.

Now is the winter of their discontent, the melancholy days without a thoroughbred running this side of Philadelphia, the cruel times when New York horseplayers are thrown upon the mercy of Howard J. Samuels and his offtrack gambling hells.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 16 -- Following is the text of a statement by the Government of China in a translation issued by its delegation here today. The statement was also distributed from Peking by Hsinhua, the Chinese press agency.

Joe Garagiola, the St. Louis Cardinals baseball catcher turned TV performer, blew his lines taping a television commercial, cursed and, through a technical error, the strong language went on the air yesterday.

Several Jewish organizations declared yesterday that they would not attend a meeting called for today by Mayor Lindsay to discuss the controversial low-income housing project for the Forest Hills section of Queens.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -Five prominent Senators demanded today that the Nixon Administration seek Senate approval of a recent agreement under which economic aid would be given to Portugal in return for continued United States use of military bases in the Azores.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Ed Marinaro of Cornell was named the top college football player of 1971 and the Dallas quarterback, Roger Staubach, was chosen the outstanding pro today by the Maxwell Football Club.

MIAMI, Dec. 16 -- At a meeting in Jacksonville a few days ago, Senator Edmund S. Muskie was told repeatedly that he must spend more time in Florida than he currently plans if he seriously hopes to win the state's March 14 primary.

FORT MEADE, Md., Dec. 16 -- The case of Col. Oran K. Henderson went to a jury of two generals and five colonels this afternoon in the last court-martial to arise from the slaying of South Vietnamese civilians by American troops at Mylai 4.

The Environmental Action Coalition, which organized the first Earth Day here in 1970, announced yesterday a major new recycling program that would more than double the scrap collection centers and for the first time put them where they are really needed.

LONDON -- Here in England most of us, all ages, prefer brown eggs to white eggs. In America, brown eggs are despised, sold off cheaply, perhaps sometimes thrown away. Can any sense be made out of this queer difference in taste I believe it can. But will it take us anywhere? Yes, I believe it will.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (UPI) -- The Pay Board ruled yesterday that a $2-a-week increase in the allowance of a Salvation Army lieutenant would not be inflationary.

SOMEWHERE ON THE BRONX-MANHATTAN BORDER, Dec. 16 -- It may be like slicing up Lilliputia, like splitting the atom -- or hairs -- but some resident of polarized Marble Hill, that tiny enclave of Manhattan surrounded on three sides by the Bronx, are now saying that "partition" is the only solution to their problem.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -Vice President Agnew met secretly in New York yesterday with two leaders of the rightwing Republican group that is searching for a candidate to oppose President Nixon in next year's primary elections.
WASHINGTON, Dec 16 -The United States declared opposition today to moves that might permit members of the Organization of American States to act individually to remove sanctions against Cuba.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -Doctors and hospital officials were generally sympathetic today to the Government's new health care guidelines, but many warned that applying them might be difficult and harmful.

CAIRO -- President Anwar el-Sadat was surely speaking the truth when he told me Soviet Russia did not want to keep substantial military contingents in Egypt and was continuing to maintain a considerable force here only in response to persistent Egyptian "persuasion."

YARDVILLE, N.J., Dec. 16 -An uprising at the State Youth Reception and Correction Center here ended this morning, less than 24 hours after it began, when two hostages were released unharmed by rebelling prisoners.
NEW DELHI, Dec. 16 -- India today ordered a complete cease-fire in the war with Pakistan after seizing Dacca, the East Pakistani capital, and accepting the surrender of Pakistan's forces there.

Sanitation Department officials here believe they are on the way to solving one of their most persistent problems -- the inordinate number of collection trucks awaiting repairs in the department's shops.

ALBANY, Dec. 16 -- Leaders of the Legislature said today that there was little likelihood of action in the new session on a jam of controversial pension bills that were placed in limbo in the last session.

DACCA, Pakistan, Dec. 16 -On a broad grassy field in central Dacca known as the Race Course, the Pakistani forces formally surrendered today, 13 days after the Indian Army began its drive into East Pakistan.

Robert M. Byrn, who proudly says that he is probably New York's No. 1 foe of abortion, is an Irishman with an easy smile who keeps right on smiling even when he hears for the umpteenth time an innuendo-laden description of himself: "A 40-year-old bachelor Catholic law professor."

HERSHEY, Pa., Dec. 16 -- Two Long Island skaters held the lead after the school figures in their respective events as the Eastern figure skating championships began tonight at the Hershey Sports Arena.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -Home building reached a monthly high in November, practically insuring that 1971 will be a record year, George Romney, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, announced today at an odd, hastily called news conference.

GREAT NECK, L. The epidemic of heroin addiction continues to rage unchecked throughout New York City. Despite an aroused citizenry, heightened official vigor and a thorough airing of many of the known (and speculative) aspects of the narcotics problem, little headway seems to have been made.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -State Department officials expressed concern tonight that the Indian-Pakistani war might continue in the West because Pakistan might refuse immediately to abide by the ceasefire declared by India earlier today.
Massachusetts, which has won all its games, and Columbia, loser of its five previous starts, scored victories last night in a college basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company reported yesterday higher operating revenues and earnings for the three and 12 months ended Nov. 30. However, share earnings in the quarter dropped by 1 cent because of the company's initial preferred dividend requirement amounting to $27.5-million.

NEW DELHI. Dec. 16 -- Prime Minister Indira Gandhi has written to President Nixon, in a letter released today, that the war between India and Pakistan could have been avoided if the United States had used its"power, influence and authority" to achieve a political solution to the crisis in East Pakistan.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -Secretary of the Air Force Robert C. Seamans Jr. said today that United States aircraft have observed a build-up of Soviet-made and Chinese-made transport trucks around Hanoi and Haiphong.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -Three conservation groups won today a Federal court order halting a scheduled sale of offshore oil and gas leases in the Gulf of Mexico until further arguments were held on possible environmental damage.

Foreign central banks continued to acquire huge amounts of dollars during the week ended Wednesday as they attempted to arrest the decline of the United States dollar in foreign exchange markets to protect their countries' trade positions.

The International Harvester Company, the world's largest producer of farm equipment and the nation's second biggest manufacturer of trucks, exceeded $3-billion in sales for the first time in its fiscal year ended Oct. 31.

ROME, Dec. 16 -- A continuing deadlock in the 1,008-member electoral college, on the eighth day of its laborious attempts to decide on Italy's sixth president, led today to the cancellation of a scheduled evening ballot and to a flare of temper in a voting session.

Switching Winston Hill from left tackle to right tackle isn't quite as momentous as it would be if the Jets were to make Joe Namath a cornerback. But for Hill the move meant more than simply changing from one side of the line to the other.

Iroquois Industries, Inc., sold 200,000 common shares and stockholders an additional 225,000 in an offering at $20 by an Eastman Dillon, Union Securities underwriting group. The Greenwich, Conn.-based company makes and markets vitamins and health food supplements.

Edmond du Pont, former chairman of F. I. duPont Glore Forgan Co., filed a suit in Federal District Court here yesterday in which he charged that H. Ross Perot and various associate had acted wrong-fully in acquiring control of the large brokerage house.

Country surrealism would resemble the light a painter such as Edward Hopper brought to small-town life.

United Merchants and Manufacturers, Inc., annouced yesterday a restructuring of its domestic textile operations and elected four senior vice presidents to newly created posts. The move follows the retirement from active management as of June 30, 1972 of Sanford S. Agate and Abbot J. Copeland as executive vice presidents.
Daguerreotypes,ambortypes and tintypes are early, one-of-a-kind photographs that appeal to collectors as much for their cases as their subject matter.

KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Dec. 17 -- President Nixon, taking note of "countless" letters from young Americans urging protection of wild horses and burros, signed into law today a bill making it a Federal crime to kill or harass the animals on Federal lands.

SESTRIERE, Italy, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Anne-Marie Proell of Austria captured the Sestriere Alberg-Kandahar downhill ski race today, winning from the strong French team and further increasing her lead in the 1972 women's World Cup.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 17 -- The Bank of England signaled today to the currency markets that the devaluation of the United States dollar would be at least 15.4 per cent when final decisions on a parity realignment were taken, perhaps this weekend in Washington.
CONCORD, N. H., Dec. 17--President Nixon's bid for re-election picked up the support today of New Hampshire's moderate Republican Governor, Walter R. Peterson.
Dating services match up men and women who have marriage in mind. Bernice Lask matches up mothers of young children who would like to exchange baby-sitting chores.

A self-portrait of Detective Sgt. David Durk as a lobbyist and political operative moving through the corridors of power in the Lindsay administration emerged yesterday in his testimoney before the Knapp Commission.

PHILADELPHIA -- In a belated though progressive move, the American Catholic bishops have convened a committee to study the status of women in the church and society. A similar action on the world level was recommended by the Synod of Bishops, just ended in Rome.
HUNTINGTON, W. Va., Dec. 17 -- St. John's opened the fifth annual Marshall University memorial basketball tournament tonight with an 85-75 victory over Rhode Isand before a capacity crowd of 6,500.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 17--Lebanon, expressing concern over the emigration of Soviet Jews to Israel, told a visiting Soviet delegation yesterday that manpower was more serious than weapons in "Israeli expansion and aggression."

Ralph Lazarus, chairman of Federated Department Stores, Inc., which includes Bloomingdale's and Abraham Straus in its nationwide chain, said yesterday that "our Christmas business is running 11 per cent ahead of last year's strong performance."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The United States warned Cuba today that it would take "all measures under international law" to protect American and other ships in the Caribbean from any new attacks by the Cubans.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Dec. 17 (UPI) -- Cambodian positions on Route 6 north of Pnompenh deteriorated today under Communist pressure, according to military sources, who added that high-level delegations of American and South Vietnamese officers had arrived here, apparently to confer on the threat.

Like many other contributors to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, Morris O. Alprin of 122 East 42d Street sent a donation to the fund in place of fancy seasonal greeting cards to friends and relatives.
ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, Dec. 17 -- One of the Croatian region's new Communist leaders charged today that nationalist forces in his republic had wanted to create a situation inviting foreign intervention.

Your Dec. 11 news story reports that a study by Hans Zeisel, Professor of Law at the University of Chicago -- which urges that responsibility for issuing data on crime be transferred from the Federal Bureau of Investigation to an independent agency -- was submitted to the President by the Commission on Federal Statistics.
State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz warned holiday shoppers yesterday against buying leaded foil icicles for decorations because of a potential health hazard to children.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Bob Foster scored a technical knockout over Brian Kelly, a 23-year old Cushing, Okla., youth director, with 1:56 elapsed in the third round tonight to successfully defend his version of the light-heavyweight championship.

MADRID, Saturday, Dec. 18 -- Jose Manuel Ibar (Urtain) the storied stone lifter from the Spanish Basque country, knocked out Jack Bodell of England in the second round this morning to regain the European heavyweight boxing championship and start the legends all over.
WARSAW, Dee. 17 -- Poland's new economic and social reforms are apparently to be accompanied by a sharp tightening of the internal structure of the Communist party.

The overwhelming vote of West Coast longshoremen to reject proffered wage increases that run nearly triple the Pay Board's basic 5.5 per cent guidepost confronts the country with the prospect of a new dock strike after the present eighty-day injunction under the Taft-Hartley Act expires on Christmas Day.

A Queens County grand jury has refused to indict a Queens couple arrested last summer after they allegedly blocked traffic in front of their Springfield Gardens house to prevent cars from going through a large puddle and flooding their basement.

As the last program in its current videotape series, the Whitney Museum presented yesterday and will present again tomorrow a selection of four rather ambitious tapes ranging from 15 to 30 minutes in length.

" To Be Young, Gifted and Black," an adaptation of the stage play depicting the life and career of the late Lorraine Hansberry, will begin the second season of noncommercial television's "N.E.T. Playhouse Biography" series.
MADRID, Dec. 17 -- Ambassador Robert C. Hill of the United States has submitted his resignation and will return home early next month.

Even with the Supreme Court's one-man, one-vote ruling hanging over them, Republican map makers managed to inject a generous amount of politics into the reapportionment of the legislature districts that is scheduled to be approved by the Senate and Assembly today.

RABAT, Morocco, Dec. 17 (UPI) -- Jerry Heard of the United States shot a 71 to grab the lead from Scotland's Bernard Gallacher today in the second round of the $50,000 international Moroccan golf grand prix.
WALTHAM, Mass., Dec. 17 -- Dr. Marver H. Bernstein, a 52-year-old political scientist and Jewish lay leader, was appointed today as president of Brandeis University.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 17 -- Pakistan's Deputy Prime Minister and Foreign Minister, Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, called again today for negotiation between Pakistan and the East Pakistani insurgents, but declined to say whether he would exert his influence to free Sheik Mujibur Rahman, the imprisoned Bengali leader.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 17 -- Jordan tonight formally accused Al Fatah, the main Palestinian guerrilla organization, of responsibility for assassination and sabotage activities.

YONKERS, Dec. 17 -- Forty-seven yearlings will be among the 284 standardbreds auctioned off at the winter segment of the Old Glory Horse Sale at Yonkers Raceway tomorrow. The vendue will start at 10 A.M. and is expected to last about eight hours.

Great artisan that he was, Camille Faure received only modest recognition in his lifetime. Now, 15 years after his death, the revival of Art Deco has uncovered a legacy of his extraordinary enameled objects, assuring him a secure place in art history.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 17 -- In sensational second-half turnabouts, the world champion Aces lost and the Italian Blue team won in the semifinal stage of the Open Knockout Team Championship here today.
BOSTON, Dec. 17 -- Eugene J. McCarthy eased himself into the running for the Democratic Presidential nomination today by announcing his candidacy in the Massachusetts primary April 25.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- New York City's Offtrack Betting Corporation was authorized today to televise live the last horse race each day from tracks with which it had contracts and to give the results and prices paid for all races on which OTB accepted bets.
Pete Athas takes up only one spot on the Giants' decimated roster, but if a severe bronchial infection prevents him from playing against Philadelphia tomorrow, the Giants would be out two players.

The president of a Brooklyn Reform Democratic club said yesterday that high Lindsay administration officials had promised him a Criminal Court judgeship 11 months ago if he lined-up pro-Lindsay delegates to the 1972 Democratic National Conventional.

The arrest of a 22-year-old addict who served as an informant for Sgt. Joseph V. Morabito, the narcotics detective found shot to death in his car in Brooklyn last August, may have provided new leads in the investigation of his murder, the police said last night.

ECHMIADZIN, U.S.S.R. -- A young Armenian couple, bridegroom in a cutaway and bride in a lemon-colored formal gown brought from America by friends, bowed toward each other until their foreheads touched. The best man held an ornate silver cross over them as an elderly blue-robed priest said prayers and, peering over his bifocals, held out a jeweled Bible for each to kiss.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Governor Rockefeller, working for the support of the New York Congressional delegation on a topic close to his heart -- revenue sharing, has agreed to give the Representatives a greater voice in a subject close to their hearts -- reapportionment.

Although most of the Rev. Al Carmines's stage sallies have been secular and, he cheerfully admits, "irreverent,'' a different goal prompted "Christmas Rappings," the oratorio that reopened yesterday at the Judson Memorial Church, where he is associate minister.

Every Christmas for the last 17 years, Mrs. Joseph Low has dusted off the antique cooky mold that hangs in her kitchen and used it to turn out 19-inch-high figures she baked as gifts for special friends.
The holiday season started early this week at the Bitter End with the arrival of a lovely present in the form of a singer, songwriter and explosive new star, Carly Simon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- United States Attorney Robert L. Meyer of Los Angeles resigned today, and reliable sources said one reason was that he disagreed with the Justice Department's decision to prosecute Dr. Daniel Ellsberg.

With the acquittal yesterday of Col. Oran K. Henderson, First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. remains the only man to have been convicted of criminal charges for his role in the attack on the South Vietnamese hamlet of Mylai 4 in March, 1968.

Ben Carnevale, the director of athletics at New York University, his alma mater, will leave that financially troubled institution July 1 to become athletic director of "the well-rounded athletic program" at the College of William and Mary.

Edward M. M. Warburg, active for many years in cultural and educational affairs, has been elected vice director of public affairs at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. He succeeds George Trescher, who has resigned to open his own business, but will continue to serve the museum as consultant.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill Dec. 17 -- The Illinois Supreme Court upheld today the special prosecutor of a grand jury that indicted Edward V. Hanrahan, Cook County State's Attorney, and 13 other law enforcement officers in connection with a 1969 raid on a Black Panther headquarters in Chicago.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17--The first session of the 92d Congress adjourned today after resolving the foreign aid controversy by temporarily extending the current program.
OTTAWA, Dec. 17 (Canadian Press) -- Relations between Britain and Canada will continue as close as ever after Britain joins the European Common Market, Prime Minister Heath said Friday night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The Government filed suit today for the third time under Phase Two of the economic stabilization program, charging a transit system in Cincinnati with illegally raising fares and reducing service.

PEKING, Dec. 17 (Reuters) -- Envoys of the Soviet Union, six Soviet bloc countries and India walked out of a state dinner tonight when Premier Chou En-lai bitterly attacked Moscow's support of Indian "aggression" against Pakistan.

An economic consultant for the Transport Workers Union said yesterday that pay increases of bus and subway workers in the last three years had been wiped out by the rise in the cost of living and that the 30 per cent pay increase that they are now seeking was justified.

WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Dec. 17 (AP) -- Bill Paultz pumped in 27 points and hauled down a team-record 33 rebounds tonight to lead the New York Nets to a 90-83 victory over the Dallas Chaparrals in the American Basketball Association.

HERSHEY, Pa., Dec. 17 -- Skaters from Long Island took championships in the senior men's and junior women's events tonight at the Eastern sectional figure-skating championships at the Hershey Sports Arena.

LUXEMBOURG, Dec. 17 -- One of Luxembourg's top currency experts said today that the world will still need Eurobonds if international monetary stability is fully restored after the devaluation of the dollar.

Bowing to the "insistence" of a City Council committee considering a bill that would bar discrimination against hiring homosexuals, the Lindsay administration yesterday directed the Police, Fire and Correction Department Commissioners or their representatives to testify.

" A Night for Jazz" is what it was called, and the title was well chosen. The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation and the National Steel Corporation yesterday joined others in the industry in putting into effect price increases approved earlier by the Price Commission.

" Who Am I? is a joyful children's "musical fantasy." The book, music and lyrics were written by Seymour Barab. The show was directed by Beatrice Straight and the Young World Foundation is presenting it at Stage 73, the home of the Manhattan Theater Club.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 17 -- The South African Reserve Bank suspended foreign-exchange dealings until further notice today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- National personal income showed a moderate increase in November as the thaw from President Nixon's wage-price freeze began to take effect, the Commerce Department reported today.

Reform Democrats yesterday called on John J. Burns, the state chairman, to postpone the Dec. 28 meeting at which his successor will be chosen. The purpose would be to give the party more time to study the qualifications of candidates.
NEWARK, Dec. 17 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey tested the sentiment of new voters and old-line party leaders today in his second brief political visit to New Jersey in a month.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (Reuters) -- Secretary of State William P. Rogers has begun a new United States effort to bring about an interim peace settlement in the Middle East, the State Department announced today.

NEW DELHI, Dec. 17 -- India marked her triumph quietly today and disclosed that in the two weeks of fighting with Pakistan 2,307 Indians were killed, 6,163 wounded and 2,163 were missing. India also said she had lost 73 tanks and 45 aircraft.

Byron Dyce of the United Athletic Association lowered his best time for the two-mile run by 5.5 seconds last night in a development track meet sponsored by the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union at the 168th Street Armory.
A plainclothes patrolman shot and killed a student on the Brooklyn Center campus of Long Island University yesterday morning when, the police said, he tried to escape arrest on a narcotics charge.

Faced with a demand for business loans that at best can be described as unexciting, a number of major banks across the country reduced their minimum charges on business loans to 5 1/4 per cent from 5 1/2 per cent -- effective immediately in some cases and on Monday in others.
Wall Street kept one eye on the monetary negotiations in Washington yesterday as stock prices forged ahead in heavy trading. Glamour issues continued to pace the market.
The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday that its board of governors had found that Donald D. Jacobson violated exchange rules. It ordered him to resign his membership immediately.

China's long statement on the Indian-Pakistani war just ended betrays more malaise than belligerence, Peking has ample reason to be disturbed by the triumph of Indian arms over Pakistan, which had received strong verbal and some material support from the Chinese.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission wants insurance companies to stick to their traditional accounting methods until a controversy over changing these methods is resolved.

LONDON, Dec. 17 -- When he took office as Prime Minister in June of 1970, Edward Heath was disturbed to find the old pattern of easy two-way communication between Britain and the United States "deteriorated sadly." So he put it six months later in an interview with Joseph Fromm of U. S. News and World Report.
The Atomic Energy Commission is going to take "a much tougher stand" on new applications for nuclear power plants, Wilfred E. Johnson, a member of the commisson, said here yesterday.
BONN, Dec. 17 -- The two Germanys formally signed an agreement today governing access through Communist East German territory to the isolated non-Communist sectors of Berlin.
A 41-year-old Brooklyn detective, who was allegedly being paid off by a gambler, was arrested yesterday, Police Headquarters announced.
KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Dec. 17 -- For the second day in succession, President Nixon slipped away from the Florida White House to go boating in the Atlantic without the knowledge of members of his staff.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The chief representative of Bangladesh in Washington called a news conference today to ask for diplomatic recognition and economic assistance from the United States.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 17 -- A black member of the House of Representative resigned from the United States delegation to the United Nations today to protest what he called the "stifling hypocrisy" of the Nixon Administration's policy toward black Africa.
An alleged associate of Carmine J. Persico pleaded guilty yesterday to two counts of usury in the same reputed loan-sharking scheme for which Persico was recently tried and acquitted.

The Empire Sinfonietta, an enterprising chamber orchestra composed of young but more than ordinarily capable players, gave its second Tully Hall concert of the season Thursday night with Aaron Copland, the composer, as guest conductor.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Finance ministers of the leading industrial nations pursued "snail's pace" negotiations on the world monetary problem late tonight, with no announcement of results.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 17 -- The six member states of the European Economic Community, approving the action of their permanent representatives in Brussels yesterday, formally agreed today to a mandate for immediate trade negotiations with the United States.

Prices of the No. 11 world sugar futures rose the daily limit of 1/2 cent a pound in the principal contracts traded on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday in very active trading that advanced prices to the highest levels since 1964.

NEW DELHI, Dec. 17 -- The Indian Government's press policy during the 15-day war with Pakistan made news itself. For India reversed the restrictive practices she followed in past wars and made a considerable effort to permit and assist war reporting.

It cannot be said that the daily book page has flinched from its duty this season in guiding readers of various tastes to books for Yuletide giving. The uproarious meeting of New York's unionized firemen and the doubt it has cast on ratification of their costly new contract only emphasize the need for City Council adoption of the long-pending bill to make arbitration the last step in municipal labor contracts.

Four public officials who made an unannounced tour of Kings County Hospital after midnight yesterday discovered, among other things, that half the beds in a well-equipped intensive care unit were unoccupied for lack of nurses with the necessary training and that staff members were afraid to walk from one building to the next for fear of being mugged.
SAN JOSE, Calif., Dec. 17 (UPI) -- The two sons of Joseph (Joe Bananas) Bonanno, one-time Mafia leader, were convicted today on Federal charges of extortion and conspiracy.

FORT MEADE, Md., Dec. 17 -- Col. Oran K. Henderson, the infantry brigade commander whose troops shot down more than 100 civilians in the South Vietnamese hamlet of Mylai 4 in March, 1968, was acquitted today of charges that he had covered up the killings by an inadequate investigation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Judge George H. Boldt, chairman of the Pay Board, announced today that the board would limit increases in executive compensation, including salaries and benefits, to the same 5.5 per cent guideline that it has applied to wage-earners in general.

SEATTLE, Dec. 17 -- Preparing dinner is a simple matter these days for Patricia Vick. To feed her husband, Dale, and their three children, Robert, 10, Rita, 7 and Connie, 6, Mrs. Vick merely opens three cans of vegetables. That is all there is most nights.

James F. Ahern, the former Police Chief of New Haven who served on the President's Commission on Campus Unrest, is being considered for the post of Corrections Commissioner in New York, Mayor Lindsay's office said yesterday.

PARIS, Dec. 21 -- Most of the world's currency markets reopened today and immediately bore out expectations that the dollar would hold up firmly after the general realignment that was set last Saturday in Washington.

Members of the New York Society of Security Analysts were told yesterday that the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation paid down about $30-million of its ong-term debt in the current quarter -- bringing its total repayments to over $100-million in the last two years.

Duane Thomas fumbled on the goal line, an error that cost the Dallas Cowboys a touchdown and possibly victory in last January's Super Bowl game won by Baltimore, 16-13. Thomas has never been quite the same, although once more he will be a key figure in the playoffs leading to the Super Bowl.
Could such an honest fellow as George Washington ever dabble in sexual dalliance? As Sam Dann, the author of "Sally, George and Martha" sees George, he could -- and did.
Thirteen persons abandoned a sinking Norwegian freighter in the Atlantic Ocean yesterday and were rescued by the British vessel Suevic, which spotted them in a lifeboat, the Coast Guard said.
A key proposal in William McChesney Martin Jr.'s report on the securities markets has aroused deep-seated controversy in Wall Street and may be modified by the New York Stock Exchange.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 21 -- Cary Grant is listed in the Los Angeles telephone directory. But if you want to speak to the actor, that is not the number to call. Cary Grant's private number is not listed. And the Cary Grant who is in the book has had his listed number disconnected.
A system of block superintendents, or "super-supers," was proposed yesterday by the city as a way to cut down on dirty streets and building decay.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 21 -- George Bush, the United States delegate, was reported today to be urging Secretary General Thant to reconsider the expulsion of the two Chinese Nationalist correspondents who had worked at the United Nations.

The Equitable Savings Loan Association marketed 901,621 capital shares, all but 50,000 on behalf of the GAC Corporation, its principal stockholder, at a price of $27. Kidder, Peabody and Salomon Brothers were managers.

PORT ISABEL, Tex., Dec. 21 (UPI) -- Two crewmen aboard a commandeered shrimp boat regained control of the vessel at sea as she was being hijacked to Mexico today. In an exchange of gunshots that ensued, two of the hijackers were killed and the leg of a woman companion was shattered.
The city's direct-lease day-care program, started three years ago as a crash program to build more day-care centers, has been criticized in a report by the Department of Investigation.

At a Federal Bar Association luncheon in Washington honoring Lewis F. Powell Jr. and William H. Rehnquist, who will become Supreme Court Justices Jan. 7, Attorney General John N. Mitchell predicted that the two "will prove to be eminently unpredictable" in their court decisions.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Dec. 21 (Reuters) -- The South African Government devalued the rand today by 12.28 per cent in terms of gold, which immediately set off a burst of new activity on the long-depressed Johannesburg stock exchange.
A 72-year-old man who lives alone on, the Upper West Side and who had been the victim of both a mugging and a robbery within the last two years bought a pistol two months ago to protect himself.

Dr. Mason W. Gross, former president of Rutgers University, has been elected president of the Harry Frank Guggenheim Foundation, Peter O. Lawson-Johnston, chairman of the board of directors, announced yesterday.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Dec. 22 -- The United States command confirmed this morning that one and possibly two of the four Air Force fighter-bombers shot down or lost over the weekend crashed inside North Vietnam east of Hanoi, while evading North Vietnamese MIG's that shot down another jet over Laos.

Bobby Short, the coal miner's son from Danville, Ill., who grew up to become the darling of the powerful and the playful, was feted by his friends at a "New York in the Thirties" dance Monday night, and nobody had a better time than Bobby did.

Civil rights leaders, headed by Roy Wilkins, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, met yesterday with Mayor Lindsay at City Hall to support him in his determination to build a low-income housing project in the middle-class community of Forest Hills, Queens.

EAST LONDON, South Africa Dec. 21 (AP) -- Mike Kriess of Bel Air, Calif., and Tom Edelfsen of Los Angeles advanced to the fourth round of the Free State Sugar tennis championships today, while Sally Walsh of San Rafael, Calif., gained the third round of the women's singles event.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Two airlines serving Hawaii, United and Western, Proposed today to discontinue group fares in the California-Hawaii markets on Feb. 1.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- A leading medical journal advises the politician who has heart disease that he should probably relax his grip on the cocktail glass and on his constituent's hand.

Milton Cross is appearing in a rerun that may hold the long-distance record.

For many who are mildly allergic to change, the Salvation Army troops at their kettles and the sad-eyed Santa Clauses with their flossy beards are symbols hot so much of Christmas as of the remembered possibility that life in this city can be predictable a n d ordered.

VINELAND, N. J., Dec. 22 -- Tomorrow, Thomas Mazzola says, he will take down the "Mazzola's Tailor Shop" sign, but that is the only definite plan he has made since learning that he and his wife had won $1-million in New Jersey's State Lottery today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- A majority of the 15-man Pay Board has determined that wage settlements in the aerospace industry must be cut back, board sources disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The Price Commission issued new rent regulations today and said that tenants whose units were not covered by state or local controls would probably pay 3 to 3.5 per cent a year more.

State Senator Martin J. Knorr, a Queens Republican-Conservative, said last night that he would submit legislation next year to require the State Urban Development Corporation to build a school or a middle-income housing project on the Forest Hills site now scheduled to be used for 840 units of low-income housing.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -The Price Commission today imposed on the nation's insurance companies restraints that are designed to force substantial cuts in some of the factors used to justify premium increases.
Three officials of the city's emergency housing-repair program--including the No. 2 man--were dismissed yesterday because of charges involving "improper financial transactions" with contractors.

The honorable and slightly anachronistic enterprise of the Don Siegel cops-and-crooks action movies over the last few years ("Madigan," "Coogan's Bluff") takes a sad and perhaps inevitable step downward in "Dirty Harry," which opened yesterday at the Loew's State 2 and Loew's Orpheum theaters.

There was a time when speculation about Yugoslavia's future centered around the question whether a unified country could survive the passing of President Tito. But even though he is still very much alive, the survival of a unified Yugoslavia today is in more serious doubt than at any time since World War II.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Dec. 22 (Reuters) -- Sheik Mujibur Rahman, hero of the East Pakistani secessionist movement, was released from a West Pakistani prison today and placed under house arrest at an undisclosed place.

I read with interest Jack Chen's "The Lin Piao Mystery" (Op-Ed Dec. 3), that is, the disappearance of Lin Piao and a few others from the public scene. I agree with him that this by no means indicates that "China is coming apart at the seams under the stress of a power struggle. . . ."

SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 22 -- The Cabinet decided tonight to increase the value of the Australian dollar against the United States dollar by 6.32 per cent. Since some of Australia's major trading partners have increased the value of their currencies by an even greater amount, the net result for Australia's dollar is an effective devaluation of 2.25 per cent as viewed against the background of her over-all trade.
Eighteen - year - old Sharon had just come from an angry shouting match with her history teacher, and she was upset. There was no doubt about that.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 22 -- Kurt Waldheim, the Austrian career diplomat newly elected as Secretary General, and U Thant, retiring after 10 years, today underscored the political crises and desperate financial condition confronting the United Nations as the 132 members ended the 26th General Assembly session.
Two impressive works, helpful to both the amateur fancier and the professional breeder, have made their appearances recently on the book marts.
PARIS, Dec. 22 -- The North Vietnamese and Vietcong delegations at the peace talks here announced today their acceptance of an American proposal to hold the next plenary session Dec. 30.

An interesting extension of a well - known bidding device has been developed by some of the younger New York experts. The idea is to designate a jump response of three hearts or three spades after a one no-trump opening as a "splinter," promising at most a singleton in the suit.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Lionel Trilling of Columbia University, the writer and teacher, was named today to give the first of the yearly Jefferson Lectures in the Humanities, which carries an award of $10,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (UPI) -- The White House said today that the third year of Richard Nixon's Presidency had produced such "large conceptions, daring innovation and substantial progress" that the Democrats in Congress would find that the best way to get re-elected was to support Nixon programs.

The chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, Secor D. Browne, predicted yesterday that the nation's major airlines, which went into a disastrous slump in 1970, would make a before-tax profit of $325-million to $350-million in 1972.

On a cold gray December afternoon with at least 70,000 Browns' fans in the stands, the craggy old Cleveland Municipal Stadium has a quality all its own. John Unitas will remember. On such an afternoon in 1964 the Unitas team, the Baltimore Colts, inexplicably lost the National Football League championship to the Browns, 27-0, in a major upset.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Dec. 22 -- The Christmas season this year is melancholy in Belfast. The pubs open -- at 11:30 A.M. -- and the men drink beer sullenly.

PARIS, Dec. 22 -- As the exchange markets slid into pre-Christmas doldrums, specialists of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development struck a note of caution today about the impact of the weekend currency realignment on the United States.

CHARLOTTE, N. C., Dec. 22 (AP) -- The president of the American Society of Newspaper Editors, in a telegram to Secretary General Thant, has protested the withdrawal of the accreditation of two Chinese Nationalist correspondents at the United Nations.

FRANKFURT, West Germany, Dec. 22 (UPI) -- Pan American World Airways today announced a special reduced fare package on trans-Atlantic air travel for United States military personnel based in Britain and West Germany.

Firemen could earn up to an extra $500 a year in overtime under a provision of the proposed contract between the city and the Uniformed Firefighters Association, according to Herbert Haber, the city's Labor Relations Director.

CALCUTTA, India, Dec. 22 -- Helped by Indian advisers here in Calcutta, the provisional Bengali government for East Pakistan has prepared a program of action for the reconstruction of the war-ravaged state.

ICM Realty raised an indicated $23-million with the sale yesterday through a Loeb, Rhoades Co. group of one million shares of beneficial interest. This was the real-estate investment trust's initial public offering. It specializes in equity investments.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22--"For several years," writes a man in Chicago, "I tried unsuccessfully to solve my identity crisis through psychiatry and finally gave it up, not because it was excessively expensive--which it was-- but because it took too much out of me. Lying around on a couch, I mean, wondering who in the world I was.
Cardinal Cooke, Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York, left last night for his annual visit with American servicemen in Southeast Asia, and on the way will visit Israel and the Near East.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 22 -- The American air war over Indochina has taken a serious turn in recent months. The situation became dramatically apparent last weekend with the loss of four planes -- but the news came first from Hanoi, not Saigon or Washington.

The Bankers Trust Company announced yesterday that four senior executives will assume new responsibilities beginning Dec. 31. Chester Baylis Jr., who has been chairman of the executive committee, will become chairman of the executive committee of Bankers Trust New York Corporation, the bank's parent company. John W. Hannon Jr. was elected executive vice president and a member of the office of the chairman.

" A Murrow Retrospective," a week-long look at Edward R. Murrow, the late television journalist, and his crusading documentaries, will be televised on Channel 13 nightly from Jan. 3 through Jan. 7. In addition, the entire program will be repeated on Saturday, Jan. 8, from 3:30 to 8 P.M.

Three Canadian fugitives, including one wanted for murder and another classified in Montreal as among the 10-most-wanted criminals, were arrested in a Queens apartment last night by state troopers and New York City policemen.

Sandra Warfield, a mezzo-soprano who was a member of the Metropolitan Opera from 1953 to 1957 before leaving it for several years, is back with it again now and on Tuesday night took over the role of Dalila for the first time in the company's production of Saint-Saens's "Samson et Dalila."

BONN, Dec. 22 -- West Germany's Bundesbank, or central bank, today lowered its bank rate to 4 per cent from 4 1/2 per cent in a determined effort to help West German industry adapt to the mark's higher value. The new rate will take force tomorrow.

GROSSINGER, N. Y., Dec. 22 -- In a departure from its usual practice, the B'nai B'rith Hillel Foundation has begun to recruit nonrabbinical personnel to cope with the needs of a Jewish campus generation "grown massive and diverse."

MOSCOW, Dec. 22 -- Pravda, the authoritative Communist party newspaper, charged today that China had given the United States "a green light for the expansion of aggression in South Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia" by bringing her foreign-policy positions into line with Washington on a number of other issues.

Democratic leaders of the Legislature insisted yesterday that despite their party's caustic division last week over reapportionment its members would be able to bargain as a unit next week should the Republican majority leadership have to turn to them for fiscal votes.
The Transit Authority emphasized in labor negotiations yesterday its desire to work with its unions to improve productivity and over-all performance.

Two Dec. 12 articles provide an interesting perspective on "participative decision-making" as a solution for controversial social problems. In the first, The Times reports that a group of engineers and environmentalists has concluded that there is a "crying need" for such decision-making in the siting of electric power plants to assure minimum adverse environmental impact.

TRENTON, Dec. 22 -- The New Jersey Supreme Court set limits today on the fees lawyers may charge under contingency arrangements, ending a freemarket system that has seen some attorneys collect as much as half of a client's $100,000 settlement.

MADRID, Dec. 22 -- The major claim of the leadership of Generalisimo Francisco Franco -- that it has given peace to Spain -- has been bitterly contested by an official document drawn by the Spanish Bishops Committee on Peace and Justice.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Most Christmas yearend bonuses will not be covered by the wage and salary guidelines if the employer has given the bonuses previously, the Internal Revenue Service said today.

The Knapp Commission has been painting an unsavory picture of police corruption in New York City, and of police and civil administrations that failed to act as vigorously and as promptly as they should have to clean up the mess. Undoubtedly, as the detailed testimony shows, there is a lot of truth in this picture.
COLUMBUS, Miss. -- When schools were integrated in Utica, Miss., last year, Mrs. Mildred M. Gettis, like hundreds of other black educators around the South, began to worry about her job.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 22 (Reuters) -- The United States and the Common Market today ended their first round of negotiations on trade restrictions with little change in opposing positions, informed sources said.

Kirk Kerkorian, the West Coast financier, announced yesterday he would seek to purchase, within the next few days, 240,000 shares of the common stock of Metro-Gold-wyn-Mayer, Inc., through a tender offer at $19 a share.

Judging by the words of its leadership, the Direct Mail Advertising Association is making progress in eliminating three areas of consumer complaint -- unwanted mail, pornography and advertisers who don't produce as promised.

CAIRO, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Harvard University's eight-man crew beat Yale, Oxford, Cambridge and Egypt again today on the Nile River.

SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 22 -- Opposition legislators began a sit-in in the National Assembly chamber today in a desperate attempt to prevent passage of a controversial bill that would give President Park Chung Hee special emergency powers.
SEATTLE, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Walt Frazier's 28 points paced the New York Knicks to an easy 120-104 victory over the Seattle SuperSonics tonight in the National Basketball Association.

Public broadcasting, which since 1951 has been struggling to become established and now has 214 stations, faces the new year with serious problems. The Administration of President Nixon is opposed to the establishment of a fourth "national network" with Federal funds and next year's financing of non commercial television probably will not be determined until February.
A young Bronx bride, Mrs. Miriam Mitzner, offered her wedding gifts yesterday as a reward to anyone who would bring to justice the murderers of her shopkeeper father, Izzy Pacht.

Mayor Lindsay attacked yesterday the "petty piranhas of the political marketplace" who have tried to interfere with what he described as his long battle to establish the principle of civilian control of the police.
ROME, Dec. 22 -- Wild shouting and scuffling, held in check by burly Chamber of Deputies attendants, all but broke up the 21st round of voting for the next president of Italy tonight.

State Supreme Court Justice Mitchell D. Schweitzer announced yesterday that he was retiring from the bench as of Jan. 24 -- the day the Court on the Judiciary was to have begun its hearing into his fitness as a judge -- to avoid the "stress and strain" that the hearing would have caused him.

DETROIT, Dec. 23 -- New-car sales continued to be slow during the Dec. 11-to-20 period, but the auto industry will still break the record sales for the year set in 1968.
SAIGON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- The Vietcong's three-day Christmas cease-fire went into effect at 1 A.M. today (noon, Thursday, New York time), but it was not expected to lessen hostilities in South Vietnam.

HOUSTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Bill Peterson said tonight he had accepted an "almost lifetime" contract to become head coach of the Houston Oilers of the National Football League on the condition that he would be released from the remaining four year of his contract with Rice University.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Dec. 23 (UPI) -- James R. Hoffa beamed and waved to his former fellow inmates as he left the penitentiary today.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 23 (UPI) -The police said today that a suspect had admitted that he got into an altercation with John E. Fitzpatrick while they were standing in line with their children to visit Santa Claus but he denied that he had stabbed Mr. Fitzpatrick.

The Federal Reserve extended credit to Government securities dealers yesterday at 3 3/4 per cent -- some three-quarters of a percentage point below the discount rate -- and so other interest rates came tumbling down in a performance in the credit markets that had been expected to be a sleepy pre-holiday one.

MOSCOW, Dec. 23 -- Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, the Nobel laureate in literature for 1970, has proposed that he receive his Nobel medal and be given a chance to deliver his Nobel lecture at a small, open ceremoney at the Swedish Embassy here.

TEL AVIV, Dec. 23 (Reuters) -- Boris L. Kochubiyevsky, a Soviet electronics engineer who served in a labor camp after protesting against Moscow's anti-Israeli policy, arrived today as an immigrant.

The Grand Union Company, which operates 571 retail food outlets, yesterday reported lower earnings in the third fiscal quarter and nine months ended Nov. 27, but achieved record sales in both periods, according to Charles G. Rodman chairman.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Dec. 23 (AP) -Nationalist China's ruling party, the Kuomintang, has decided to hold the firest national elections since 1947, but details will not be decided until after President Nixon visits mainland China in February, party officials reported today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -President Nixon signed today a bill extending for six months the Government's authority to fix an interest rate higher than 6 per cent on Federal Housing Administration and Veterans Administration loans.

John J. Maloney Jr. was elected yesterday president of Thomson McKinnon Auchincloss, Inc., succeeding William E. Ferguson, who was made chairman and continues as chief executive officer. Mr. Maloney was previously an executive vice president. James C. Barnes, Roger Cortesi and J. Ronald Morgan were named executive vice president.

City Councilman Carter Burden criticized Herbert L. Haber, Director of Labor Relations for the city, yesterday for "piecemeal leaking" of contract terms between the city and the fire and sanitation unions.

Assemblyman Antonio G. Olivieri, Democrate-Liberal of Manhattan, announced yesterday the formation of the Citizens Committee for No-Fault Automobile Insurance and plans to introduce his own no-fault insurance bill in the Legislature.
LOCKPORT, N. Y., Dec. 23 -- A 36-year-old man convicted of resisting arrest was ordered by a judge yesterday to tip his hat to every policeman he meets for the next three years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -Senator George McGovern proposed today that every American, regardless of other income, receive a monthly payment from the Government.
The Georgia-Pacific Corporation said yesterday it would increase the price of gypsum wallboard by an average of about $2 per thousand square feet, effective in late January.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -The Federal Communications Commission said today that it was dropping an investigation of the rates charged by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company for interstate long-distance telephone calls because it did not have adequate staff or resources.
The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation confirmed yesterday reports that it intended to make sharp cutbacks in the work force in parts of its Pittsburgh works.
HONG KONG, Dec. 23 -- China is keeping her currency at parity with the pound sterling and the Hong Kong dollar, thereby upvaluing the jenminpi in terms of the United States dollar.

The Columbia Broadcasting System completed arrangements yesterday to phase out the processing operations of its electronic video recording and concentrate eventually on program production. MANILA, Dec. 23 -- At the top of the escalator in the central department store on Bangkok's Silom Street a large, artificial snowman greets shoppers with a jaggedly sketched smile. The Offtrack Betting Corporation presented a check for $1-million to Mayor Lindsay yesterday, reducing the balance still owed the city to $1.2-million.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Administration officials reported today that the Soviet Union in the last few weeks has made several proposals ,toward resolving differences at the talks on limitation of strategic arms.
MIAMI, Dec. 21 -- His name is hardly a household word outside his own state, but Reubin Askew, Governor of Florida, is a man Democrats will be watching in 1972.

Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy dispensed Christmas largess to 100 members of the force yesterday by announcing he would grant amnesty to those facing departmental trials not involving corruption or other criminal offenses.

Alex Webster yesterday discharged Norb Hecker, his No. 1 assistant and the defensive coach of the Giants for the last three seasons. Webster, the head coach, described the dismissal as "a question of differences in coaching philosophy."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans said today that available data indicated that retail sales in the Christmas season would be 8 to 9 per cent higher in real volume than a year ago, the largest increase since 1966.
Daniel J. Pressman, president of Prestex, Inc., a textile concern at 245 Fifth Avenue, died yesterday at his home in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. He was 53 years old.

RAWALPINDI, Dec. 23 -- President Bhutto continued a purge of high-ranking military officers today, retiring the commander of the navy, five other ranking naval officers and three army major generals.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today that United States warplanes would continue their strikes against enemy positions in Laos and Cambodia during 1972 to blunt the new North Vietnamese offensives in those areas.
An American cargo ship and a Russian fishing trawler collided last night 26 miles off New Jersey, the Coast Guard reported.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -Donald Rumsfeld, Executive Director of the Cost of Living Council, said this morning that the United States Postal Service could not raise rates until the council agreed that they met certain anti-inflation standards.

A State Supreme Court justice yesterday issued a temporary restraining order barring the Democratic State Committee from meeting next Tuesday to elect a successor to John J. Burns, whose resignation as state chairman becomes effective that day.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- President Nixon signed today a bill to implement a much-expanded research attack on cancer, saying it might prove to be the most significant act of his Presidency.

In the country's largest city, the 1971 Christmas selling season is winding up today with strong gains by major department stores over last year. For the opera mixes children's tunes with a rich Wagnerian-style orchestration and a fairy tale that is by turn charming, saccharine and funny.

1982--We were such newlyweds we counted Christmas day as our four-month anniversary. My husband had just begun Medical School. We didn't buy a tree (saving money) until at ten that night.
