Remember how everyone got excited about the Alaskan North Slope when it turned out that there was lots and lots of oil up there? Everyone heard that the Atlantic Richfield Company would be one of the biggest winners and the company stock took off like gangbusters.
The money and capital markets, encouraged by Federal Reserve moves, continued to sweep toward lower interest rates yesterday in relatively light post-holiday activity.
Lazard Freres Co. has formally appealed to the Supreme Court to reverse a lower court decision that has sent shock waves through the mutual-fund industry.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27 -- To reduce the "dehumanizing" effects of modern factory life, it was reported here today, two Swedish automobile makers, Volvo and Saab, have begun to eliminate that pillar of mass production, the assembly line.

GENEVA, Dec. 27 -- A spokesman for the International Committee of the Red Cross said today that its representatives in Dacca would try to obtain good treatment for former East Pakistani officials who have been turned over to the Bangladesh regime by the Indian Army.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 27 -- Andrew F. Brimmer, a member of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System, said today that it would be "extremely risky" for the Federal Reserve to base its policy decisions and actions on any single objective -- the money supply or any other.
ZURICH Switzerland, Dec. 27 -- Muhammad Ali said farewell to the hills and mountains of Switzerland today, saying he was "seriously" thinking of returning here to train for his next fight.

A Federal court has ruled that a hospital can be held liable for proved damages for pain and suffering and for violation of constitutional rights caused by refusal to perform a sterilization operation on a woman.

The Accounting Principles Board published yesterday the text of a proposed ruling that will allow many multinational corporations to postpone recognition of profits or losses resulting from the devaluation of the dollar.
RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Dec. 27 -- President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto said tonight that he had met with Sheik Mujibur Rahman, the detained leader of East Pakistan's Bengali separatists.

The name of Ebenezer Scrooge does not appear on the roster of any team in the National Football League. Nor is it listed on any tabulation of front-office hierarchy, including the top command post on Park Avenue. But it almost seemed over the weekend as if pro football had reached all the way into Charles Dickens's touching "Christmas Carol" to capture the spirit of Ebenezer Scrooge. He despised everything about Christmas.
The city earned $2.6-million interest in the last 14 months on payroll deductions of city employes held by banks in trust funds, Controller Abraham D. Beame said yesterday.

The Cerro Corporation announced yesterday it had signed an agreement giving it the initial option to buy 2.91 million shares of the Behring Corporation's common stock, or about 55 per cent of Behring's shares outstanding.

Of the four teams that lost in the division playoffs last weekend, the Minnesota Vikings need the most profound pondering of their position. Perhaps what the Vikings need also is Francis Asbury Tarkenton -- the return of the prodigal one to the land of 10,000 lakes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- A Soviet intelligence agent who defected to the United States in October returned to the Soviet Union last night after eluding his American escorting officer, the State Department announced today.
COLOGNE, West Germany, Dec. 27 (UPI) -- Three men armed with submachine guns robbed a bank of some $96,700 today and fled with two police officials who had volunteered themselves as hostages.
A police inspector, a deputy inspector, a captain and two lieutenants were cleared yesterday of charges that they had failed to take action against an illegal Harlem bottle club.

A prominent Wall Street bond specialist, asked to comment recently on the financing of the New York City Transit Authority, said: "The Mad Hatter and Mr. Micawber, working together, could never dream up anything as strange."
HONG KONG, Dec. 27 -- China today charged new intrusions by Indian forces into Tibet and lodged a strong protest with the Indian Government.

American Export Isbrandtsen Lines has complained to the Federal Martime Commission that the rates a major competitor has filed to carry United States military cargo on the Atlantic are so low as to be "predatory."

The city's Housing Authority contended yesterday that on the basis of official crime index statistics for the city in the first six months of 1971, the crime rate in public housing projects was "invariably lower than [in] the surrounding neighborhoods."
Channel 13 TV televised Sgt. David Durk's appearance before the Knapp Commission on Dec. 17.

LARCHMONT, N.Y. -- The lovely picture-book harbor here has become a battleground between 115 residents who live on the waterfront and duck hunters who blast away with shotguns from a small, rocky island less than 1,000 feet from shore.
CAIRO, Dec. 27 (Reuters) -- Delegates of 18 Arab countries held intensive discussions today in an attempt to coordinate military and economic strategy against Israel.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 27 -- Testimony in the bribery-conspiracy trial of Representative John Dowdy ended today in United States District Court, where the defendant's principal accuser denied that he once bragged of falsifying evidence against the Texas Democrat.
ALBANY, Dec. 27 -- State legislators arrived here today seemingly more concerned whether they would be home for New Year's Eve than whether the state's fiscal problems would be solved this week.

In publishing a poem by Allen Ginsberg ["On Jessore Road" Op-Ed Dec. 17] you saw fit not to print in full a generally known four-letter word describing human excrement used three times by the poet within a context which not only justified its use but dramatically heightened the harrowing sense of human suffering the poem endeavored to express.

Vietnam veterans barricaded inside the Statue of Liberty yesterday rejected a Government compromise designed to reopen the historic monument to the public while allowing the veterans to continue their antiwar protest.

Unable to win its four previous games, St. Peter's came into the 20th annual Holiday Festival in Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon as everybody's underdog, and turned into a dark horse by upsetting Duke, 77-74.
On the first shopping day after Christmas, the big stores in New York were almost as jammed as the days before Christmas -- only there was a bit of a difference.

The legacy of the blustery Michael J. Quill, who died a few weeks after the 1966 subway strike, is the nonsensical tradition that transit union negotiations must always wind up in a New Year's Day cliffhanger. That threadbare scenario is being played out again this week, even though Mr. Quill's successor as head of the Transport Workers Union, Matthew Guinan, is an eminently practical man with neither flare nor appetite for melodramatics.
NEW DELHI, Dec. 27 -- The Indian Government said tonight that it would consider the holding of war-crimes trials of Pakistani military personnel charged with "heinous crimes" in East Pakistan.

The Horace Mann School and the Barnard School for Boys, both old-established private day schools with adjoining campuses in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, are planning a merger that would eventually produce a coeducational institution with grades from nursery through high school.
DUBLIN -- Two years after Ireland became the first country to exempt artists from income taxes, a total of 262 writers, painters and composers have found a haven with uncertain blessings.

KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Dec. 27 (UPI) -- An advance team of White House aides and technicians, including the Presidential press secretary, Ronald L. Ziegler, will leave for Peking on Wednesday to prepare for President Nixon's planned Feb. 21-28 visit, the Columbia Broadcasting System said today. The Florida White House refused to confirm or deny the report.

A foreign observer often has more understanding of the reasons why the people of a land do certain things than a native does. J. B. Priestley, then, may be right when he suggests why Americans prefer white eggs.
Soviet spacecraft have discovered the presence of hydrogen and oxygen atoms in the upper atmosphere of Mars, according to a report from Tass, the Soviet press agency.
Earnings of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc., in the first fiscal quarter of 1972 were the highest for the period since 1967, the company said yesterday at its Culver City, Calif., headquarters.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Representative Wright Patman, chairman of the House Banking Committee, has written President Nixon that a finding of no present necessity for interest controls does not meet the requirements of the law extending Presidential economic authority.

Pointing to "serious Health Code violations" in the Peking Restaurant, considered one of the best Chinese restaurants in the city, the Health Department threatened yesterday to close the eating place unless the infractions are corrected by Jan. 17.

Many current transit proposals are essentially for borrowing from next year's revenues to cover this year's operating deficits. As tight as the current budget may be, there is little hope that the big problem next year will be what to do with all the surplus money.

The Public Service Commission said yesterday that it had assigned eight additional staff members to its New York office to help Consolidated Edison resolve a mushrooming number of consumer complaints about overcharging.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The deficit in the nation's balance of trade showed a sharp improvement in November but the figures continued to be distorted by dock strikes, the Commerce Department reported today.

During the holiday season New York parents and children have usually been able to exult in the imaginative theatricalities of the Paper Bag Players. But this Christmas "The Bags" are not in residence in their home city. Instead, they are playing the Young Vic, the experimental wing of Britain's National Theater.
A year ago last October, Robert T. Kesner at the age of 55 gave up the world of advertising and marketing which had him commuting to New York every day, to stay home and become a newspaper publisher.

MIAMI, Dec. 27 -- When Coach Paul (Bear) Bryant phoned John Mitchell Jr. person to person and invited him to visit the University of Alabama as a football prospect earlier this year, Mitchell was flattered, but not awed.
The General Electric Company announced yesterday that it will raise prices by an average of less than 2 per cent on most General Electric and Hotpoint major appliances, beginning Jan. 1.

ALBANY, Dec. 27 -- About 25 years ago Dr. Thomas Norman Hurd, then a subaltern in Thomas E. Dewey's administration, was working late in the Capitol on a complicated farm labor-food shortage problem when he thought he smelled a gas leak.
JERUSALEM, Dec. 27 (UPI) -- The Jerusalem Post said today that the wife of the Defense Minister, Moshe Dayan, has begun divorce proceedings after 36 years of marriage.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The Customs Bureau of the Department of the Treasury said today that it had achieved notable success in 1971 against the smuggling of heroin and other dangerous drugs.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird said today there would be no draft calls in January and perhaps none until April. Two military pay increases totaling $3-billion a year, Mr. Laird said, are expected to lead to increased enlistments and decreased departures from the active duty forces.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 27 (UPI) -- At least five persons, all white, were injured today when a crowed of about 400 blacks battled the police and motorists for about an hour in an incident apparently ignited by pranksters.

PARIS, Dec. 27 -- Even after a currency realignment that has made acquisitions with dollars about 10 per cent more expensive, international American companies still are looking fondly at expansion in Western Europe.

Two small items reported recently on the inside pages of The Times raise an issue that bears close watching. The first reported that porpoises are being taught to assist scuba divers; the second ("Porpoise Is Found Ulcers Prone, Too") that the cross-infectivity of man and porpoise with one another's diseases is under investigation.

One of the world's largest and most comprehensive collections of science and technology materials -- 750,000 books and documents, none of them duplicates -- is scheduled to be closed to all users after Friday by the New York Public Library.
American Telephone rang the bell with a solid gain yesterday and several leading glamour issues soared to record prices as the stock market generally continued to consolidate its recent big advance.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27 -- A Harvard survey of public attitudes toward First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. has found that two-thirds of those questioned said that most people would shoot unarmed civilians if ordered to do so.

Police Department officials said informally yesterday that the department's public morals administrative division had set about systematically collecting information on individual prostitutes and their pimps in an effort to combat major crimes associated with prostitution.
PALO ALTO, Calif., Dec. 27 -- In about a month, Angela Davis goes on trial for her life.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Women who feel aggrieved by the present organization of society now have a new magazine. It is called "Ms." And if you are uncertain how to pronounce it and hate to sound dumb at the newsstand you can ask for it by its subtitle, which is "The New Magazine for Women."

SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 27 -- President Park Chung Hee signed into law today a controversial bill that gives him broad powers in a state of national emergency, which legislators from his party rammed through the National Assembly in a hasty session before dawn this morning.

Just as the drama got off to a start that only charity could call leisurely, so the dance also moved with the speed of a discreet waltz rather than a hectic gallop. For one thing, everything was a little retarded, including this season's opening.

The Nixon Administration and the Washington press corps are beginning to look foolish in the "backgrounder" controversy. While the stories add an amusing touch to the otherwise dreary news of the day, to put the argument on a high moral plane, as some have done, is ridiculous.
Following are excerpts from a news conference by Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of A.B.C. News:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Home buyers can look forward to an ample supply of mortgage money at attractive rates in 1972, Preston Martin, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today.

MOSCOW, Dec. 27 -- The Soviet Union, after a year of striving not to embarrass Chilean Marxists with too rapid an embrace, today sent its first top-level delegation to Chile since the election victory of President Salvador Allende Gossens.
A court ruling cleared the way yesterday for the Offtrack Betting Corporation to televise horse races into the metropolitan area even if the programs conflict with action at tracks here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Nearly seven years after President Lyndon B. Johnson began sustained bombing of North Vietnam in an effort to save the South, another American President is relying heavily on airpower to achieve his objectives in Indochina.

TOKYO, Dec. 27 -- Japan's exports will drop by 1.7 per cent and her imports will increase by 6.8 per cent in the next fiscal year over the current fiscal year, ending March 31, because of the upward revaluation of the yen, a leading Japanese trading concern predicted today.

DAKAR, Senegal, Dec. 27 -- The police have finally succeeded in chasing local building contractors away from one of this city's magnificent beaches, which they had been digging up as a source of sand.
HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Dec. 27 -- A $250,000 off track betting system for Suffolk County, independent of New York City's, was proposed today to the County Legislature.

TEMPE, Ariz., Dec. 27 (AP) -- Woody Green, a sophomore halfback, plunged to a touchdown from 2 yards out with 34 seconds remaining to give Arizona State a 45-38 victory over Florida State today in the inaugural Fiesta Bowl college football game.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Dec. 28 -- Heavy American bombing raids against North Vietnam went into the third consecutive day this morning while the United States command kept its official silence about details of the attacks and allied losses.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27 -- Twenty-five antiwar demonstrators occupied the Betsy Ross House here for an hour today in protest against continuation of the war in Vietnam. All were arrested.

WARWICK, R. I., Dec. 28 (AP) -- The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company today settled its lawsuit against the Leesona Corporation, a Warwick manufacturer of textile machinery, Leeson said. The suit involved Leesona's right to collect royalties from licensees under its stretch yarn patents.
While almost 100 policemen were massed inside and in front of the Civil Jail early yesterday morning during some inmates' rebellion, three gunmen robbed a gasoline station half a block away.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission asked Congress today for greater regulatory powers over the securities industry to protect investors from a recurrence of the crisis that struck Wall Street in 1969-70.

Mayor Lindsay's announcement yesterday of his candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination was received by his fellow Democrats with a variety of comment -- some politic and some not so politic.

Mayor Lindsay has now officially joined the growing band of Democrats who believe they can defeat President Nixon in 1972 and would like the privilege of trying. In spite of the Mayor's brief life as a Democrat -- four months -- his entering the race for his party's nomination is neither whimsical nor unreasonable. Whatever his chances of getting it, he should have no trouble in making a case.

Judges, District Attorneys and mayoral aides, in a swift response to Monday night's rebellion at the Civil Jail, announced today that the cases of material witnesses held there would be reviewed within a month and that no such witness would be held there more than 90 days.

The National Aviation Corporation, a closed-end investing company, has elected Donald C. Burr as president. He succeeds Harvey Gaylord, who will resign Jan. 1 but continue with the company as consultant. Howard E. Buhse, formerly director and chairman of the executive committee, has been elected chairman of the board of directors, The lastnamed also is chairman of the board of the directing partners of Hornblower Weeks-Hemphill, Noyes, stock brokers.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 28 (AP) -- A touchdown by Stahle Vincent of Rice and a field goal by George Hunt of Tennessee gave the South a 9-0 victory in the annual Blue-Gray football game tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28--President Nixon signed today a bill requiring most able-bodied welfare recipients to register for jobs or job training, beginning July 1. The President praised the "workfare" provisions and said, "In my judgment, they reflect the national interest."

DACCA, Pakistan, Dec. 28 -- The acting president of the Bengalis' East Pakistan regime said today that his government would welcome the establishment of diplomatic relations with the United States, but that the United States must take the initiative.

ALBANY, Dec. 28 -- Governor Rockefeller's proposed freeze in state spending would cost New York City $71-million in expected revenues from Albany and would put an end to open enrollment in the City University, according to Richard A. Brown, Mayor Lindsay's legislative representative here.
DETROIT, Dec. 28 -- James R. Hoffa, former president of the teamsters union, said today that Phase Two of President Nixon's economic program so far had "not bothered the teamsters."
RANGPUR, Pakistan, Dec. 25 -- Chandrakant Joddar returned home today after living for eight months and eight days in a concrete pipe at a refugee camp in Calcutta.
MIAMI, Dec. 28 -- Mayor Lindsay announced today his candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination and at the same time attacked the Nixon Administration and his prospective Democratic rivals.
ALBANY, Dec. 28 -- Proposals to solve the state's money problems were spread about the Capitol today like leaflets advising an enemy to surrender.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the-counter market bounced back yesterday and finished slightly higher in accelerated trading.

PARIS, Dec. 28 -- Italy has bowed to powerful French pressure and reversed a decision that would have opened up Italian ports to increased imports of grains from the United States and other food exporters.
ALBANY, Dec. 28 -- Democrats accused Republicans today of a "double cross" in the wording of legislative proposals for a 35-cent transit fare in New York City.

The real pleasures offered by well-trained dancers along with precision and craftsmanly care in choreography are always an integral part of the Mary Anthony Dance Theater. On Monday evening at the Theater of Riverside Church the company offered a new work created by Miss Anthony, "A Ceremony of Carols."

HOUSTON, Dec. 28 -- The Young Socialist Alliance, a frequent target of the Texas Ku Klux Klan, opened its annual convention in Houston today with a plea that delegates "be a little extra cautious and a little extra courteous."

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Dec. 28 -- Suffolk County Executive H. Lee Dennison delivered his farewell address today after 12 years as the county's top leader. He recommended drastic changes in the county's political organization, a comprehensive new highway network and a severance of all county ties with the Long Island Rail Road.

Chain stores and catalogue houses chalked up a sales gain of 12.2 per cent last month. It was their second largest gain this year, exceeded only by a 13.8 per cent increase in April. The November sales advance reflects the excellent start made for Christmas business, which reached record proportions this year.
Proclaiming victory for their gesture with cheers and raised fists, 15 antiwar veterans ended their occupation of the Statue of Liberty yesterday.
MANCHESTER, N. H., Dec. 28 -- Senator Vance Hartke, Democrat of Indiana, teetered today an the brink of announcing his candidacy in New Hampshire's Presidential primary next March 7.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28 (UPI) -- South Carolina, with every starter scoring at least 13 points, romped to an 86-64 victory over Boston College tonight to reach the final of the Quaker City basketball tournament.
LEOPARDSTOWN, Ireland, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Kelanne won the Irish Sweepstakes Hurdle today, a horse race that made lucky ticket-holders around the world rich.

HONG KONG, Dec, 28 -- The Hanoi radio, in a broadcast monitored here today, quoted the North Vietnamese Army newspaper Quan Doi Nhan Dan as having said that more United States pilots had been captured and that no American pilots held in North Vietnam would be freed as long as President Nixon continued the war.
The formation of a new securities industry group to speed the settlement of stock and bond transactions through the use of regional depositories was announced yesterday.

More students in the country's journalism schools are studying advertising than preparing for jobs on the news side, according to Billy I. Ross, chairman of the Department of Mass Communications of Texas Tech University, Lubbock.

POUGHQUAG, N. Y. -- Thirty pampered baby bulls are living a life of luxury, eating and drinking to their hearts content, here at the only bull testing station in New York State in the rolling hills of southern Dutchess County, less than two hours from Times Square.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The Pay Board, by the testimony of a representative cross-section of its members, has been ineptly led, acrimoniously divided and largely ineffectual in the first months of the second phase of President Nixon's economic stabilization program.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 28 (UPI) -- pair of former Wimbledon champions, Frank Sedgman and Neil Fraser, advanced to the round of 16 in the Australian open tennis championships today. Fraser, 37 years old, upset an Australian Davis Cup player, Geoff Masters, 16 years his junior, by 7-5, 7-5, 6-2.
ROME, Dec. 28 -- Italian television fans are being baffled by a seven-part primetime serial retelling Vergil's "Aeneid."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Nelson Gross, the State Department coordinator for international narcotics affairs, said today that at least six tons of heroin and related materials were confiscated in the last year through the direct or indirect efforts of United States authorities.

Vice President Agnew has a foeman worthy of his steel in Mayor Lindsay. Responding to charges of "possible perjury, malfeasance and misfeasance," leveled by Matthew J. Troy against his administration's dealing with police corruption, the Mayor countered with "petty piranhas of the political marketplace" (how many hours were spent by his staff futilely seeking a synonym for the last word that would begin with "p"?) and with the "petty, carping, nagging little men." Carping piranhas?

Residential building contracts, breaking all records in November, gave a big increase to the total value of all construction contracts awarded in the month, the F. W. Dodge division of the McGraw-Hill Information Systems Company reported yesterday.

Most of the public comments about John Lindsay's bid for the Presidency illustrate the tyranny of the political parties, and add to the confusion about how to pick a President of the United States in 1972.

METAPONTO, Italy -- Donato Montanaro used to earn $15 and 80 pounds of grain a month as a hardworking farmhand. Today he owns a model farmhouse, 10 acres of irrigated land, a garden tractor and a motorbike, employs five seasonal workers, makes $10,000 a year and raises rabbits as a pastime.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The Securities andExchange Commission said today that the AmericanBioculture Corporation of New York had violatedantifraud, proxy and recording provisions of Federalsecurities laws.

EVANSTON, Ill., Dec. 28 -- This Chicago suburb, site of the national headquarters of the Women's Christian Temperance Union, will apparently retain its 116-year-old ban on liquor sales for at least a month or two.
ORLANDO, Fla., Dec. 28 (AP) -- Mel Long's shattering tackle and fumble recovery for a touchdown led Toledo to its 35th straight victory, 28-3, over Richmond in the Tangerine Bowl tonight.
Two of the world's leading string musicians, Pablo Casals, the cellist, and Lionel Tertis, the violist, are celebrating their 95th birthdays today.
Joseph F. Crangle, chairman of the Erie County Democratic organization, was elected the party's state chairman yesterday in a contest with national political overtones.

In the interests of safety and showmanship, the 1972 running of the Indianapolis 500 will require four pit stops instead of the present three. The Primary purpose is to make it unnecessary to fill fuel cells chock-full.

WASHINGTON, Dec.28 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission gave its conditional approval today to the merger of the Gulf, Mobile Ohio Railroad Company and the Illinois Central Railroad Company into the 9,400-mile, 13-state Illinois Central Gulf Railroad Company.

This has been a season when American museums talked poor even while some of them acted rich. The undisputed kingpin of them all, New York's Metropolitan Museum of Art, had it both ways, paying a record sum of $5,544,000 for an old master, Velazquez's portrait of Juan de Pareja, while apologetically collecting its new admission charge.

An outbreak of chills, headaches, fever, sore throats, aching muscles and occasional vomiting and stomach cramps has swept through Connecticut, causing absenteeism at work an jamming emergency rooms in hospitals.
In a farewell to the United Nations General Assembly the other day, Secretary General Thant said: "I feel a sense of great relief, bordering on liberation . . . on laying down the burden of office."

WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 28 -- In the first two years of its life, the Westchester County Board of Legislators has surprised many county residents by making the public aware of -- and giving it access to -- what used to be a level of government hidden by a lack of concern.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28 -- Monkeys raised in isolation from other monkeys during a critical phase in their youth grow up unable to control their tendencies for violent behavior, a team of animal behavior researchers reported today. They suggested that there may be a similar phase in human development.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (UPI) -- The Tandy Corporation, Fort Worth, Texas, agreed today to sell 36 electronic-products retail stores it acquired last year in its multimillion-dollar takeover of the Allied Radio Corporation of Chicago.

Earnings of the Beatrice Foods Company increased 17 per cent in the third quarter ended Nov. 30 on a sales gain of 14 per cent. For the nine months, earnings were up 16 per cent and sales 15 per cent. William G. Karnes, president, said this was the 79th consecutive quarter of record results.
Heavy selling pushed prices of soybean futures down near the close of trading on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday, and the prices were off 1 7/8 cents to 4 cents a bushel.

KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Dec. 28 -- President Nixon assured Chancellor Willy 'Brandt of West Germany today that he would not strike any separate bargains with the Soviet Union on troop withdrawals from Europe when he meets with Soviet leaders in Moscow in May.
There is something about a uniform that is intriguing corporation executives all over the country.
BOSTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- State Insurance Commissioner John G. Ryan disclosed today the rates for the new no-fault property damage insurance plan tentatively scheduled to go into effect Jan. 1.

MIAMI, Dec. 28 -- Tighter coverage and a mixture of defenses appear to be the Miami Dolphins' strategy for stopping John Unitas in Sunday's American Football Conference championship game with the Baltimore Colts at the Orange Bowl.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Eighty-seven members of the Vietnam Veterans Against the War were arrested for disorderly conduct today after blocking the entrance to the Lincoln Memorial.

PARIS -- A new allied crisis over Malta -- or, at any rate, another flare-up of the old one -- can be regarded as probable. The strategically located island republic has not figured much in recent news -- but only because it has been negotiating with Britain and NATO.

WILLISTON PARK, L. I., Dec. 28 -- A reputed underworld figure under indictment for refusing to testify before a Nassau County grand jury investigating organized crime was killed here today in what was described by the police as a "lover's quarrel."

The $260,000 Jackie Gleason Inverrary Classic, one of four new tournaments on the 1972 Professional Golfers' Association tour announced yesterday, will surpass the Westchester Classic as pro golf's richest.
RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Dec. 28 -- Within the last two weeks, Abdul Rahim Khan, a former fighter pilot who commands Pakistan's Air Force, has emerged as the strongest military influence in the country.

In common, its practitioners -- who include most prominently John Vaccaro, Ronald Tavel and Charles Ludlam -- are irreverent, particularly toward subjects traditionally revered, derisive even toward their own work, adoring of certain movies and myths, and grotesquely comic.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28 -- Thirty-two years ago, J. Robert Oppenheimer and Hartland S. Snyder proposed that a great assembly of matter, as in a large, burned out star, would collapse into something so dense that it would become invisible.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The Department of Justice filed a suit today charging Mississippi officials with refusing to count hundreds of ballots in predominantly black Humphreys County in last November's elections.
ATLANTA, Dec. 28 -- Mayor Sam Massell announced yesterday a plan that would more than double the size of this city's land area and change its black majority into a minority.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Lakers, despite 32 points and 20 rebounds by Buffalo's Elmore Smith, defeated the mistake-plagued Braves, 105-87, tonight and extended their National Basketball Association record winning streak to 29 games.

The Manhattan District Attorney's office is investigating the circumstances surrounding the death of a 30-year-old nurse two weeks after she took out a $100,000 life insurance policy.

VIETIANE, Laos, Dec. 28 (UPI) -- North Vietnamese troops scored another victory today in a drive southward through Laos, capturing the town of Paksong and giving them control of virtually the entire Boloven Plateau.

The chief judge of New York said yesterday that he intended to put the state's new speedy-trial rules for criminal cases into effect on May 1 as scheduled -- even if he has to shut down the state's civil courtrooms and eliminate judges' vacations to make the rules work.

Bruce Taylor, the San Francisco all-pro cornerback, has a badly sprained ankle and is a doubtful performer for the 49ers against the Cowboys in the National Conference championship game at Dallas on Sunday.
HOBART, Tasmania, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The 73-foot American yawl, Kialoa II, is leading the fleet in what could be a record time for the Sydney-Hobart yacht race.

The village of Salado, deep in the heart of Texas, has 336 registered voters, vast expanses of land, and a dress shop that does an annual business of about $500,000. Two of the voters and land-owners, one of them also the owner of the dress shop, threw a party at the Sign of the Dove restaurant Monday night for the debutante daughter of dear friends and 150 other friends, acquaintances and strangers.
Two surprise applicants, Thomas E. Dewey Jr. and William Levitt, the builder, put in bids yesterday to acquire the National Hockey League franchise awarded to the new Nassau Coliseum for next season.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 28 (UPI) -- Harry Bridges, leader of the West Coast waterfront workers, advocated today a merger of his independent union with the International Longshoremen's Association, which represents East and Gulf Coast dock workers.

Significant long-range changes in the operation of the securities industry are likely to occur in 1972, according to a yearend statement yesterday by Paul Kolton, president of the American Stock Exchange.

MIAMI, Dec. 30 -- Despite the Baltimore Colts' success at blocking seven of 13 field-goal attempts this year, the Miami Dolphins won't alter Garo Yepremian's place-kicking style or increase the yardage to where the ball is spotted behind the line of scrimmage Sunday in the American Football Conference championship game.
Seasonal cross-currents affected stock prices yesterday to send the market moderately lower. Today will mark the final trading session for 1971.
The over-the-counter market did somewhat better than the American Stock Exchange yesterday as prices of most counter issues advanced while the listed issues were slightly lower.

The operators of the eight private bus lines in the city are participating in the current contract negotiations at the Americana Hotel, but their real interest lies in what happens after the contract talks end.
Roy Boe and 10 partners who helped raise $10-million for the team were awarded the National Hockey League franchise for Long Island yesterday.

PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 30 -- The Premier of Israel, Mrs. Golda Meir, is the woman most admired by the American people, according to a Gallup Poll taken earlier this month. In last year's survey, she was third among the top 10; in 1969, fourth.

Because their landlords failed to file for an increase or were disqualified for not clearing up violations, tenants in 400,000 controlled apartments here will not have to pay a rent increase next month.

Negotiations aimed at averting a subway and bus strike tomorrow moved toward a climax yesterday, but the two sides remained far apart on critical money matters. Mayor Lindsay warned that the time was "very short" and urged the parties to intensify their bargaining efforts in the remaining hours before tomorrow's 5 A.M. deadline for a possible walkout of 40,000 bus and subway workers represented by the Transport Workers Union and the Amalgamated Transit Union.

Although most of the contributions recorded yesterday by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund were from individuals or families, several came from groups of workers employed in the metropolitan area.

Pilobolus, a dance group formed by four Dartmouth men as an outgrowth of dance classes at the college, made an informal debut here Wednesday night at the Louis-Nikolais Dance Theater Lab, 344 West 36th Street.
LAUREL, Md., Dec. 30 (AP) -- Kathy Kusner suffered a fractured nose and lacerations of the face today when she fell from her mount in the first race at Laurel Race Course.
Left behind by the younger, the richer and the mobile, lonely elderly people live scattered around New York in neighborhoods that were better in their younger years.

The disarming of Bengali guerrillas by Indian troops under the pretext of preventing violent reprisals against Pakistan collaborators in Bangladesh is an ominous step. It makes clear Indian intentions for Bangladesh: indefinite occupation by the Indian army, speedy elimination of the Bengali guerrilla leadership and installation of a puppet government now waiting in the wings in Calcutta.
Mayor Lindsay called on Federal authorities yesterday to order a 90 per cent cutback in the production of amphetamines by the country's drug manufacturers.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 30 -- William P. Bundy, one of the influential policy makers of the Vietnam war, conceded today that American military planners might have let conventional war get out of hand in their direction of the conflict in Southeast Asia.
John H. Vogel, president and chief administrative officer of the National Bank of North America, has been named chief executive officer of the bank, a C.I.T. Financial Corporation affiliate.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Prices farmers received for raw products rose 2 per cent in December, the third successive monthly increase, an average of 12 per cent more than a year ago, the Agriculture Department announced today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The following tables show the new values of the world's currencies in the aftermath of the Dec. 18 agreement among the Group of 10 industrial nations on a realignment of their currencies, leading to an effective devaluation of the United States dollar.

ROME, Dec. 30 -- Buses and streetcars carried passengers free today as the city started an unprecedented nine-day experiment with public transit. But many Romans spurned the free rides or suspected some gimmick.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 30 -- The United States command announced today the end of its intensified bombing of North Vietnam after five days of raids. It also stated for the first time that the targets of the heaviest attacks against the North in three years -- involving 1,000 strikes -- were airfields, supply depots and antiaircraft sites.

The bond and money markets, which customarily drop into a deep slumber during the final week of the year, finally started to doze yesterday, following three sessions of abnormally heavy activity in which interest rates had moved sharply lower.

Stokely-Van Camp, Inc., fruit and vegetable packers, reported yesterday for the six months ended Nov. 28 net income of $3,095,000, or 81 cents a share, up 9.8 per cent from $2,819,000, or 72 cents a share, for the preceding year's period.

ROME, Dec. 30 (Reuters) -- An American Jesuit historian here has reported that Pope Pius XII acted as intermediary for a group of Germans ploting to overthrow Hitler in 1940 and also warned Britain and France four days in advance of Germany's May 10 invasion of France, the Netherlands and Belgium.

After being hailed as "Fakhr al Islam" -- pride of Islam -- Muhammad Ali fulfilled the dream of all Moslems by visiting Mecca. At the Red Sea city of Jidda, Prince Faisal ben Fahd, head of Saudi Arabia's youth welfare department, told the boxer: "
Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday the award of a $228-million contract that is expected to start construction within six weeks on the controversial North River Pollution Control Plant.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 30 (UPI) -- Ed Marinaro and John Reaves, two of the biggest stars of the 1971 college football season, won't be in the starting line-up tomorrow for the 47th Shrine East-West game at Candlestick Park.
GENEVA, Dec. 30 -- The International Press Institute reported today that in the democratic world "the will of the journalist to say what he thinks is being slowly and imperceptibly weakened."
BALTIMORE, Dec. 30 -- A jury today found Representative John Dowdy, Democrat of Texas, guilty on all eight counts in his bribery, conspiracy and perjury trial in United States District Court here.

The New York Telephone Company has asked J. Curtis Counts, director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, to enter the negotiations in the 25-week-old strike between the company and 23 state locals of the Communication Workers of America.

To come upon an article in The Times called "The Meaning of Brown Eggs" was an unexpected pleasure. To find that it was by an Englishman, J. B. Priestley, gave it an extra fillip. And to happen on it while returning from the barn carrying the day's catch of nine brown eggs seemed almost too pat.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Second-seeded Ken Rosewall defeated Jean Paul Meyer of France, 6-4, 6-4, 6-2, today and Alan Stone eliminated Mark Cox of Britain 6-1, 6-2, 6-3, leaving only one non-Australian in men's singles play at the Australian open tennis championships.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The agreement Dec. 18 of the Group of 10 leading industrial nations (which effectively devalued the United States dollar) required currency exchange-rate decisions by nearly 100 countries, the International Monetary Fund disclosed today.

BOSTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Massachusetts today announced plans for state acquisition of 145 miles of railroad rights-of-way in Massachusetts from the Penn Central Transportation Company. The deal, which includes options to purchase an additional 90 miles, is to cost some $19.5-million and is contingent on a Federal loan.
PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 31 (AP) -- Don Hutson, the Alabama end who caught two touchdown passes in the 1935 Rose Bowl game, heads the 50-year Rose Bowl team announced today.

Grass Roots Exposition, Inc., which just completed its first year of operation, has developed a new program for bringing together prime contractors and other major corporations with minority businesses.

It was a most unfortunate choice of picture The Times used to illustrate Robert L. Zion's letter (Dec. 18) protesting the "boring empty" plazas that front too many of New York's office buildings. The unnamed plaza pictured is that of the Time Life Building.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y. Dec. 31 -- Oarsman from Boston, Buffalo, Syracuse and New York City battled 30-mile-an-hour head winds and 30-degree weather today in the New Year's regatta of the New York Rowing Association
BOSTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The surging Boston Celtics, led by John Havlicek, Dave Cowens and Jo Jo White, Swept to their 10th consecutive National Basketball Association vic
LONDON, Saturday, Jan. 1 -- Cecil Beaton, the designer and photographer, and Jackie Stewart, the Scottish racing-car driver, won places today in Queen Elizabeth's annual New Year's honors list.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 31 (UPI) -- Jimmy (the Greek) Poulos's 25-yard touchdown run late in the third period gave Georgia a tougher-than-expected 7-3 victory over North Carolina today in the Gator Bowl football game.
The nation's steel industry, hit by what one company termed a "drought" in the latter part of 1971, looks to better times on hopes that the entire economy will grow at a higher rate.

SAIGON, Dec. 31 (UPI) -- The Hanoi radio said today that North Vietnam has captured three American pilots and it gave their names. They were the names of three men Who had flown two of three planes the United States command in Saigon admits having lost yesterday and Sunday.

MOSCOW, Dec. 31 -- An authoritative Soviet newspaper reported today that a powerful group close to the Chinese leadership had publicly expressed its opposition both to improving relations with the United States and to an all-pervasive role for the army in China's affairs.
The stock market rang out the old trading year yesterday with modest price gains for its closing session and high hopes for 1972.

Family Court Judge Millard L. Midonick urged the State Legislature yesterday to eliminate the "Victorian rules" in state penal statutes that require "corroboration" for con-victims on charges of rape and other sexual offenses.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- United States Government analysts said today that China's relatively restrained reaction to the five-day American bombing of North Vietnam indicated a wish to go ahead with President Nixon's trip in February even at the cost of additional strains in Peking's relations with Hanoi.
ALBANY, Dec. 31 -- Even the lame and the sun-tanned legislators were here ready to vote on the last day of what the Governor emphasized was the most urgent fiscal crisis of 1971.

MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 31 -- A detailed signed statement that purports to describe how a narcotics addict shot and killed a Nassau County patrolman after a holdup Wednesday night was read in a crowded courtroom in First District Court here today.

A 67-year-old liquor store clerk foiled a holdup yesterday afternoon by disarming one gunman and wounding his armed accomplice twice in an exchange of gunfire at a shopping center in Brooklyn, the police reported.

The bitter pill is slow going down. Some Republican members of the State Legislature have balked, at least temporarily, at accepting a tax package agreed on by Governor Rockefeller and Republican and Democratic legislative leaders.

NIERSTEIN, West Germany -- German wine growers will have only their older and second best wines to taste for months to come. The new harvest holds the promise of being one of the great vintages of the century, but it is still lying in the casks.
Israeli tank commanders are reputed to ride with turrets open, heads and shoulders exposed, in even the sharpest of battles.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Dec. 3l (Reuters) -- Avery Brundage, president of the International Olympic Committee, issued a new warning today to Olympic skiers and other winter sports competitors about advertising.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The Nixon Administration plans to make 1972 the most expensive farm-subsidy year on record in an attempt to head off growing crop surpluses and discontent over sagging farm income.

A Queens man recommended by the John V. Lindsay Association -- and "absolutely not" by County Democratic leader Matthew J. Troy Jr. -- and the brother of the Bronx District Attorney were among 10 new judges sworn in yesterday by Mayor Lindsay.

On New Year's Day it is possible to be sentimental or sardonic, nurse a hangover or the world. It's no trick at all to be serious; anyone, poet or journalist or subway straphanger -- if there is a subway -- can study the front pages of the past twelvemonth and shudder.

For a basketball tournament that looked on paper as if it might be a monumental bore, the Eastern College Athletic Conference's 20th annual Holiday Festival turned up quite a bit of controversy and a couple of surprises.
MISSOULA, Mont., Dec. 31 -A Federal District Court has refused to interfere with the expulsion of a high school student whose hair was longer than specified under the school's dress code.
Negotiators for the Wire Service Guild agreed late last night to submit the latest wage offer of the Associated Press to its members for a vote this week on a new two-year contract.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota, the Democrats' 1968 Presidential candidate, will announce Jan. 10 his decision to try again for the nomination.

The Bangor Aroostook Railroad has filed suit against the Bangor Punta Corporation and Bangor Punta Operations, a subsidiary, on 14 separate charges totaling more than $13.6-million, it was disclosed yesterday.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 31 (UPI) -- The Sugar Bowl scorekeeper should expect a busy day tomorrow in the Oklahoma-Auburn clash matching teams that together have averaged 76.2 points a game.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UPI) -- The State Department announced today that two agreements had been signed with Nationalist China, limiting Taiwan's textile exports to the United States during the next five years.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 31 -The Argentine Government last night decreed a 25 per cent wage increase for all workers payable in two installments.

Pictorial styles that rely on an essential painterliness for their expressive force are not always easily transferred to the lithographic medium. Divorced from the visual and physical properties of the actual pigment, even the most powerful pictorial style may be reduced to a hollow caricature of itself.

TUCSON, Ariz., Dec. 31 (AP) -- Four copper companies with exploration offices here are reducing or completely shutting their exploration work because times are tough in the copper business. The Kennecott Copper Corporation, the Anaconda Company, the Copper Range Company and the Cerro Corporation disclosed the moves today.
ROCKY BOY RESERVATION, Mont. -- What haunts the parents on this northeastern Montana reservation is the fact that in 10 years only 12 Cree teen-agers have graduated from high school.
HONG KONG, Dec. 31 -- Peking greeted the new year with a declaration that 1971 was "a year of victory" and reaffirmed its determination to "liberate Taiwan."

DETROIT, Dec. 31 (UPI) -Mickey Redmond maintained his team lead with his 17th and 18th goals of the season tonight to pace the Detroit Red Wings to their third straight victory, 6-3, over the California Golden Seals in the National Hockey League.

ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 31 (UPI) -- Willie Shoemaker guided Royal Owl to a 6 1/2-length victory in the $59,100 California Breeders' Champion Stakes today to record his 46th stakes victory of the year and the 548th of his career.

Two shareholders of the Topper Corporation, a toy manufacturer, have filed a class action suit in Federal District Court here. The suit accuses the company and certain insiders of having made false statements and of having unloaded substantial amounts of stock in the company in underwritten public offerings.
NEW DELHI, Dec. 31 -- Prime Minister Indira Gandhi offered some glimpses into her life-style and goals at a news conference here today.

Madison Square Garden threw a New Year's party last night and 6,927 fans came to see the Chiefs, the Garden's Roller Derby team, defeat the Red Devils, 43 -- 41, in an International Roller Derby League game.
CAIRO, Saturday, Jan. 1--Egypt's "year of decision" deadline for war or peace with Israel passed quietly yesterday with no clear indication of what decision, if any, had been taken.
Lower operating income and net losses for the quarter and nine-month periods ended Nov. 30 were announced yesterday by the USM Corporation.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 31 (UPI) -- Gary Hammond of Southern Methodist threw scoring passes of 45 and 28 yards today as the West rolled to its fourth Consecutive victory, 17-13, over the East in the 47th Shrine Football Classic.

NEW DELHI, Dec. 31 -- Prime Minister Indira Gandhi said today that India would like to have a friendly relationship with the United States again, but she wondered "whether the United States Administration wants friendship or not."

IRVING, Tex., Dec. 31 (UPI) -The San Francisco 49ers' coach, Dick Nolan, admitted that he respects the Dallas Cowboys' running attack his team will face in Sunday's National Football Conference championship game. The First National City Bank and the Irving Trust Company, both of which have minimum business - lending rates that "float" in relation to the money market, yesterday lowered their charges for the week beginning Monday, respectively, to 5 1/8 per cent and 5 per cent.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Dec. 31 -- Outside, in the dazzle of sun on the palm trees, people sprawled on the beach and autos moved past the luxury hotels on Collins Avenue.

The Bank of America, the nation's largest bank, charged off $39.9-million in bad debts in the first nine months of 1971, against $38.7-million for the full year of 1970. In a preliminary offering circular for its pending offering of $150-million in capital notes, a copy of which was obtained yesterday, the bank also disclosed for the first time, certain other details of its business.

Today is just the day made for a session with any or all of the titles listed at the head of this column. They're a good excuse to linger in bed. They don't need a lectern to prop them up. LAUREL, Md., Dec. 31 -Peter Fuller's Tantamount, a daughter of Tim Tam, rallied in the final eighth of a mile today to win the New Year's Eve purse as Laurel racecourse's 75-day meeting ended before a crowd of 13,675.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UPI) The Labor Department said today that it currently estimates that unemployed workers in 13 states and Puerto Rico will be eligible for 13 extra weeks of unemployment benefits on Jan. 30, 1972.
EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Dec. 31 (UPI) -- An associate professor at City University and her 7-year-old son were burned to death today in a fire at their rented home here.

ALBANY, Dec. 31 -- After five days of haggling, cajoling, agreeing and rebelling, the three prime movers in the stillunresolved disharmony over the state's fiscal problem left the Capitol today with their politicial images scuffed but not demolished.

HOUSTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- A sophomore tailback, Charlie Davis, scored touchdowns on runs of 27 and 1 yards to lead Colorado to a 29-17 victory over Houston tonight in the 13th annual Astra-Bluebonnet Bowl.

A few weeks ago, it was James Taylor with the horn players from Dreams. Thursday night, at the Academy of Music, it was The Band, backed by a five-horn unit that included some of New York's finest jazz men.

RYE, N. Y., Dec. 31 -- Michael Calman of the Mamaroneck Frostbite Association sailed to a 7-point lead today when the American Yacht Club's annual three-day New Year's frostbite invitation regatta began with five races in a puffy northwest to northerly wind.

The college health service, long viewed by students as good only for doling out aspirin, patching up athletes and diagnosing the common cold, is now emerging as a leading counseling and treatment center for student sex and psychiatric problems.

LOS ANGELES (AP) -- Mother is thrilled when her son decides to become a doctor. But what if Johnny wants to be a nurse?
Supersized, supergraphic calendars are big sellers in stores these days. And, say some producers, the boom has just begun.

The Paula Modersohn-Becker exhibition at La Boetie, 1042 Madison Avenue at 80th Street, is primarily a drawing show, even though it is exceptional in including her complete etchings. (There are exactly a dozen of these, some existing in only one or two proofs.)

" Every year we meant to contribute to the fund but found excuses for delaying and forgetting," Diane and Phil Barbers wrote in one of the letters that accompanied contributions to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund recorded yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- An electronic storage tube invented by a Princeton, N. J., engineer and business man has already found many uses, including the recording of pictures of Mars being returned from Mariner 9. Steven R. Hofstein was granted Patent 3,631,294 this week for the Lithocon, which he says is the first storage tube to record on silicon and silicon dioxide.

To a bedlam of hornblowing in Times Square and spectacular fireworks in Central Park, many thousands of revelers last night shouted in a New Year that they hoped would be better than 1971.

MIAMI, Dec. 31 -- Bear Bryant is calling tomorrow night's Orange Bowl Classic "just about the biggest college game that's ever been," which is fine for Bryant: Alabama is No. 2 and its New Year's night opponent, Nebraska, is sitting in the hot seat.

CONCORD, N. H., Dec. 31 -- President Nixon's campaign organization plans to file Mr. Nixon's name Monday in New Hampshire's Presidential preference primary.

The editor of an Episcopal weekly charged yesterday that the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine should no longer enjoy the right to tax exemption because it was recently used for "partisan political gatherings."

The Mutual Broadcasting System announced yesterday the appointment of C. Edward Little Sr. as president, succeeding Victor Diehm, who has resigned effective January 31. The New York Public Library's science and technology division has fallen $9,000 short of its goal of filling an $86,000 budget deficit and will close its doors, at least temporarily, on Monday.

MIAMI, Dec. 31 -- Don Shula, the coach of the Miami Dolphins, called today for a new playing surface next season in the Orange Bowl Stadium, the site of Sunday's American Football Conference championship game with the Baltimore Colts.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 31 -- A California veterinarian has developed what appears to be a successful technique for saving wild water birds from the lethal aftereffects of oil spills.

DALLAS, Dec. 31 -- Penn State and Texas will meet in the 36th annual Cotton Bowl game tomorrow two years after a Cotton Bowl matchup between the Nittany Lions and Long-horns would have been the 1969 season's struggle for the final No. 1 ranking.

Manny Farber, a painter who has also been widely published as both a film critic and an art critic, has come a long way since his first New York exhibition 10 years ago. The New York Chamber Soloists, with Charles Bressler front and center, gathered around the Christmas tree in the Medieval Sculpture Court of the Metropolitan Museum Thursday night to present a choice assortment of baroque music for an audience that filled all the available space in the splendid setting.

Manhattanville College will present a five-day Improvisational Arts Institute at its Purchase, N. Y., campus from Jan. 17 through 21.
The Transport Workers Union and the Transit Authority reached an agreement on a new contract shortly before 3 A.M. today, averting a strike threatened by the union for 5 A.M.
The Murray Louis Dance Company and the Alwin Nikolais Dance Theater will appear together on one bill for the first time at the Brooklyn Academy of Music from Jan. 18 through Jan. 30.

Only someone with a large garden, however, can grow many varieties of a single vegetable to find the ones most suitable for him.
