A temporary stay to avert a threatened cutoff in Medicaid reimbursement to nursing homes upstate was granted here yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals, while the state asked that the stay be expanded to cover also state government homes that include one on Staten Island.

One of the mysteries of "The Nutcracker" is why anyone would want to give a child a nutcracker as a Christmas present in the first place. The ballet never explains this. But in George Balanchine's production for the New York City Ballet, currently approaching its 680th performance at the State Theater, more immediate mysteries do have their solutions.

LIMA, Peru, Jan. 4 (AP) -- A 17-year-old girl, one of 92 persons aboard an airliner that crashed Dec. 24, has been found alive in a jungle in eastern Peru where she had wandered among swamps, rivers and tropical forest.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -Ralph Nader charged today that Senator Edmund S. Muskie had failed to follow through on the promise he made more than a year ago to conduct a public investigation of the property tax and its abuses.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Amtrak, the National Railroad Passenger Corporation, said today that it was immediately discontinuing service between Buffalo, Cleveland and Chicago.

DETROIT, Jan. 4 (UPI) -Passenger-car production by the Big Three auto makers increased by 2,253,540 units in 1971 to 8,723,126, compared with the 1970 total of 6,469,586, figures released today showed.

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 4 -- The first half was similar, but the second half was not as the Milwaukee Bucks beat the Knicks, 121-100, at the Arena tonight, just 24 hours after the dramatic 101-99 Knick victory in New York.

WESTBURY, L.I., Jan. 4 -The walls of the tack room in the stable of the four-acre Shapiro home in Brookville are covered with all the blue ribbons Neal has accumulated in the 12 years it has taken him to become one of the most successful riders of show jumpers in the world.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Twenty-five persons were injured when a National Airlines 747 with 334 persons aboard ran into severe air turbulence today on a flight here from Miami. All but five were later released from hospitals to which they were taken.
Two city sanitationmen who interspersed commercial refuse collections for a fee with their regular rounds of pickups in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn were suspended yesterday.

The American Ballet Theater started its winter season at the City Center last night with a conventional but sturdy program of "Paquita," Eliot Feld's "At Midnight," Antony Tudor's "Jardin aux Lilas" and Alvin Ailey's "The River."

LONDON, Jan. 4 -- British schools, once a symbol of stern discipline, have been accused by a teachers' union of ignoring the problem of classroom violence. Another teachers' union denies that there has been evidence of a marked increase in complaints.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The Food and Drug Administration announced today the beginning of the first over-all review ever attempted of the safety and efficacy of the more than 100,000 nonprescription drugs on the market.
ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- Following are estimates supplied by the State Division of the Budget on the amount of income tax increase to be paid this year by a typical family of four.

As life regained its gracious rhythm at the Pierre Hotel yesterday, the police reported finding what may be a key clue to tracing the bandits who stole more than $1-million worth of guests' jewelry and cash on Sunday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 4 -- Iran has informed United Nations officials and delegates that a "dangerous situation" has been created by the expulsion of more than 60,000 Iranians from Iraq in the last three months.

The White House has wasted no time in shattering the illusion created by President Nixon in his television interview earlier this week when he indicated that the fate of American prisoners of war is the "one circumstance" standing in the way of total withdrawal from Indochina.

LONDON, Jan. 4 (Reuters) -- The British Broadcasting Corporation tonight disregarded an almost unprecedented Government rebuke and said it would not abandon plans to present a two-and-a-half-hour television program tomorrow on ways to solve the Northern Ireland crisis.
DE KALB, Ill., Jan. 4 (AP) -Northern Illinois, led by Jim Bradley and Billy Harris, upset high-ranked Indiana, 85-71, tonight despite 30 points by Hoosier Jobie Wright.
HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Jan. 4 -- The National Collegiate Athletic Association will not attempt to solve the serious financial problems of intercollegiate sports during its 66th annual convention this week.

NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 4 (AP) -- The commander of the Fifth Coast Guard District, charging that recent issues of Playboy magazine had "gone beyond the bounds of what many consider proper," has canceled all Government - purchased subscriptions to the magazine at district units, the Norfolk VirginiaPilot reported yesterday.

COCOA, Fla., Jan. 4 -- Dr. George Denton Beal, who retired in 1958 as a director of research at Mellon Institute in Pittsburgh, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home here. He had lived in Cocoa since his retirement. His age was 84.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Gov. George C. Wallace's decision to enter several Democratic primaries poses problems for the Democratic front-runner, Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine, at the moment when he has finally made his candidacy official.
PARIS, Jan. 4 (UPI) -- The United States and South Vietnam agreed today to resume the Vietnam peace talks on Thursday after four weeks of postponements by both sides.

FRANKLIN, N. H., Jan. 4 (AP) -- Representative Paul N. McCloskey Jr., Republican of California, said today that he would welcome Senator Edward W. Brooke, Republican of Massachusetts, who is a Negro, as his running mate on a Presidential ticket.
J. Perry Rudick has been named a senior vice president of Smith, Barney, Co, Inc., international investment bankers. He will continue as the director responsible for the corporate finance department.

The bond markets, despite the beginning of a new round of prime-rate reductions, failed to move much yesterday. Corporate and tax-exempt bonds dipped and recovered, and Government bonds recovered from their Monday slide.

The redevelopment of Harlem is being placed in the hands of 25 blacks, three Puerto Ricans and two whites who are being appointed today to the board of directors of the Harlem Urban Development Corporation.
The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith and other Jewish organizations yesterday challenged the contention that laws permitting the Jewish ritual slaughter of livestock are unconstitutional.

SAN MATEO, Calif., Jan. 4 (UPI) -- The National Federation of Independent Business said today that 91 per cent of members polled support the Government's plan to combat inflation by restraining wages and prices. But members were divided on the guidelines employed.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Consumer installment credit rose by a record $1,266,000,000 in November, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
Dr. Harvey Scribner, the City Schools Chancellor, last night stepped into the controversy involving Community School Board 1 on the Lower East Side by appointing two temporary board members.
LONDON, Jan. 4 (UPI) -- Prime Minister Dora Mintoff of Malta has barred use of facilities on Malta by the United States Sixth Fleet in the Mediterranean, the British Defense Ministry said today.

AYRSHIRE, Iowa, Jan. 4 -- It isn't every day that Ayrshire inaugurates the youngest mayor in the United States, so it was only fitting that the school gym was packed with more people than Ayrshire's population of 273 last night for the inaugural ball of 19-year-old Jody Smith.

Strikes by teachers have become so much a part of the national school scene -- there were more than 400 in the last three years -- that they now seldom excite interest outside the community directly affected.

ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- After a week of wooing, waiting and searching for votes, the Republicancontrolled Legislature today passed a $407-million package of tax increases with needed help from the Democratic minorities in both houses.

The city administration reported yesterday that it had recruited unemployed people to fill all 1,575 public-service jobs allotted it under the Federal Emergency Employment Act, and had 1,200 applicants so far for 938 other jobs under a special allotment for areas of severe unemployment.

Robert T. Carson was sentenced yesterday to 18 months in prison for taking part in a bribery conspiracy to kill stock-fraud indictments when he was the administrative aide to Senator Hiram L. Fong, Republican of Hawaii.

DETROIT, Jan. 4 -- The General Motors Corporation said it would close a tooling plant here by March 31, idling 1,000 hourly and salaried workers. And the Ford Motor Company this week laid off 50, or about 5 per cen of the employes at its design center.
The concept of "democratic Communism" as expounded in Professors Raditsa and Mestrovic's Dec. 24 letter, "Repression in Croatia," is open to serious question.

In closed board rooms, private dining rooms and sedate executive suites around Wall Street, financial analysts meet corporate managements to gather the information that influences investment decisions.
Locking wheels like a couple of Roman chariots, the Offtrack Betting Corporation and Yonkers Raceway careened through a new flurry of accusations yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The Peace Corps, short of funds, began shaping plans today to reduce its 8,000-member volunteer force by half and to cancel programs in as many as 15 countries.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 4 (UPI) -- A Defense Ministry spokesman reported today that enemy troops, supported by two North Vietnamese MIG aircraft, had destroyed a bridge on the only road between Vientiane and the royal capital, Luang Prabang.

Mrs. Sheila Jackson Dorsey of New York was married in St. James' Episcopal Church yesterday to John Montague Bates Jr., who is with the San Francisco office of du Pont Glore Forgan, investment bankers. The ceremony, performed by the Rev. Almus Thorp, was followed by a reception at the Knickerbocker Club.
WASHINGTON -- A great deal has been written about the Army lately, good and bad. As its Chief of Staff, I welcome this opportunity to tell you where the Army is and where it is headed.

PARIS, Jan. 4 -- Representative Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, has bowed out of a trip to Paris and Brussels the committee is making over the next week to try to improve American relations with the European Common Market.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -Ralph Nadar, the consumer advocate and auto safety expert, has been dropped from membership on the Transportation Department's Motor Vehicle Safety Advisory Council.
A 69-year-old widow was found strangled and stabbed yesterday morning in the bedroom of her apartment in a low-income project in the Hammels section of the Rockaways, Queens.
Key glamour issues and the long-depressed aerospace group helped to lift the stock market onto higher ground yesterday. Volume picked up with the rebound in stock prices in afternoon trading.

SAN DIEGO, Jan. 4 -- In his first public appearance of the new year, President Nixon announced today a major shipbuilding contract before some 2,000 happy shipyard workers here. In the process, he gave a vivid demonstration of how ordinary Presidential business can be made to coincide with political purpose.
MOSCOW, Jan. 4 -- The Soviet Union announced today a major advance in its nuclear energy program with the end of construction of the world's first large commercial fast breeder reactor.

LAWRENCE, L. I., Jan. 4 -Three armed men, two of them wearing ski masks and the other a black wig, held up nine employes of the Franklin National Bank branch here this morning and escaped with $180,500 in cash.

The Mark Donohue-Porsche entry into the 1972 CanadianAmerican Challenge Cup is shaping up as the best break the Can-Am has had in years. Today at Road Atlanta, Donohue will resume his testing program to evaluate refinements suggested by two previous sessions there and in Germany.

ATLANTA, Jan. 4 -- Gov. George C. Wallace, an independent candidate four years ago, has decided to enter the 1972 Democratic Presidential primary in Florida and perhaps party contests in several other states.

A unit of the National Council of Churches has accused 10 Protestant denominations of complicity through their stockholdings in the "irresponsible, immoral and socially injurious acts" of 29 corporations holding military contracts.

When William R. Tolbert Jr. was inaugurated Monday as President of Liberia, he wore a blue cotton shirt and trousers, unconventional attire for such ceremonies anywhere, but pointedly so in a country long preoccupied with the intricacies of protocol and formal dress. Mrs. Richard M. Nixon, 'who headed the official United States delegation to the inauguration of 'Liberia's 19th president, sat beside the new President at the inaugural banquet.
Now that Billy Hardwick, the former two-time bowler of the year, has taken a new grip on his game, he is looking forward to making another comeback.

The Police Department yesterday requested a $680.7-million expense budget for 1972-73 -- or $28.7-million more than its current budget -- to provide for about 1,000 more policemen to bring the department's patrol force to its maximum allotted strength of 25,000.

DUBLIN, Jan. 4 (Reuters)--The Official wing of the Irish Republican Army today condemned the violence pursued by the organization's militant Provisional wing. The Official wing said that violence could only delay prospects of Irish unity and asserted that British troops were actually trying to provoke it.
Whoever was listening yesterday morning to the panel on "Who's Listening to Serious Music and Why Not?" got an earful, not much music but plenty serious.

The George Harrison-Ravi Shankar-Bob Dylan Bangladesh record album, released two weeks ago after months of disputes, has created what the music industry calls "bad vibes" among some record stores and their customers.

ATLANTA, Jan. 4 (AP)--An airliner that carried a leaky shipment of radioactive medical isotopes from New York to Houston has been decontaminated and placed back into service, Delta Air Lines said today.
Senator J. W. Fulbright, in an article published yesterday, traced the failures of United States foreign policy since World War II to blind adherence to the anti-Communist Truman Doctrine.

" There's blood all over the keyboard," complained Bert Farber, the pianist who leads the house band at the Persian Room of the Plaza Hotel. And there was blood -- the same blood -- on both thumbs of Roger Williams, who had just finished his evening's performance on the Persian Room's piano.
Cities across the nation are turning increasingly to special property, sales and gasoline taxes to subsidize soaring deficits on their mass transit systems.

Purchases by the Soviet Union in the world sugar market are helping to push sugar futures prices to their highest levels in seven years, a Dow Jones News Service dispatch from London said yesterday. New York sugar brokers agreed.
An elderly man with all the appearances of a derelict who suffered a heart attack on a city bus yesterday afternoon had his pockets stuffed with more than $130,000 in cash, checks and bankbooks.

MONROVIA, Liberia, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Mrs. Richard M. Nixon, wearing native dress with a bouffant bead scarf, tapped her foot to tribal drums today as she watched dancing girls with painted bodies and bare breasts.
The four men who will begin to function this month as "district managers" in a test by the city of government decentralization were named yesterday by Mayor Lindsay.

John Brockington of the Green Bay Packers, who shattered the National Football League rushing record for first-year running backs by grinding out 1,105 yards, was named yesterday the N.F.L. offensive rookie of the year by The Associated Press.

ESSEN, West Germany, Jan. 4 (Reuters) -- Guenter Vogelsang, who led Fried, Krupp, G.m.b.H., the West German industrial giant, back to financial health, will resign as chairman of the executive board at the end of 1972, the company confirmed today.
KARACHI, Jan. 4 (Reuters) -President Bhutto has offered peace and friendship to India and said he would go to New Delhi to talk with Premier Indira Gandhi "tomorrow" if India responded.

The key to "22 Years," Robert Sickinger's play about Charles Manson that opened last night at Stage 73, is in the title. The 22 years refer to the time that Manson is reported to have spent in prison from 12 to 34, before he became a self-prec]aimed messjah and convicted murderer.

LA JOLLA, Calif., Jan. 4 (UPI) -- Dr. Hannes Alfven, a 63-year-old Swedish physicist and Nobel laureate, was notified today that he had been granted the highest award of the Soviet Academy of Sciences in 1971 for "outstanding achievements in plasma physics and astrophysics."

Seymour Yusem's Dec. 23 letter tells Middle East history according to Zionist ideology rather than scholarly fact. Perhaps his most serious misstatement was that, at the turn of the century, "Palestine was virtually deserted."
A group of angry transit workers demonstrated outside the headquarters of the Transport Workers Union at 1980 Broadway yesterday against a tentative contract announced last Saturday.

Shortly before the turn of the year, William L. Safire, Special Assistant to President Nixon, told a New York Law Journal Forum that the first of the great changes he foresaw for 1972 would be "a growing awareness of the economic root of international power.
Albany's new tax and toll package is like a cat o' nine tails laid on the twitching backs of many daily commuters to Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- A State Department spokesman said today that no decision had been reached on providing additional United States assistance to refugees in India and the newly declared nation of Bangladesh.

The Indochina war has set in motion a wholesome and belated critique of the American Presidency. A direct product of this war is the proposed "War Powers Act of 1971," a bill designed to restrain the power of Presidents to carry the nation into undeclared hostilities.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- One of the misfortunes of those telephone calls from President Nixon to the football coaches is that we are told only part of what the President said and are left to imagine the rest of the conversation.

NEW DELHI, Wednesday, Jan. 5 (AP) -- A Pakistani Army officer killed a Pakistani major, the only other occupant of a two - seater reconnaissance plane, and flew the plane to India, news reports here said today.

HONG KONG, Wednesday, Jan. 5 (UPI) -- The Chinese Communist and the State Council have issued a joint call for greater efforts "to strengthen the unity between the army and the Government," the Chinese press agency, Hsinhua, reported today.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 4 -- A political conflict of national importance in the University of Chile found a compromise solution today that was hailed as a victory by the anti-Marxist academic forces.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Jan. 5 (AP) -- American helicopters supporting South Vietnamese troops in the Mekong Delta accidentally fired on Government forces, killing one soldier and wounding seven, the United States command disclosed today.

STOCKHOLM, Jan. 4 (Reuters) -- The Swedish Academy said today that it would present the gold medal and diploma for the 1970 Nobel Prize in literature to Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn at a private ceremony in Moscow in the spring.
Neil Shayne lost his suit yesterday to compel Nassau County to give his World Hockey Association franchise playing dates in the new Nassau Coliseum.

NEWARK, Jan. 4 -- A restraining order barring a landlord from raising his rents in violation of wage and price controls and from evicting a tenant who refused to pay the higher rent was signed here today.
Dr. Carl F. Hovde will resign at the end of the year as dean of Columbia College, the university's undergraduate school for men.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it had established a new system to measure the performance of specialists, the men at the center of the auction market whose role is to maintain fair and orderly trading in the stocks assigned to them.
Two new theater magazines, Performance and Scripts, published by Joseph Papp and the New York Shakespeare Festival, are now available at news stands and by subscription.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- In a major shift of policy, leaders of the National Conference of Catholic Charities said today that the organization planned to supplement its traditional social services with a new focus on political activism.
The unclogging of the Bruckner Interchange in the Bronx, widely regarded as the city's worst bottleneck, began yesterday as traffic moved for the first time on two of its new viaducts.

The mystery of how the Soviet trawler s'Andreyev incurred a 4-by-10-foot gash in her hull off New Jersey appeared cleared up yesterday when her captain told the Coast Guard that the vessel had collided with another Russian ship.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Daniel Ellsberg pleaded not guilty today to new Federal charges stemming from the Pentagon Papers case.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4--Administration officials said today that United States negotiators in Paris had never proposed a firm date for withdrawal from Vietnam in exchange for the release of American prisoners of war, but that they were convinced nevertheless that the North Vietnamese would reject such a formula.

SCRANTON, Pa. -- There are two pastors at the 600-member Trinity Congregational Church here. They take turns preaching on alternate Sundays, share the neighboring rectory and receive equal salary checks and pension payments. They also think alike on most subjects, although their approach is often quite different.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Investors Diversified Services, Inc., told the Securities and Exchange Commission today that if the commission insisted on continuing to set the price of the sales commissions on stock transactions it could hurt its own ability to regulate the securities business.
The Newport Jazz Festival, the first musical event of its kind in the United States, will move to New York City for the summer of 1972.
WASHINGTON, Jan 4 (AP) -- A physics journal has complained that no top Nixon Administration official "is qualified to function in top Government circles as a spokesman for the scientific community."

In this early post-devaluation period, we just cannot rely on a mechanical devaluation of the dollar and expect overnight miracles of balanced trade. The recent devaluation of about 8 per cent will just bring us back to a competitive situation of two years ago before domestic inflation accelerated.

HARTFORD, Jan. 4 -- Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, said yesterday that a former Connecticut insurance commissioner told him in early 1970 that the International Telephone and Telegraph Company had exerted political and economic pressures here to insure that its acquisition of the Hartford Fire Insurance Company, a $1.5-billion deal, would be approved.
McMURDO STATION, Antarctica, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Dr. Arthur L. DeVries would like to catch a codfish in the cold waters of the North Atlantic Ocean and give it a blood transfusion.

TRENTON, Jan. 4 -- State officials said today that the Federal Government had agreed to guarantee up to $50-million in initial financing for the construction of a community in the Hackensack Meadows in northern New Jersey.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 4 (Reuters) -- Reliable sources said today that unrest caused by reports of mass deportation of Iranians from Iraq had caused Premier Amir Abbas Hoveida to cancel a scheduled visit to the United States.
LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland, Jan. 4 (Reuters) -- Two shops were blown up in the center of Londonderry today after staff and customers had been given three minutes to get out.

TEL AVIV, Jan. 4 (Reuters) -- A police bomb-disposal expert was seriously injured here yesterday as parcels containing bombs, apparently sent by Arab guerrillas, continued to arrive in Israel from Europe, mainly Austria.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The Proprietary Association, representing 87 manufacturers who account for more than 90 per cent of over-the-counter drug volume said it generally approved of the plan.

Reflecting a fact of the last decade, LaRoche, McCaffrey McCall has officially changed its name to McCaffrey McCall. Chester J. LaRoche, who founded the C. J. LaRoche agency in 1946, retired from the business at the end of 1967, having turned over the direction of the agency five years before to a couple of young cats from Young Rubicam, James J. McCaffrey, now chairman, and David B. McCall, president.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (UPI) -- Samuel F. Yette, a Negro correspondent dismissed by Newsweek, today charged the magazine with racism and denial of free speech and press.

Lincoln Center's first Community Holiday Festival, which ended at Tully Hall last night with a Puerto Rican musical pageant entitled "The Night Before Epiphany," has been accounted a success by Lincoln Center officials, and they are already considering the possibility of having more of them.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5--The Food and Drug Administration proposed restrictions today on the use of hexachlorophene, an antibacterial chemical used in a wide variety of consumer products, ranging from soap to deodorant sprays.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -A committee of the National Academy of Sciences has concluded that the "rate of progress" in developing a clean automobile engine "makes it possible" that "the larger manufacturers" can achieve the drastic reduction in pollution from their 1975 models that is required by the Clean Air Act of 1970.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 5 -- British soldiers in Northern Ireland have been given new authority to shoot to kill.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -Three scientists will move into an undersea mobile home off the Florida Coast on Jan. 27 to begin a new research project of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Jan. 5 -- The New York Nets snapped out of their mid-winter thaw long enough tonight to defeat the last-place Carolina Cougars, 125-116, but they had to survive a barrage of "home runs" to do it.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Jan. 5 -- Former Senator Eugene J. McCarthy of Minnesota can run in the Illinois Presidential primary March 21 despite his refusal to sign a loyalty oath, the state electoral board ruled today.

LIMA, Peru, Jan. 5 (Reuters) The wreckage of an airliner missing since Dec. 24 with 92 persons aboard was found today in the north central Peruvian jungles. There was no sign of the additional survivors reported by a passenger who escaped.

In a move that will probably force the Federal Reserve to decide a controversial issue it has so far been able to avoid, a West Coast bank-holding company announced plans yesterday to acquire a savings and loan association.

Mario Lisanti, a tenor born and trained in New York who has sung here previously, came to Town Hall for a recital on Tuesday night. Accompanied by Mitchell Andrews, he offered a Program that included Schumann's "Liederkreis" and Menotti's "Canti della Lontanaza" in addition to songs by Arne, Falla, Rachmaninoff and Barber.

The new 50-cent weekly New York State lottery tickets went on sale yesterday with hopes that the reduced rates would increase lottery sales. The top prize will be $50,000, but a total of 1,000 winners across the state will be selected in the weekly drawings.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 5 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Lakers lost a 19-point lead tonight, then came back behind Wilt Chamberlain and Jim McMillian to outscore the Cleveland Cavaliers, 15-0, in a 6 1/2-minute stretch of the fourth quarter for a 113-103 victory, extendign their National Basketball Association record winning streak to 32 games.

NEWARK, Jan. 5 -- New Jersey's Consumer Affairs Director and Attorney General went to court today in an attempt to shut down operations of Glenn W. Turner's success motivation course, "Dare to Be Great," throughout the state.

Dr. Peter C. Goldmark, the man who at age 64 turned down $75,000 a year for 10 years with the CBS Laboratories division of the Columbia Broadcasting System, announced yesterday the start of a new career and a new company in conjunction with the Kinney Services, Inc.

The plan for the city to buy and renovate Yankee Stadium moved a step closer to realization yesterday as the City Planning Commission voted an urban-renewal designation for the ball park and adjacent parking areas.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- In a move to maintain an American military presence in the Persian Gulf area, the United States has entered into an unpublicized agreement to establish a permanent naval station on the island of Bahrain.

Prices of world No. 11 sugar futures rose nearly 0.4 per cent a pound on nearby contracts yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange with the report that the Agriculture Department had raised its 1972 domestic sugar marketing quota by 400,000 tons.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Jan. 5 -- When President Nixon meets with Premier Eisaku Sato of Japan here tomorrow and Friday, he will be talking with the leader of a restless, anxious nation that appears close to being distraught.

Of course, during the years, they have been the traditional victims of inflation; to them devaluation is about the last straw.

If the economy in 1972 works out the way most economists say it will, the year should be a very good one for the forest products industry.

Interco, Inc., the nation's largest shoe manufacturer, which also makes men's apparel and operates hardware and department stores, posted record sales and earnings in the fiscal year ended Nov. 30, the company reported yesterday. A team of researchers at the Mayo Clinic has reported feeding pills experimentally to four patients whose gallstones then dissolved or markedly without surgery.

The stock market rally took on new vigor yesterday as prices climbed sharply in the heaviest trading in two weeks.
The Long Island Rail Road yesterday made public a proposed new fare schedule, virtually certain to be approved, that would increase the cost of the average trip by about 20 per cent.

MANCHESTER, Vt., Jan. 5 -- Though the years ski Injuries have occurred most often on slopes and trails, frequently producing leg fractures. In many cases such mishaps have resulted from faulty ski equipment or just carelessness.

Cripples and prisons seem to be the major preoccupations of Harvey Perr's most interesting play, "Rosebloom," which opened last night at the Eastside Playhouse. It is a play that sounds as though parts of it had been written by a Jewish James Joyce, has in total been strongly influenced by Edward Albee and that takes a certain delight in theatrical devices of Pirandellian fancy.

Dawley, chairman and chief executive officer, will take a new post with responsibilities that will no longer require him to be involved in daily operations.

MONTPELIER, Vt., Jan. 5 -An easy victory has been predicted for Republican candidates in a special election to be held Friday to fill Vermont's seats in the United States Senate and the House.

CHICAGO -- Much of the rebellion that has occurred in recent years has been attributed to disenchantment with the life that has been shaped by advanced technology, but the problems of our society cannot be solved by wearing of love beads and reversion to the simple life of the pioneer or of Rousseau's "Noble Savage."

TOKYO, Jan. 5--The Cabinet approved today a draft budget for the 1972 fiscal year calling for total outlays of $37.24-billion. In terms of the yen, which was recently revalued, this is 21.8 per cent higher than the budget for the current fiscal year, which ends March 31.
George W. Schmidt, formerly a vice president of the Singer Company, has been named president and chief executive officer of the Duplan Corporation, effective Feb. 1.

LOS ANGELES -- What some people here swear is the most beautiful apartment in Beverly Hills belongs to Gant Gaither, producer, artist and author. He had lived in a Mediterranean-style villa on a hill in the Sunset Plaza area of Los Angeles. But following the death of a friend, Bradley Little who had been editor of the magazine Architectural Digest and shared the villa with him, Mr. Gaither sold it and moved to the apartment.

Members of the Uniformed Firefighters Association ratified a new 30-month contract yesteray that provides for pay increases totaling $2,150 during the life of the agreement.

ACCRA, Ghana, Jan. 5 -- Mrs. Richard M. Nixon came to this sultry West African republic today for the second stop in a handshaking tour that is showing increasing signs of being a big success.

" You can never get tired of chestnuts," says Lilly Joss Reich, a tiny, woman who is an unabashed nut about nuts. Mrs, Reich, whose husband, Richard, is a playwright, not only follows the standard Viennese practice of using ground chestnuts and other nuts instead of flour in pastry, but she has developed an entire repertory of dishes based on chestnuts. It includes everything from soup to, well, nuts.

Senator Edmund S. Muskie went home to Maine to declare himself a candidate for the Presidency. The accent on down-East hominess was no doubt intended to underscore the simplicity, calm and quiet dignity which Senator Muskie has made the basis of his political appeal.

Just like any other tourist in Florida, Willy Brandt, Chancellor of West Germany, took in the sights of Disney World at Orlando. He and his 11-year-old son, Matthias, were escorted through the amusement park by Mickey Mouse himself, who clutched Matthias's hand.
George Allen, who led the Washington Redskins to their best record in 26 years, was named coach of the year in the National Football League yesterday in The Associated Press poll.

John Havlicek of the Boston Celtics has gone from the best sixth man in pro basketball to the leading vote-getter of the National Basketball Association's East All-Star team, which was named yesterday.

Richard Nixon, the football strategist, favors the bomb with a down-and-in pattern and applauds the deception of the flanker reverse; Spiro Agnew is irrevocably committed to the shotgun attack; Edmund Muskie relies on the belly series; in long-yardage situations, George Wallace goes to the Statue of Liberty play; Gene McCarthy is strictly a Wishbone man, and Hubert Humphrey clings to the old Minnesota shift. After leading the $100,000 desperately not to get any Bowling Proprietor's Association of America United States Open tournament at Madison Square Garden for the last three days, Ernie Schlegel, a 29-year-old from Newburgh, N. Y., is trying rest.

The understandably reluctant decision of the State Legislature to impose $400 million in additional taxes brings New York to the end of a fiscal era. Tommy Hicks, a 27-year-old schoolteacher of retarded children in Ithaca, N. Y., knocked out Dennis McNamee of Pawtucket, R. I., in the 10th and final round of their light-heavy-weight fight at Madison Square Garden last night.

President Nixon has made a wise decision in authorizing the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to proceed with development of the space shuttle. There has been a lack of awareness that the textile and apparel trades are a good source of jobs, Lawrence F. Davenport, chairman of the National Advisory Council on Vocational Education, said here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- A black member of Congress enlisted the aid of the State Department today in seeking to make the South African Government reconsider its decision denying him a visa to South-West Africa.
Glasses aloft and tongue in cheek, the Millard Fillmore Birthday Party Society disported itself yesterday at its seventh-annual "Dutch treat luncheon" to salute the President with the "leastest."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The nation's job situation remained essentially unchanged in December, with both employment and unemployment showing minor increases, the Labor Department reported today.

The American Stock Exchange has issued its latest weekly report on changes in stock ownership by major stockholders, directors and officers of its listed companies. This week the New York Stock Exchange did not issue a report on insiders' trading.

The East New York Savings Bank has begun recently to offer and promote a new money-order service that provides its depositors with what amounts to a free checking account while they continue to earn 5 per cent interest on a day-to-day basis.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 7 -- In a game that the victors considered crucial for their National Basketball Association playoff hopes, the Philadelphia 76ers let a 13-point lead dwindle to 1 in the final two minutes, but hung on for a 117-113 triumph over the New York Knicks tonight before a crowd of 10,229 at the Spectrum.

Sugar futures prices dropped yesterday for the second day in a row after having advanced as much as 30 points (hundredths of a cent a pound). However, the trading was not so intense as during the previous day, when declines hit the daily limit of 50 points.

Mrs. Linda Childs Pearson, daughter of Mrs. Starling Winston Childs Jr. of New York and Norfolk, Conn., and the late Mr. Childs, was married in Sylney, Australia, yesterday to Peter Brock Quinnell, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. H. Quinnell of Sydney. The Presbyterian ceremony in the H.M.A.S Watson Memorial Chapel was performed by the Rev. Malcolm A. Spence, an Australian Navy chaplain.

Don Johnson of Arkon, Ohio, scored 10 victories in afternoon and evening matches and is only one game away from claiming the 18th victory of his career in the $100,000 United States Open Bowling tournament at Madison Square Garden.

School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner removed the acting director of the school system's bureau of educational research yesterday, a day after the Chancellor criticized a bureau report as "sloppy" workmanship.

RUSSELSHEIM, West Germany, Jan. 7 (UPI) -- A shortage of domestic orders is forcing Opel, the West German auto manufacturer owned by the General Motors Corporation, to shut down one of its three factories for the week from Jan. 24 to 28, the company said today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7 -- Lowell R. Beck is resigning as executive director of Common Cause, a national citizens' lobby, to become associate executive director of the American Bar Association, it was announced today.

The Timken Company, the nation's largest producer of roller bearings, had the best earnings in 1971 since 1966, according to its preliminary estimate yesterday day of $3.60 a share, up from the $2.69 earned in 1970.
ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Jan. 7 -- This steamy West African country gave Mrs. Richard M. Nixon a rousing welcome today.

I should like, however, to clarify certain key points in our plan.
Women's lib has begun to show up in the elementary grades.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (UPI) -- People throughout the world smoked more last year, the United States Public Health Service said today.

Abraham Hershkovitz, a former office manager of the Jewish Defense League, pleaded guilty yesterday to conspiring to bomb the Soviet Union's trade agency here last April 2 and was ordered deported to Israel.

The propriety of paying high salaries and fees to newsmen and performers in public television continues to vex the noncommercial medium at its point of greatest vulnerability -- the local station operation.

CALCUTTA, India, Jan 7 -- ''Fifty-thousand gone? Excellent! Wonderful! Keep it up!" shouted the refugee relief commissioner on the phone to one of his officers in charge of a sprawling refugee camp on the border.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Thirty-three of the nation's biggest corporations have promised the Price Commission that they will hold their average price increases to 2 per cent or less during the next 12 months, commission sources disclosed today.
ATLANTA, Jan. 7 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Lakers extended their record-shattering winning streak to 33 games tonight by routing the Atlanta Hawks, 134-90, in the National Basketball Association.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 7 (AP) -- President Salvador Allende Gossens today defied a congressional vote that suspended his close associate, Jose Toha Gonzalez, as Interior Minister by naming him Defense Minister instead.

NEW DELHI, Jan. 7 -- India and North Vietnam upgraded their diplomatic missions from consular to ambassadorial level today, signaling a further deterioration in relations between the United States and India.

ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- State Environmental Commissioner Henry L. Diamond today ordered the 240 uniformed enforcement officers of the department into retail stores across the state to check on possible sales of highphosphate detergents and improperly labeled detergents.
PALO ALTO, Calif., Jan. 7 -- Anthony J. Russo Jr., who is under indictment with Dr. Daniel Ellsberg on charges of divulging the Pentagon Papers, was married here tonight under bizarre circumstances.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Pentagon officials stressed today that plans to send United States warships more frequently into the Indian Ocean were announced several years ago but that their implementation had been deferred because of the Vietnam war.

Business wasn't too lively for David L. Pakter, a portrait painter in what he calls "the Renaissance manner." A couple of years ago, while waiting for the current modernistic mish-mash in art to pass, he began to think about going into design.

MOSCOW, Jan. 7 -- "Have a soybean," a United States Congressman said today, extending a glass of the roasted and flavored beans to Soviet officials as he made the rounds of Government offices to drum up trade.

WEST HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Jan. 17 -- Rick Barry scored 43 points tonight, including 19 in the final quarter, but the New York Nets still lost to the Denver Rockets for the third straight time this season, 107-104.
A fireman assigned to the fire prevention division here was arrested yesterday on extortion and bribery charges for allegedly taking $25 to overlook fire violations.

Chadbourn, Inc., announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement with a group of European investors to buy its approximate 81 per cent interest in HudsonTextilwerke, G.m.b.H., Stuttgart, West Germany, for more than $13-million in cash.
SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Jan. 7 -- Premier Eisaku Sato of Japan, with a smile, a bow and a handshake, boarded his helicopter and disappeared into the gray skies over the Western White House today.
RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Jan. 7 -- The Government announced tonight that the Shah of Iran would arrive here tomorrow for a day of talks on the situation in the subcontinent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- A Federal judge today ordered the National Bank of Washington, the United Mine Workers of America and two of its officers to pay $11.5-million in damages to the union's pension fund for misusing miners' money.
BONN, Jan. 7 -- Idle workers and stalled assembly lines at six major Volkswagen plants mirrored the unresolved malaise of West Germany's automotive giant and largest exporter this week.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Jan. 7 (UPI) -- Senator Edmund S. Muskie called today for a national "government in the sunshine" law so that the public will not have to depend on stolen secret papers to tell them what their President is doing.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 7 (UPI) -- An appeals court dismissed yesterday legal proceedings against United States District Judge R. Dixon Herman, removing an obstacle to the trial of eight persons charged with a kidnapping conspiracy involving Henry A. Kissinger. President Nixon's adviser on national security matters.

The world's biggest-ever bridge cruise, numerically speaking, departs from New York today. Three hundred sixty-five enthusiasts, one for each day of last year, sail on the Anna Maria bound for Caribbean.

MIAMI, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Two directors of the Bush Foundation of St. Paul have sued 10 other directors for $39.75-million, accusing them of stock manipulations and conflicts of interest in violation of Federal regulations.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the-counter market continued to move higher yesterday in active trading.
SPLIT, Yugoslavia -- Nikola Viceic is a master winemaker. On the island of Hvar, 2 1/2 hours by slow ferry from this Adriatic coast town, he watches over the quality of his wines.

BRUSSELS, Jan. 11 -- Two candidates for membership in the European Economic Community, Ireland and Norway, failed today after a frustrating dusk-to-dawn negotiating session to reach agreement with the bloc on the final terms for entry.

The National Collegiate Athletic Association's decision to allow first-year college students to play varsity football and basketball is merely the latest in a long string of surrenders to professionalism and 'commercialism in college sports. It is ironical that faculty representatives of major colleges who rammed this change through the recent N.C.A.A. convention should claim that the consequent elimination of freshman teams would save money.
MARIETTA, Ga., Jan. 11 (UPI) -- A special Cobb County grand jury ended a week-long investigation today by "exonerating" two Atlanta Falcon football players involved in a raid.

MOSCOW, Jan. 11 -- The decisions by East Germany and Bulgaria to recognize Bangladesh are expected here to be followed by similar action by the Soviet Government. There was no indication when this might happen.

A combination of flexed foot and pointed toe signaled the end of the "Nutcracker" season Tuesday night at the State Theater as the New York City Ballet went back into repertory with George Balanchine's "Japanese'' ballet, "Bugaku."

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 11 -- The United States command said today that a North Vietnamese missile site near Tchepone, deeper and farther south in the Laotian panhandle than one has ever been reported before, fired two surface-to-air missiles yesterday morning at an American fighter-bomber that was attacking enemy supply trails.

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Dick Van Arsdale sank two free throws after time had expired to give the Phoenix Suns, who had trailed by 17 points in the first half, a 115-114 victory over the Milwaukee Bucks tonight.

Rent Commissioner Benjamin Altman predicted yesterday that rents on New York City apartments covered by Federal guidelines "might well" increase by as much as 8.5 per cent, far above the 3 or 3.5 per cent originally predicted by the Federal Price Commission.

The Ampex Corporation, the largest producer of magnetic tape recording equipment, which is also involved in making computer memory systems, instrumentation recorders and other products, announced yesterday it would report a loss of approximately $40-million for its fiscal year ending April 29.

DACCA, Pakistan, Jan. 11, (Reuters) -- Sheik Mujibur Rahman, home in triumph from nine months of detention in West Pakistan, took over today as President of Bangladesh, a nation of 75 million people proclaimed by the Bengalis in what was East Pakastan.
NEWARK, Jan. 11 -- An amusement park will share a tract in the Hackensack Meaddows with the proposed new stadium for the New York football Giants.

Eight members of a New York City family headed South to spend the Christmas holidays in 1968 were awarded $750,000 in damages yesterday for injuries they sustained when their car collided with a tractor-trailer truck south of Washington. The car was demolished in the accident.
LONDON, Jan. 11 -- Prime Minister Heath shoved signs of irritation today at what he evidently considered to be belated intervention by Britain's allies in the Malta crisis.
A "Tribute to Dorothy Fields," which involved not only Miss Fields's songs but Miss Fields herself, was held on Monday evening at the Top of the Gate.

Theodore Schlesinger announced yesterday his resignation as chairman and chief executive officer of the Allied Stores Corporation, the country's second largest department store chain, effective Feb. 1. He will not reach the concern's mandatory-retirement age for more than a year.

The clutch part of the National Hockey League season -- the second half -- starts for the Rangers tonight at Chicago as they begin a six-game road trip that can go a long way in deciding the final standing in the East.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- East coast states were promised today that they would be consulted before any decision on whether to permit offshore oil drilling in the Atantic.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The remote town of Tchepone in the panhandle of southern Laos, now a bombed-out ruin, is a familiar place-name in the records of conflict in Indochina.

CORTLAND, N.Y., Jan. 11 (AP) -- Stockholders of Chris-Craft Industries voted today on slates of directors presented by company officials and a group of dissident shareholders, but official results of the balloting were not expected to be announced for 10 days.

Commercial freight on the historic New York State Barge Canal System dropped sharply in the 1970 and 1971 navigating seasons after having stayed at a fairly constant volume in the nineteen-sixties.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The Agency for International Development is lending $126,422 to provide a swimming pool filter system, a diving board, underwater lights and restaurant and bar equipment for a privately owned hotel in the Dominican Republic.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 11 -- Israeli forces killed three Palestinian guerrillas last night and destroyed a number of buildings, according to a military spokesman here. A Lebanese woman was also reported killed and her husband wounded.
A growing number of Broadway stage shows are offering three or more matinees a week, instead of the traditional two, in pursuit of larger box-office receipts.
A law providing $33-million in New York State funds to aid financially troubled parochial schools was declared unconstitutional here yesterday by a panel of three Federal judges.
A 19-year-old college sophomore apparently parlayed a persuasive voice on the telephone into a $200,000 stake in the stock market in December without ever putting up a penny in cash.

The chances for enactment at Albany of "no fault" automobile insurance now seem vastly improved if only because state legislators who have just had to vote higher taxes for reduced services need something positive they can boast about in an election year.
