Many restaurants here report an increase in business over the last two months following a two-year slump.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Mrs. Judy Dalton of Aus-Australia flashed an improved backhand today to eliminate Rosemary Casals from the $17,000 British Motors women's tennis tournament, 4-6, 6-0, 6-3.

ATHENS, Jan. 10 -- An informed Czechoslovak source has received word from reliable sources in Prague of two major series of political arrests in Czechoslovakia in the closing weeks of last year. The number of those arrested was put at several hundred.
Mack H. Schlesinger has been appointed senior vice president of the Palm Beach Company. He had been sales vice president since 1955.

In fashion's lexicon, classic is as much abused a term as elegance. It's applied to any style that's been around a couple of weeks. Last year, just before they perished, hot pants were being hailed as classics; a few months ago, it was long skirts that would live forever.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 13 -- Wally Wojdakowski scored a career-high 34 points to lead Army to a 104-92 victory over Colgate tonight. The 104 points were the most ever scored by an Army team.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The first words proclaimed by Senator Edmund S. Muskie after he handed a check for $500 to the New Hampshire Secretary of State last week to qualify as an entrant in the nation's first Democratic Presidential primary were, "Where's Squier?"

Giovanni Virginio Schiaparelli, the Italian astronomer, astonished the world almost a century ago by announcing that he had observed "canali" on Mars. Through mistranslation, his "canali" -- meaning channels or grooves -- entered English as canals, and that, in turn, sparked widespread speculation that they were the product of intelligent beings living on Mars.

State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz announced yesterday that 17 airlines had signed a court-approved agreement to install antipollution devices by Dec. 31, 1972, on jets equipped with Pratt and Whitney JT8D engines and using airports in the state.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 13 -- Jack Nicklaus, with a 66, led the opening round of the Bing Crosby tournament today in golf considered normal for him. But while the weather was delightful it wasn't regarded as typical. The three courses along the Pacific Ocean were dry from lack of rain, fog or snow that usually prevail at this event.
This latest round of ticket boosts on the New Haven Division of the Penn Central is simply incredible. [Editorial Jan. 10.]
L. W. Frohlich/Intercon, which is the largest advertising agency in the health and medical field, is up for sale.

Reflecting its net loss in the third fiscal quarter ended last November, the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company cut its quarterly dividend yesterday to 20 cents a share from 32 1/2 cents. It was the first time the company had reduced the dividend since it became publicly owned in 1959 when the directors initiated the payout at 20 cents a share.

MOSCOW, Jan. 13 -- A politically prominent Soviet writer was reported today to have suggested that Moscow would relax its restrictions on political dissidents and emigration if Western radio stations beamed toward the Soviet Union ceased what he described as anti-Soviet propaganda.
DETROIT, Jan. 13 -- Car sales for the Jan. 1-10 period were 2.9 per cent ahead of last year with 141,929 cars being sold this year compared with 137,961 cars for the same 10 days last year.

Methods for getting the body into shape and then keeping it there are virtually without number. Some demand that enough energy be expended to power a locomotive. Others require medication and a philosophical approach.

Transamerica Corporation, the multi-market service organization based in San Francisco estimates its 1971 earnings at about 94 cents a share, according to John R. Beckett, chairman and president, meeting here yesterday with securities analysts.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 13 -- A part-time soldier was shot and killed in Belfast today when a car drew up beside his truck and a gunman opened fire at point-blank range. He was the second civilian member of the Northern Ireland security forces to be killed within 24 hours.
OZARK, Ala., Jan. 13 (AP) -- A tornado smashed into two trailer parks and an Army airfield early today, leaving four persons dead and some 100 house trailers demolished or heavily damaged.
AL AIN, Abu Dhabi -- The nomadic tribes that used to roam this barren Arab sheikdom are being lured into Government jobs, trade, farming and the booming oil industry.
She likes walking on a beach before a storm, dining by candlelight in undiscovered restaurants and Johann Sebastian Bach -- she says.

Surveillance and enforcement throughout Wall Street are being strengthened as a result of the stock-market escapade of Abraham H. Treff, the 19-year-old college student who bought more than $200,000 in stock without putting up a penny in cash.
MIAMI, Jan. 13 (AP) -- A 35-foot sailing yacht that twice penetrated the restricted waters off President Nixon's private beach at Key Biscayne was seized today, Coast Guard spokesmen said.

Vital Statistics -- The Republic of Ghana, a nation of 92,099 square miles situated on the west coast of Africa, has a population of 8,545,561 people, chiefly of black Sudanese stock, whose per capita income is $262. The illiteracy rate is about 75 per cent, and the life expectancy is about 45 years.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 13 -- John Niland, the all-pro guard for the Dallas Cowboys, was becoming impatient today.
BOSTON, Jan. 13 -- Mayor Lindsay of New York entered the Massachusetts Presidential primary today and called it "the most crucial test of all" for his campaign.
The General Electric Company would neither confirm nor deny yesterday reports that it planned to move some of its transistor production to Dublin.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13--The Pay Board provided today for the recovery of frozen wage increases of up to 7 per cent, and in certain cases more. It also limited aerospace workers to first-year raises of no more than 8.3 per cent.
A suit seeking to halt publication of the purported autobiography of Howard R. Hughes was filed in Manhattan State Supreme Court yesterday on behalf of the billionaire industrialist.

In his Jan. 4 letter, Prof. Edward C. Devereux strives mightily to marshal reasons behind his stand against diverting any tax dollars to private or religious schools. But he argues in a vacuum. Upon reading his letter, a member of our parish church, whose children attend the parochial school, had this to say:
HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 13 -- When Senator Hubert H. Humphrey announced his candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination in Philadelphia on Monday, former Mayor James H. J. Tate was there.
Kipchoge Keino is back in the United States to celebrate a 32d birthday and "to see where I am" in a training program for the Olympic Games.
Bronx District Attorney Burton B. Roberts had 15-year-old Alexander Innis arrested yesterday for what he said was the youth's role in the kidnapping and beating of two fellow high school students.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The Nixon Administration today made a major effort to assure the Soviet Union that yesterday's incidents involving the detention in Moscow of a Congressman from New York City and the dispute over a Soviet student's leaving the United States had not diminished its interest in improving relations with Moscow.

A day-care crisis throughout the country and a "terrifying collection" of incidents of child abuse and neglect were reported yesterday by the National Council of Jewish Women after a study of nearly 700 day-care centers and homes serving 25,000 children.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- President Nixon is expected to announce shortly the appointment of Peter G. Peterson to succeed Maurice H. Stans as Secretary of Commerce.

An exchange of more than 50 shots among four plainclothes men and four men who opened fire on them early yesterday sent Andre L. Fraser, 25 years old, of 368 West 116th Street, to Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center with a head wound.

SAN DIEGO, Jan. 13 -- The New York Knicks, carrying a four - game losing streak, worked out this afternoon at International Sports Arena in preparation for their National Basketball Association game there tomorrow night against the Golden State Warriors.

In his letter of Jan. 5, Bruce Chasan tries to convince the reader that he brings "scholarly facts" versus "Zionist ideology." This is somewhat presumptuous. There are some elements of truth in his claims, as well as in those he challenges (Seymour Yusem's letter, Dec. 23).

Purple drama. Banana-peel comedy. Wry social comment. Realistic reporting. And all of it being filmed or edited by about 150 young devotees of filmmaking who are participants in the Film Club -- three narrow store-fronts on a dingy strip of Rivington Street between Chrystie Street and the Bowery.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The Nixon Administration made a relatively low-key response today to the Soviet Union's order expelling Representative James H. Scheuer.
Hiroko gave a little party to celebrate her first showroom recently. All her friends came wearing their newest Hiroko dresses, just as if it were a big couture opening.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- A group of women in the Department of Health, Education and Welfare made more than 100 recommendations today for improving the status of women both inside the department and in areas of national activity for which the department has responsibility.
PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 14 -- Tony Jacklin of England drew even with Jack Nicklaus today with a 70 and a 36-hole score of 140 in the Bing Crosby golf tourney.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 14 -- Peking has asked the United Nations to halt the economic help going to the Chinese Nationalist Government on Taiwan from the United Nations Development Program.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 14 (UPI) -- Mrs. Billie Jean King, two surprising Australians and a Briton make up the field for tonight's semifinals in the $17,000 British Motors tennis tournament at the Civic Auditorium.
Mayor Lindsay reported yesterday that more city-assisted housing was begun here during 1971 than ever before.

Newark's Planning Department has started exploring the feasibility of expanding the tiny rapid-transit system in Newark into the blighted heart of the city and redeveloping and revitalizing whatever route might be chosen for an extension.
Residents in the Forest Hills section of Queens had a new reason to be upset yesterday about a low-income housing project being built in their middle-income area.
Glamours, golds and airline stocks moved higher yesterday in a drifting market that produced a mild rally in the final half hour. The Dow-Jones industrial average edged up 1.50 points to 906.68.

The bitter conflict stirred by the Forest Hills public housing project raises grave questions of public housing policy. The problem is epitomized by Percy Sutton's question: "Where do black people and Puerto Rican people turn if they want to change their lives and not forever be restricted to the ghetto?"

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) The Agriculture Department issued today a revised report on 1971 crop production showing farmers last year harvested a record corn crop of 5,540,253,000 bushels, up 35 per cent from 1970.

The International Business Machines Corporation in 1971 registered its 20th consecutive year of increased profits and its second consecutive year in which net income from overseas exceeded earnings from the United States.
Cavenham, Ltd., announced yesterday in London that it is making a 82.5-million ($210,375,000) take-over bid for Allied Suppliers, Ltd., a British wholesale and retail grocery chain with 1,700 stores.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Jan. 14 -- For a couple of days in this quiet corner of Florida this week it seemed that Hubert H. Humphrey, one of the 10 or more Democratic candidates in the March 14 Presidential primary, was everywhere.

GROSSINGER, N. Y., Jan. 14 -- The first day of play in the Tri-State Regional Championships here yesterday provided some evidence that most bridge players have more enthusiasm for the game than for their regular occupations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The Deputy Secretary of Defense, David Packard, disagreed with Henry A. Kissinger's efforts during the height of the Indian-Pakistani war to aid the Pakistani cause, instead of remaining neutral, according to a newly published account of a secret White House strategy session.

The 11 New York City policemen who lost their lives last year while performing their duties were remembered by Mrs. Rose Zittwitz of this city as she contributed $10 to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 14 -- Premier Saeb Salam said that the Lebanese armed forces -- about 15,000 troops -- were placed on the alert today following the warning to Lebanon by General Elazar.

GENEVA, Jan. 14 -- The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, which broke off negotiations last night with the major Western oil companies, told them today that it would accept an 8.57 per cent increase in oil payments to make up for the devaluation of the dollar in December.

The singer - instrumentalist Buzzy Linhart, appearing at Folk City this week, does almost everything well. He sings the blues, he sings folk music, he scats jazz and plays the guitar, he pounds out drum solos and plays improvisations on the vibes. Multi-talented is a good description, but the old enigma of the jack-of-all-trades keeps rearing its ugly head.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 14 -- Israeli troops staged another reprisal raid into southern Lebanon last night, and the new Israeli Chief of Staff warned today that further reprisals would follow if Palestinian guerrillas were allowed to use Lebanese territory for continued raids on Israel.

Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy reported yesterday that the number of serious crimes committed in the city in November was 6.2 per cent less than a year earlier and said he was optimistic that the crime rate was slowly being reduced.
TEL AVIV, Jan. 14 -- (UPI) -- A mechanical failure at Tel Aviv's central power station blacked out most of Israel tonight for nearly two hours.

Last Wednesday proved a black day for the Soviet and American image makers who are trying to improve Moscow's public relations stance here. Soviet Culture Minister Yekaterina A. Furtseva, the highest ranking Soviet woman, was to hold a Washington press conference in connection with a Soviet art exhibition and to be the guest of honor at a State Department luncheon.

ACCRA, Ghana, Jan. 14 -- The army officers who took over this West African nation in a coup d'etat yesterday morning moved today to consolidate their controal amid signs that the quick, clean take-over had been widely successful.
A citywide ring that allegedly stole $3-million in automobiles in one year and then stripped down the cars and sold the parts on order was disclosed last night after four arrests in Queens.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The chairman of the Price Commission, C. Jackson Grayson Jr., said today that speculation by high Government officials about an early end to economic controls might be "damaging" to the entire stabilization effort.

MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 14 -- A judge in Minneapolis has ruled that "Brooklyn is not a desirable place for a child reared in Minnesota to grow up, even though the particular neighborhood proposed may be reasonably good."
WESTBURY, L. I., Jan. 14 -- Joeys Byrd registered his third straight victory of the season in taking the feature race at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.
BUDAPEST, Jan. 7 -- Fifteen years after the unsuccessful Hungarian uprising in Budapest, the nation seems to be moving steadily toward the liberal reforms that were crushed at the time.
DENVER, Jan. 14 -- The president of the American Horse Shows Association said today that the organization had sanctioned 959 events last year, the largest number in its 55-year history.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Wholesale prices resumed their rise as expected in December, the first full month after the freeze, the Labor Department reported today.

An international ring of counterfeiters specializing in the wholesale production of phony Omega watches so closely resembling the $150 to $2,500 originals that even jewelers were deceived was disclosed yesterday after two alleged leaders of the ring were arrested.

Striking telephone workers demonstrated again yesterday, protesting both what they called the company's failure to settle the six-month old dispute and the use of management personnel from other states to perform strikers' work.
Ten members of the World's End motorcycle gang of Ozone Park, Queens, were arrested yesterday on charges of burglarizing a Brooklyn warehouse of $340,000 worth of women's raincoats.
MIAMI, Jan. 14 -- Whipping around this town's palm-lined expressways, a gambler can't go more than a few miles without seeing an arrow pointing to a racetrack, a dog track or a jai-alai fronton.
NEW LONDON, Conn. Jan. 14 -- The General Dynamics Corporation announced today a cutback in its public-affairs staff in four major divisions and eight subsidiaries in the United States and Canada.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Jan. 14 -- King Frederik IX of Denmark died tonight at the Copenhagen municipal hospital. He was 72 years old.

BERKELEY, Jan. 14 -- A mother's basic personality type, rather than the fact that she smokes cigarettes, may be responsible for the excessively high incidence of low-birth-weight babies born to mothers who smoke, a professor of bio-statistics at the University of California has found.

SAN DIEGO, Jan. 14 -- Pulling away in the second half when Nate Thurmond, their center, started hitting from outside and Jim Barnett and Jeff Mullins, their guards, started driving through, the Golden State Warriors defeated the New York Knicks, 115-111, before a crowd of 6,304 at the Sport Arena tonight.

The seesaw war in Laos has annually brought a winter dry-season advance by the Communist forces toward the Government-held Mekong Valley along the Thailand border. Later, under pressure from American air power and air-supplied Lao and Meo ground troops, the Communists usually have pulled back again to shorter lines of supply in the rainy season, when mud and washouts have made a morass of ground routes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The State Department acknowledged today that an Air Force officer, serving as an assistant air attache at the United States Embassy in Moscow, was beaten by a group of civilians at the Riga Airport in Latvia on Jan. 5.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 14 -- Bob Heinz, the big Miami tackle who will be playing in the Super Bowl here on Sunday against the Dallas Cowboys, is going to get a clean game from his opponent across the scrimmage line, John Niland, who will be wearing a jersey one size too small for good reason.

The latest in the Museum of Modern Art's in-house exhibitions, a series of economically assembled shows of works owned by the museum, is "Naive Painting From the Museum Collection," a group of 30 canvases from the 100 or so it has in this charming genre.
The American Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter market yesterday resumed their recent upward trend as both lists gained in active trading.

BONN, Jan. 14 -- A series of spectacular escapes by East Germans across heavily guarded borders to the West in recent days and sharper than usual Communist protests have cast gloom on the prospects for upcoming negotiations between West Germany and East Germany, officials here maintain.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 14 -- All this week, in baking stadiums and sweltering auditoriums, 600,000 Brazilian students have been taking college entrance examinations to try to guarantee their chances for the good life.

BRUSSELS, Jan. 14 -- Norway and the European Common Market reached agreement tonight on the problem of protecting Norwegian fisheries after Norway joins the European group. At the same time, Ireland accepted a quota that will be applied to its sugar producers by the market.
The Most Rev. Michael Ramsey, Archbishop of Canterbury and Primate of All England, will preach at St. Patrick's Cathedral one week from tomorrow.

TRENTON, Jan. 14 -- The black liberation flag was pictured today as both an innocent symbol designed to inspire young black students to learn and the banner of black revolutionaries bent on fomenting trouble between whites and blacks in the Newark school system.

Even in infancy, Princess Margrethe was a special source of pride and an object of affection in Denmark. Her birth a week after the Nazi invasion in 1940 lifted hopes at home, and her early outings with her mother, Queen Ingrid, became a symbol of faith in the country and the royal family during the occupation.
Judith Norell, a harpsichordist who made her New York recital debut last April, returned to Carnegie Recital Hall for a second solo appearance on Thursday night.
ALBANY, Jan. 14 (AP) -- The State Board of Pharmacy today instructed pharmacies to comply with the Federal Price Commission's price-posting regulations.

I am very disappointed with what I see at Ithaca now. I graduated in June, 1970. Now everyone seems to be more serious, their lives are duller. Friends who were always willing to come over Friday night to drink wine and to watch a horror movie on television spend their time studying.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 14 -- The streetcar named Desire is now a bus, which explains much of what New Orleans is all about now.

PRINCETON, N. J. -- An author was once said to be qualified as an expert on murder and capital punishment because he had "talked with over one hundred murderers." I too have talked with over a hundred murderers. Therefore, I submit that I too am an expert on murder and capital punishment.

BRUSSELS, Jan. 14 -- The dollar came under pressure in nearly all the major financial centers of Europe today, while the United States and the Common Market completed a second round of trade talks with both sides reporting progress.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The Atomic Energy Commission announced today plans for building the nation's first large fast breeder nuclear power plant as the first major step in a multi-billion-dollar program aimed at meeting American energy demands well into the 21st century.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 14 (AP) -- A United States jet fighter-bomber attacked a mobile enemy-missile unit today only three miles north of the demilitarized zone, which straddles the border between the two Vietnams.

On Jan. 4, the U.S. Military Command in Saigon announced that one American G.I. was killed and fourteen were wounded in a firefight with the enemy near Fire Support Base Mace. The soldiers were on a routine patrol when the attack occurred.

The constructionist Naum Gabo said that the content of his sculptures lay in themselves, devoid of outside references. The same could be said for the metal creations of Kenneth Snelson, a contemporary constructionist whose frameworks of anodized aluminum tubes held in space by stainless steel cables are familiar.

Nine former shareholders of the Tsai Management and Research Corporation, investment adviser to the Manhattan Fund, have agreed to pay $1-million in stock of the CNA Financial Corporation to the mutual fund in settlement of suits against the management company by six stockholders of the fund.

The Aetna Life and Casualty Company, in a major revamping of its top executive echelon, yesterday named John H. Filer, a 47-year-old executive vice president, to become the company's new chairman and chief executive officer, effective July 1.
In an attempt to slow the rise of raw-sugar prices, the Agriculture Department ordered yesterday a 200,000-ton expansion of its 1972 sugar-marketing quota, to 11.8 million tons.
PARIS, Jan. 14 -- Anti-racket squads have started cracking down on a flourishing business in France of supplying false invoices to industrialists to bilk the tax authorities.

A call for the restoration of a law requiring New York City policemen to live in the city was among five resolutions passed yesterday at the close of a three-day seminar on black and Puerto Rican policemen and minority communities.
The First National City Bank announced yesterday it would cut by one-half per cent to 4 per cent the rate it pays on regular savings accounts, effective Feb. 1.

A preliminary report of the Surgeon General's study of the effect on children of violence on television has predictably run into immediate controversy. The issue is understandably emotion-charged. Parents who see the blood and gore to which their children are so regularly exposed form their own strong views entirely independent of any scientific studies.

Dr. Robert R. Gilruth, head of the space agency's Manned Spacecraft Center in Houston from its inception through five moon landings, has turned over the post to Dr. Christopher C. Kraft Jr., the crisp-voiced flight director of America's early manned missions.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 14 -- Rhodesia's African National Council, which is campaigning for rejection of the proposed terms for settlement of the British-Rhodesian dispute, denied tonight that it was in any way connected with recent disturbances that culminated in the killing of an African and wounding of nine others at the asbestos mining town of Shabani on Wednesday.

A graduate student in advanced chemistry at Adelphi University was held yesterday in $250,000 bail on charges he planned to blow up a Defense Department facility in Garden City, L. I., to protest "the continuing war in Vietnam."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- When President Nixon looks to Congress for support of his legislative program he obviously cannot count too much on the New Yorkers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Chemical links between three types of human cancer and three viruses known to cause comparable types of cancer in animals have been found by a team of scientists at Columbia University.
NEWARK, Jan. 14 -- Ron Porambo, a television reporter and author of a book about the 1967 race riots here, was shot and wounded in both thighs here early this morning.

LONDON, Jan. 14 (Reuters) -- New moves by Britain's 280,000 striking coal miners today threatened fuel supplies to about 30 major power stations generating electricity for millions of homes in London and southeast England.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- A merger agreement has reportedly been reached by the teamsters and the West Coast longshoremen's union.

LONDON, Jan. 14 (UPI) -- The reaction to the South African readmission was swift and divided. In Johannesburg, Owen Williams, the tennis promoter, said he was "delighted" and the president of the South African Lawn Tennis Union, Alf Chalmers, said any nonwhite player in South Africa would be given a chance to win a spot on the team.

Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy denounced the Civil Service system yesterday as a "handcuff" inhibiting the promotion of strong leaders to the rank of captain and announced that he had instituted a six-month probationary period for sergeants, lieutenants and captains.

A 23-year-old narcotics addict described by defense and prosecuting attorneys as a "sick" man who "needs treatment" was sentenced in a Bronx court yesterday to a maximum penalty of 30 years in prison for selling one-seventy-third of an ounce of heroin last summer to police undercover agents.

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- The British Broadcasting Corporation has begun a 13-part television series on the British Empire -- a half-proud, half-mocking look at Britain's imperial past -- with high hopes that it will be as well received and as widely seen in the United States as its "Civilisation" and "Forsyte Saga" series.

ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, Jan. 14 (Reuters) -- The Yugoslav Republic of Croatia announced the formation of a new government tonight and a purge of the judiciary following charges of counterrevolutionary activity in the republic, the official press agency Tanyug reported.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 14 -- Ten months and a week after clearing his title to the heavyweight championship of the world by whipping Muhammed Ali in one of the gaudiest promotions ever, Joe Frazier returns to the ring tomorrow night to play second fiddle to a pair of football teams.
COLLEGE PARK, Md., Jan. 14 -- Almost effortless, without serious speed or stamina workouts, Kipchoge Keino shattered 4 minutes in the mile for the first time indoors tonight.
At least five persons and perhaps more, the police now believe, shot and killed two city patrolmen outside the Colonial Park housing project in Harlem last May 29.

The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation reported yesterday declines in earnings before securities transactions for the fourth quarter and for the year ended Dec. 31, compared with results for the corresponding periods a year ago.
MOSCOW, Jan. 14 (AP) -- The Soviet secret police have arrested 11 Ukrainians apparently on suspicion of nationalist activity, reliable sources said today.
JANESVILLE, Wis. -- January is the valley of winter, a depression in the year when the northern earth lies dead, buried in the clammy grip of snow and ice.

To prevent the state's private universities from being priced out of the market, their leadership has demanded that stiff tuition charges be imposed on students in New York's public colleges. Your Dec. 21 editorial "Universities in Jeopardy" properly pointed out that the imposition of heavy costs on public college students would place an intolerable burden on middle- and lower-class families and would do little to spur private college enrollment.

Clock collectors will be tempted to apply press-agent superlatives to the exhibition on view at the Metropolitan Museum of Art under the properly intellectual title "Northern European Clocks in New York Collections."
American Ballet Theater's new production of "La Fille Mal Gardee" suffers from a total lack of subtlety but also makes quick recovery through the actual performances by its dancers.
BOSTON, Jan. 14 -- Judge Edward J. DeSaulnier Jr., denying that he was guilty of accepting a bribe, resigned today from the Massachusetts Superior Court.

DACCA, Pakistan, Jan. 14 -- Sheik Mujibur Rahman, Prime Minister of the Bengali regime that has taken over East Pakistan, declared today that "I have strong resentment against the American Government" for its support of the Pakistanis against whom his people rebelled.
NASHVILLE, Jan. 14 -- Purchase of The Nashville Banner, a six-day-a-week afternoon daily, by the Gannett news paper chain was announced to day by Banner and Gannett executives.

Edward Bennett Williams, the trial lawyer who has defended several major figures, including James R. Hoffa, will represent Judge Otto Kerner in his trial on charges of income tax evasion, conspiracy, mail fraud, bribery and perjury.

OAKLAND, Calif. (AP), Jan. 14 -- Warren Wells, former wide receiver of the Oakland Raiders, was returned from state prison today and placed on three-year probation. Superior Court Judge Leonard Dieden said Wells, as a condition of probation, would be committed for an indeterminate period to the Oakland facility of Synanon, a drug and alcoholic rehabilitation center, and would not be permitted to quit the program.

EDLINGTON, England, Jan. 12 -- In the workingmen's club along Bungalow Road, opposite Jim's Bingo and the pinball machines in Penny Lane, the miners and some of their wives gathered for another session of beer, darts, talk and laughs.

ESSEN, West Germany, Jan. 14 -- A long-running, behind-the-scene feud between two top managers of the Krupp industrial empire has finally erupted in the open with an announcement by Gunter Vogelsang, the concern's managing director, that he will leave his one million mark-a-year post at the end of 1972.

Effective today, 120,000 household workers in New York State come under a new minimum-wage law and must be paid at or above the state's hourly minimum of $1.85 -- $14.80 for an eight-hour day or $74 for a 40-hour week.
HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Jan. 14 -- Suffolk County's Labor Commissioner today announced a new Federal emergency appropriation to fight unemployment here and then bitterly attacked it as too small.

BOSTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Noam Chomsky, professor of linguistics at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and Ralph Stavins of the Institute of Policy Studies, filed motions in Federal court today seeking to bar their appearances before a grand jury next Tuesday investigating the distribution of the Pentagon papers.

OTTAWA, Jan. 14 (Canadian Press) -- There was a net inflow of $76-million into Canada in the three months ended Sept. 30, 1971, in international trading in long-term portfolio securities, the Canadian statistics Bureau responded today. This was an increase from an inflow of $43-million in the second quarter of 1971, and in sharp contrast to an outflow of $159-million in the third quarter of 1970.
The head of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association disclosed yesterday that a traffic-ticket quota system had been established in a West Side precinct.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Jan. 14 -- Judy Schwomeyer of Indianapolis and Jim Sladky of Solvay, N. Y., moved steadily toward their fifth straight gold dance title in the United States championship. But, unlike other probable figure-skating champions, they will not compete in the Olympic Games.

MOSCOW, Jan. 14--The Soviet Government ordered the expulsion of Representative James H. Scheuer of the Bronx today, accusing him of "improper activities." The United States promptly termed the action a "grave step not helpful to relations."

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 14 -- Lawrence F. O'Brien, the Democratic National Chairman, opened today a frontal assault on the Presidential candidacy of Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama, all but reading him out of the party.
Two patrolmen subdued an 18-year-old girl who they said had attempted to shoot them with a pencil gun near the women's room in the emergency ward of St. Clare's Hospital.
In a program honoring the memory of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., his widow, Mrs. Coretta King, told inmates of the Adolescent Remand Shelter on Rikers Island yesterday:

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 14 -- Six persons were reported wounded early today in a shooting incident as the campaign for Sunday's legislative by-elections drew to a close.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Senator Edmund S. Muskie's bid for the Democratic Presidential nomination will be endorsed Monday by three United States Senators and by three leading Democrats in Ohio.
HARTFORD, Jan. 14 -- Unemployment in Connecticut dropped in December to its lowest point in 1971, the state Labor Department reported today in a year-end economic review.

In his four terms as Representative from the Bronx, James H. Scheuer has established a number of political hallmarks, among them gregariousness, boundless enthusiasm and virtually nonstop ruminations about issues he has become interested in.
Thomas G. Labrecque, 33 years old, has been promoted to senior vice president in the portifolio and investment banking department of the Chase Manhattan Bank, N.A.
An instrumental trio from Boston called Rhythm served up a mixture of jump and soul at the weekly session of Jazz Adventures yesterday afternoon at the Maisonette of the St. Regis-Sheraton Hotel.

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- South Africa, barred from the Davis Cup tennis competition for the last two years, was readmitted today and organizations opposed to the country's policy of racial segregation (apart-heid) announced immediately that demonstrations would be mounted at matches involving the South Africans.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 17 -Tom Landry, the coach of the Super Bowl champion Dallas Cowboys, indicated today that Duane Thomas would be traded if the controversial running back insists on maintaining his virtual silence and aloof attiude.

MOSCOW, Jan. 17 -- The Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia today accused members of a group of Congressmen, including Representative James H. Scheuer of The Bronx, of subversive activities while on an official tour of educational institutions.
LONDON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- The dollar slumped to new lows in Europe today amid signs that devaluation a month ago had failed to restore confidence in the currency.
The Association of Philippine Coconut Desiccators convened a two-day symposium, a kind of coconut convention, in the Plaza Hotel yesterday.

A filmed documentary on Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. will be offered to television stations around the country for presentation by the highest bidders during the week of April 2. The entire proceeds from the sale of the film will go to a memorial fund for the slain civil-rights leader headed by his widow, Mrs. Coretta King.
The case of four young men accused of having killed a Harlem shopkeeper in April, 1964, is expected to go to the jury this week.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 17 -- Representative Scheuer said in a telephone interview in Belfast tonight that the Izvestia accusations were "absolute malarkey."

MADRID, Jan. 17 -- Official United States support for the Spanish regime and neglect of the Spanish democratic opposition was sharply criticized today by the chairman of a House Foreign Affairs subcommittee.

The New York Times has belatedly received a copy of a letter made public 10 days ago telling of the placement of longfuse time bombs in safe deposit boxes in nine banks in New York, Chicago and San Francisco.
MOSCOW, Jan. 17 -- Andrei D. Sinyavsky, the literary critic and author sentenced in 1966 to seven years at hard labor, has reportedly been quietly allowed to return to Moscow.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -Americans spent over $75-billion on their health care in the fiscal year 1971 at a rate of increase that was double that of both the cost of living and the gross national product.

TORONTO, Jan. 17 -- The Ontario Securities Commission received today insider trading reports from 18 officers or directors of Kaiser Resources, Ltd., a British Columbia coal mining venture, and its parent, the Kaiser Steel Corporation of Oakland, Calif.

GENEVA, Jan. 17 (AP) -- A church relief official reported today that about 200,000 Bengali wives who were raped by Pakistani soldiers during the war in East Pakistan last month were now ostracized by the Moslem communities and had virtually no place to turn to.

Deltec International, Ltd., engaged in investment banking, meat packing and sugar mills, expects to be in the black in its first fiscal quarter, ended Dec. 31, Clarence Dauphinot, president, told shareholders at yesterday's annual meeting here. In the corresponding three months last year the company had a loss of $2,234,000 on revenues of $4,852,000.

White House Press Secretary Ronald L. Ziegler says President Nixon is working on the fifth or sixth draft of his State of the Union Message, and no wonder. If history is a guide, that message ought also to provide his basic platform for re-election.
Your Dec. 28 editorial on "The Farm Revolution -- II" is right on.

The "Limited Gross Agreement,'' under which Broadway producers may obtain financial and working concessions from labor unions and the Dramatists Guild provided that the weekly grosses for their shows are limited to $25,000, has been extended through June 30 of this year.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -President Nixon enters his campaign for re-election with all the advantages of incumbency but still burdened by the fact that he is a minority President leading a minority party.

Two men accused of bribing three policemen in connection with an East Harlem murder were held without bail yesterday in State Supreme Court here after the judge was told that "the District Attorney is concerned about the security of his witnesses."
TRENTON, Jan. 17 -- The New Jersey Supreme Court struck down the state's death penalty today.
PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 17 -- A strike deadline set for this morning by the 268-member teachers union against eight public schools here was postponed today for 24 hours.

To the surprise of some startled store managers, the state began yesterday to enforce its new law limiting the amount of phosphate allowed in detergents.

Jerome Robbins's "The Concert'' is a genuinely funny ballet, and Todd Bolender is a witty and amusing dancer. The two were reunited Sunday afternoon at the State Theater in a hilarious performance of the work as Mr. Bolender paid a guest visit to New York City Ballet.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -A House Judiciary subcommittee, in a unanimous report, declared today that the Justice Department had not properly enforced the Federal Voting Rights Act in 26 Mississippi counties to prevent discrimination against black voters.

Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy's denunciation of the Civil Service system last week as inhibiting the promotion of strong senior officers was criticized yesterday by a former high-ranking police official and lauded by a high suburban police commander.

PARIS -- Eugene Ionesco, a dean of the Theater of the Absurd and a freshman in the Academie Francaise, is about to unveil his 16th or 17th play -- he is not sure which. In keeping with his new dignity, he calls it a melodrama of classic inspiration, but in keeping with his profound pessimism, it is also a horror comedy about the tyranny of power, as "Rhinoceros" is about the tyranny of conformism.
TORONTO, Jan. 17 -- A panel of six Americans who described themselves as "war resisters in Canada" said today that they opposed "the current 'amnesty' proposals in the United States."

WESTBURY, L. I., Jan. 17 -Baldridge Lobell closed with a rush to win the $6,000 Bellaire Pace tonight at Roosevelt Raceway. The margin was a nose over Shiaway Frosty, who took the place by a nose over Candios.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 17 -- The dustoffs, unarmed Army helicopters that evacuate wounded American and South Vietnamese soldiers while giving them emergency treatment, will be in Vietnam as long as there are any United States troops here.

The Southern Railway Company announced yesterday that it had reached an understanding looking toward a tax-free acquisition of the Norfolk Southern Railway Company, one of the few remaining independent carriers in the South.

Pop music and a symphony orchestra met head-on Sunday night at Carnegie Hall in a program titled "Symphonic Soul." If everyone came out of the encounter a bit battered musically, they also managed to produce some pleasant sounds.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 17 -- For the last half-dozen years there was a strong belief in many areas that the Dallas Cowboys were the best team in football. But no one could prove it because the bottom kept falling out of every argument since the team from Texas lost each convincer. On at least two occasions the frustration struck in closing seconds and Dallas was labeled a choke-up club that folded under pressure.

CAIRO, Jan. 17 -- Egypt's official spokesman indicated a sharpening hostility toward the United States today as the country's new Premier, Dr. Aziz Sidky, put together a Cabinet for mobilization of the home front and intensive economic development.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 17 -Roger Staubach brought a new dimension today to the image of a Super Bowl star -a "square" dimension.
For 10 days earlier this month, a large yellow and orange poster outside the Museum of Contemporary Crafts proclaimed: Ideas Wanted.

And it could have been worse.

January 15, 1918. An isolated airfield in France, far behind the front lines. Maj. Stanley Woolley, the 23-year-old leader of Goshawk Squadron, R.F.C., sits on a deckchair watching his 12 SE5a biplanes -"squared-off machines with wings like box kites and tails like weather-vanes" -- straggling in to land.

Northwestern Financial Investors, a new real estate investment trust, yesterday offered 1.35 million units, consisting of one share of beneficial interest plus one warrant, at $20. Shields Co. and Wheat, First Securities managed the syndicate.

The Greenwich Savings Bank, one of the oldest and largest banks in the U. S., has elected William S. Brennen, its president, to the additional posts of chairman of the board and chief executive officer. He succeeds Earl Harkness, who retires after 29 years of service but continues as a consultant.
JERUSALEM, Jan. 18 -Seventy-five years after Theodor Herzl assembled a band of Jewish idealists in Switzerland for the first Zionist congress, Zionism has become many things to many people.

GRINDELWALD, Switzerland Jan. 18 -- The Olympic torch went out for two more skiers today.

That part of the Rockefeller tax package that has received the most publicity, i.e., the 2.5 per cent surcharge, is peanuts compared with another feature which has hardly come to public attention. Elimination or the statutory tax credit will hit the small wage earner much harder than the surcharge will and represents a gigantic tax increase for those least able to afford it.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 18 -- Gloria Swanson did a lunchtime guest shot at the Actors Fund Home here today. Her visit was something of a cross between a reunion with near-contemporaries and a health department inspection.

VIENNA, Jan. 18 -- Walter Dejaco, who designed and built the gas chambers and cremation furnaces in AuschwitzBirkenau, the largest Nazi death camp in occupied Poland, went on trial before an Austrian jury here today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -The Treasury's top monetary official said today he saw no reason for concern at the recent weakening of the dollar against some foreign currencies in the foreign exchange markets.
The former director of the Municipal Loan Fund and seven borrowers have been indicted by a New York County grand jury.

ALBANY, Jan. 18 -- In his State of the State message to the Legislature today, Governor Rockefeller proposed three major programs -- no-fault automobile insurance, crime control through court reform and a plan for increasing electrical power supplies in the state -as part of his 1972 priority legislative package.

The stock market surged ahead yesterday in active trading and closed with solid and widespread gains.

William L. Waller was sworn in yesterday as Mississippi's 56th Governor in ceremonies on the steps of the Capitol in Jackson. He promised a progressive administration aimed at giving the Magnolia State a new measure of national prominence.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (UPI) -- Republicans struck back today at Senator Edward M. Kennedy for his attack yesterday on President Nixon and his record.

ALBANY, Jan. 18 (UPI) -- A Lewis County pair won one of two $100,000 top prizes in the final $1 state lottery ticket drawing.
COMPTON, Calif. -- Once they called this city the Hub. Little signs around the town boasted of it. Politicians always said it. And just about everyone believed it.

The three executors of the estate of the late Mark Rothko, the abstract expressionist painter who committed suicide in 1970, responded yesterday to a petition charging that they conspired with a prominent art gallery to "defraud" and "waste the assets of" the artists estate.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-thecounter market continued to move higher yesterday in very active trading.

New York City -- Governor Rockefeller proposed "new structure and government" for the city, alleging that "as things now stand there is no actual control over the functioning of city government despite the almost total centralization of power in City Hall."

WESTBURY, L. I., Jan. 18 -A record superfecta of $13,680 featured the proceedings at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. John T. Ace finished first in the eighth race, the event on which the superfecta is based. His win price was $26.60 and he was driven by Robert Bostic.

It is slightly more than 20 years since Leonard Rose left the New York Philharmonic and struck out on a career as a solo cellist, chamber musician and teacher. By now, Mr. Rose is a fixture of our concert scene.
ATHENS, Tex., Jan. 18 -- Representative John Dowdy, Democrat, bowed out of elective politics today when he wrote friends he would not be a candidate for re-election. He is completing his 11th term.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 Reuters) -- The chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, Preston Martin, outlined today a $2-billion purchase program for conventional mortgages to accommodate sellers of non-guaranteed, non-insured mortgage loans.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Jan. 18 -- Blending the styles of shrewd diplomat, benevolent despot and circus barker, Zulfikar Ali Bhutto has showered a glittering trail of oratory across Pakistan during his first month as President, hoping to breathe life into a demoralized nation.
If you want to become an instant publisher in the mass magazine field why don't you talk to Robert A. Joyce. No. You better wait a couple of years in case his idea doesn't work.
A book publisher was temporarily enjoined yesterday in State Supreme Court from distributing a purported autobiography of Howard R. Hughes pending a hearing later in the week.

DACCA, Pakistan, Jan. 18 -- The International Rescue Committee, a private American relief organization, has made plans to spend a million dollars and possibly more to help the Bengali intellectual community recover from the shattering effects of the struggle against West Pakistan.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The Pacific Maritime Association reversed itself today and ordered its member shipowners to begin handling military cargo immediately at struck West Coast ports, according to Edmund Flynn, president of the association.

A full house at the Brooklyn Academy of Music was on hand Tuesday night to applaud the Murray Louis Dance Company and the Alwin Nikolais Dance Theater. It was the first time the two dance groups have appeared on the same program.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The Government's Committee on Interest and Dividends said today it "expects lenders to be aggressive in passing on promptly to the borrower the benefits of reduced costs of funds available in the credit markets."
Lee Trevino, a professional golfer whose style is unorthodox, was selected yesterday as the Male Athlete of the Year by The Associated Press.

Joseph A. Beirne, president of the Communications Workers of America, told union officials representing the state's 35,000 striking telephone craftsmen yesterday that contract proposals advanced by the New York Telephone Company Jan. 7 were "so meager they were rejected out of hand."

Mrs. Veroni Sandstrom of Solna, Sweden, has her own ideas of breeding. "You cannot be kennel-blind," she said. "You must be able to see the faults in your own dogs and then strive to correct them." Mrs. Sandstrom can speak with authority for she has been breeding dachshunds for more than half a century.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- More than 40 per cent of the rental housing and three-fourths of the retail establishments in the country were freed from economic controls by the Government today.

" Vivat! Vivat Regina!", which opens tonight at the Broadhurst Theater, is Robert Bolt's first play on Broadway since "A Man for All Seasons" in 1961. Both are historical dramas about larger - than - life figures.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Black Jack, the spirited, rider-less horse that followed the coffin of John F. Kennedy to the grave and symbolized the lost young leader to millions of watching Americans, dominated his birthday party today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19 -- Three Democratic Presidential candidates were given a chance today to win some of the 170 Illinois delegates to the Democratic National Convention as filings closed for the March 21 primary.
James M. (Ding) Schoonmaker 2d of Miami, who posted five straight victories in the pre-Olympic Star Class regatta in Kiel, Germany, has been named the Martini Rossi yachtsman of the year for 1971.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Jan. 19 (UPI) -- The corrections director of Florida, in an unprecedented and probably illegal move, refused today to admit any new convicts into the state prisons because of overcrowding.

NEWARK, Jan. 19 -- James Schofield, president of Local 8 of the International Pressmen's Union, said today that members had overwhelmingly turned down a proposed agreement under which some pressmen formerly employed by The Evening News of Newark would work for The Newark Star-Ledger.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 19 -- Seton Hall, trailing by 17 points late in the opening half, pulled to within three points in the closing minutes of the game before bowing to Fordham University, 81-74, before 3,200 fans in Walsh Auditorium tonight.
ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- The State University Construction Fund today announced the suspension of 150 projects valued at $215-million involving classroom space and dormitories.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- When President Nixon sets foot in Peking on Feb. 21, his historic step will be televised instantly -- via a $1.6-million trailer in the Chinese capital, an Intelsat satellite in the Pacific sky, a communications station in Jamesburg, Calif., and a transcontinental cable to New York -- into millions of American living rooms.
GRINDELWALD, Switzerland, Jan. 19 -- The United States Alpine skiing team may have set a Winter Olympic record today when it named three members of the same family to compete in the Games next month.

Three utilities in Michigan, Minnesota and Idaho announced yesterday plans for spending more than $700-million on expansion budgets this year.
VIENNA, Jan. 19 (UPI) -- Two Austrian architects who built the Auschwitz gas chambers in which three million Jews died testified today that they did not know what the buildings were to be used for.

DACCA, Pakistan, Jan. 19 -- Earth is freshly turned and the fields are planted with rice. Agile village men can again be seen in the tops of the coconut palms, legs wrapped around the trunks, as they tap the sap to make palm toddy, a potent country liquor.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Legislation to impose the first Presidential campaign spending limits in history was approved by the House today and sent to President Nixon. The vote was 334 to 19.

MONTREAL, Jan. 19 (UPI) -- Pete Mahovlich scored with two seconds left to play tonight to give Montreal a 1-0 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs and extend the Canadiens' unbeaten home string to 21 games this season in the National Hockey League.

The olive-drab dormitory is once again the order of the day.

SEA BRIGHT, N. J., -- A recent survey of marinas at Sandy Hook indicates that dock space is scarce, slips 90 per cent rented for the 1972 season and expanding facilities in the area not enough to keep up with increasing demands.

WASHINGTON Jan. 19 -- A spokesman for the Pentagon declined today to comment on renewed charges that the Army had covered up the massacre at Mylai in South Vietnam in 1968. Jerry W. The United States, which has yet to win, will challenge Australia for the International Catamaran Challenge Trophy starting Feb. 12 in Victoria, Australia. Contested in Class C catamarans, the four-out-of-seven series, known as the Little America's Cup, will be a match race between Weathercock of the United States and an Australian boat yet to be chosen.

Santa Fe Industries, Inc., the parent holding company of the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway, reported yesterday that its net income for 1971 fell to $33,143,000, or $1.31 a share, from $40,216,000, or $1.59 a share, in the preceding year.
A series of three Tully Hall recitals by pianists who teach at Indiana University -- Sidney Foster, Abbey Simon and Jorge Bolet -- began Tuesday night with the appearance of Mr. Foster.

HONG KONG, Tuesday, Jan. 20 -- Chi Peng-fei, a former army medical officer who became a diplomat, has been appointed China's Foreign Minister. He succeeds Chen Yi, who died in Peking earlier this month at the age of 71.

For some weeks, Senator Jacob K. Javits had been ballyhooing his intention of making the Navy unhappy by nominating the first female midshipman for the Naval Academy at Annapolis. Only this week Mr. Javits announced he would make his nominee's name known next Tuesday, and her identity was shrouded in secrecy.

RICHMOND, Jan. 19 -- A United States District Court judge here denied today county and state requests to delay implementation of his order for consolidation of predominantly black Richmond public schools with those of the predominantly white schools in two of the city's suburban counties.

Nina, a schooner that won the 1928 trans-Atlantic race to Spain and numerous other ocean races, has been purchased by two families and a bachelor from Long Island. They plan to use the yacht for world travel.
The conclusions of the Surgeon General's report on the effects of TV violence on the behavior of children (why only children?) raise more questions than they answer. [Editorial Jan. 15.]

Failure to take a decision for war or peace with Israel in December at the end of his much-advertised "year of decision" has confronted President Sadat of Egypt with a problem of credibility at home and abroad. He evidently feels he must justify his inaction -- and yet restore the threat of a future resort to force -- both to contain his domestic critics and to pressure Israel to negotiate on his terms.
Primary aluminum production in this country last year slipped to 3,925,242 tons from the 3,976,148 tons turned out in 1970, the Aluminum Association reported yesterday.

There is a fine, lovely and lyric madness at the Cherry Lane Theater. It is called "Wanted," it is by David Epstein and Al Carmines, and, at last, it restores the art of the musical to the Off Broadway theater.

During my firefighting career I've been blown from the roof of a blazing pier, have had the man next to me on a hose line gasp and die as we tried to advance into a burning tenement, have had a woman relieve herself as we carried her down an aerial ladder from a blazing Harlem tenement in a snowstorm.
The National Foundation-March of Dimes has warned that eating rare or raw meat or handling cat feces during pregnancy may result in a parasitic infection that can seriously damage the unborn child.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (Reuters) -- The Federal Reserve Board said today it would give expanded authority to Federal Reserve banks to expedite handling of applications received under the Bank Holding Company Act.
It was a good idea on the part of Eugene Ormandy to preface Brahms's Fourth Symphony with the composer's "Tragic" Overture in the Philadelphia Orchestra's Tuesday night concert in Philharmonic Hall.

For the first time in the history of commodity exchanges, diamond futures were traded yesterday on the West Coast Commodity Exchange in Los Angeles; an event the exchange had spent months preparing for.

The report of the extensive study made by the Surgeon General's office regarding the effect of violence on TV (news story Jan. 11) neglects to mention how many youngsters are adversely affected. I think that many people are aware that the majority of the nation's youth may not be so influenced.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 19 -- The New York Rangers didn't quite reach their quota, but did well enough in beating the Los Angeles Kings, 5-1, before 7,814 at the Forum tonight. The victory moved them within two points of the first-place Boston Bruins, who have played one more game.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Three economists with differing economic and political philosophies agreed today that many of the Government's own actions and policies were making inflation worse by reducing the extent to which businesses may compete.

For some time, engineers and knowledgeable boatmen have been wondering why it has taken so long for pleasure boats to be powered by an engine that is vibration-less, silent, ecologically clean, safe and operates at low cost.

Two missions -- one to unravel the mystery of a strange valley and the other to go by water from the remote forests of the Yukon to the United States border -- were accomplished by a group of British explorers in the wild Northwest territories of Canada in 1971.
Accusations of racism were exchanged yesterday at a City Planning Commission hearing on a low-income scatter-site housing project in Brooklyn.
Mariner 9 has transmitted a panoramic photograph of Mars showing a vast chasm with branching canyons resembling a network of dry river beds -- features hitherto unseen on the planet.

MEMPHIS, Jan. 19 (UPI) -- Mayor Wyeth Chandler promised today to set immediate guidelines for use of police weapons following the third shooting death of a young black by the Memphis police in two weeks.

" This is where I live," says David (Dustin Hoffman), the ordinarily loving, mild-mannered mathematician, to the thugs who want to invade his home. "This is me! I will not allow violence against this house!"

It used to be that the Brahms First was the graduation piece for a visiting orchestra making its New York debut. Every orchestra and every conductor wanted to be measured against the Brahms C minor. No longer. Mahler is gilt-edged these days -- any Mahler.
The city's newest Commissioner once described himself as "a poor country boy from the South who came here believing that there was an opportunity here."

The Jan. 7 letter by James H. Sheldon and your Jan. 8 editorial, "Double Fault at the U.N.," concerning the accreditation of two correspondents from the Central News Agency of China appear to be based on a misunderstanding of the facts in the case.

John Aldridge has always seemed to me to be some sort of an organ transplant at the Saturday Review, one that never managed to revitalize the arteriosclerotic old body but that, paradoxically, continued to thrive by itself. His mind is independent enough to seem almost perverse, at times, and perhaps that explains his willingness to appear in its pages.
President Nixon will ask Congress to appropriate $78-million for the arts and humanities in the budget for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1973.

C. Jackson Grayson Jr., the chairman of the Price Commission, said yesterday that he was concerned about public acceptance of Phase Two and about future compliance with its rules, and had scheduled an eight-city tour of the country to explain the program to consumers and industrial and retail groups.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 19 -- The United States command announced that a Navy Phantom jet shot down an enemy MIG-21 deep inside North Vietnam today. It was the first MIG reported downed in 22 months.
Stock prices sagged yesterday on profit taking, but the market bounced back to recover the bulk of its losses before the final bell.

DORTMUND, West Germany, Jan. 19 -- A row of West German steel magnates facing a crowd of newsmen here yesterday broke out in hearty laughter when someone suggested that their new cooperative venture with a Dutch company be named the "Anti-Japan company."
COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo. -- Eleven battalions of the National Guard, representing as many states, have taken over an important share of the defense of the continental United States from air attack.

Victor Gotbaum, executive director of District Council 37 of the State, County and Municipal Workers, which has 95,000 members in this city, endorsed Senator Edmund A. Muskie yesterday for the Democratic Presidential nomination and urged Mayor Lindsay to withdraw from the race.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Senator Stuart Symington suggested today that some American nuclear weapons stationed in the Far East were not being properly protected against misuse or seizure.

Business is still recovering slowly from the recession. In December, industrial output rose seven-tenths of 1 per cent, but nearly half the rise was due to the increase in coal output after last fall's strike. Industrial production went up only 3 per cent in the past year -- and is still 3.7 per cent below its peak in 1969.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- One of the most expensive things wrought in this country since the automobile is a large body of people who cannot write letters. This group ranges in age from about 13 to, oh, maybe 25. Its members are, in some respects, well educated.
ROME, Jan. 19 -- Talks on the use of military bases in Malta by British and allied forces resumed here today, and some progress toward an agreement was reported.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Andy Granatelli and Richard Petty joined forces today in a stock car racing deal that is understood to have cost Granatelli about $1-million.
Tom Blair, track and field's newest 17-foot pole vaulter says he is having trouble "thinking I can keep this up."

On their second combined bill at the Brooklyn Academy of Music Wednesday night, the Murray Louis Dance Company and the Alwin Nikolais Dance Theater remained happily separate but equal. Later in their current two-week engagement, the companies will join forces on stage in the same piece.
Short-interest positions on the New York Stock Exchange as of Jan. 14 were 6 per cent below the month-earlier figure, the exchange reported yesterday.

The Board of Education revoked its contract yesterday with a small bus company that carries handicapped pupils, as on outgrowth of a city investigation into allegedly fraudulent practices by some concerns that transport Medicaid patients.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -Following is a detailed examination of the written State of the Union Message:
The Federal Reserve's expansionary credit policy showed signs of accelerating in the weekly banking data made available yesterday.
TRENTON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The New Jersey Racing Commission approved today a shift of racing dates from the Atlantic City Track to both Monmouth Park and Freehold Raceway.

PARIS -- Andre Malraux, the great French writer, is an outstanding example of the "committed" artist. It is a cliche among younger intellectuals that they should "engage" themselves in world events and play an active role.
Three dozen angry railroad riders and public officials laced into the New Haven commuter lines of the Penn Central yesterday and into a proposal to increase its fares as much as 160 per cent.
ROME, Jan. 20 -- Negotiations concerning military bases in Malta ran into new difficulties today and a breakdown was barely avoided.

LUXEMBOURG -- This tiny country, which is not quite the size of Rhode Island, has given a warm welcome to the giants of American industry whom it invited here to lessen Luxembourg's dependence upon its famed steel mills.

So far as some segments of the shipping industry are concerned, the Sandy Hook Pilots Association of New York and New Jersey is as adept at threading its way into snug legislative harbors at Albany as its members are in guiding deep-sea vessels through the Narrows.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -The annual State of the Union Message is not normally more than an upbeat rendering of the state of the President -- except in election years, when it also becomes an index of the President's sense of the mood of the voters.
BONN, Jan. 20 -- A wave of violent crime highlighted by the long and intensive hunt for a gang of anarchists has stirred a wide and sometimes strident debate among West Germans.

Walter Seeley of Sayville, L. I., who spends his work time clambering around house roofs and his hobby time punching ring rivals, will meet Jesus (Farajito -- means pigeon) Nieves in the co-featured 10-round featherweight fight in the Felt Forum tonight.

NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 20 (AP) -- The Kentucky Colonels tied an American Basketball Association record tonight with their 10th straight road victory as they built an 11-point lead in the final period and withstood a late Virginia Squires rally for a 118-115 decision.

GENEVA, Jan. 20 -- The major Western oil companies signed an agreement here tonight under which they will pay at least $700-million a year to six producing countries on the Persian Gulf to compensate them for the devaluation of the dollar last December.
LONDON -- Paradox has hardly ever marked an economy as distinctly as it did Britain's in 1971. Even W.S. Gilbert, that most ingenious paradoxicalist, would have been sated.

Nicholas A. Rattenni, identified by Federal authorities as a Mafia leader in Westchester County, was acquitted yesterday of offering to bribe an Internal Revenue Service agent to gain favorable treatment on his income-tax returns.

BERLIN -- At the turn of the year, West Berlin was looking for a new political, economic and commercial role in Europe, following the accords reached by the Western allies and the Soviet Union to improve the situation for this Western outpost, isolated deep inside East Germany.

Wage and price controls, similar in some cases to those now in force in the United States, have been widespread in Europe in recent years to fight inflation, but in most instances the controls have had only limited effectiveness.
THE HAGUE -- In the southernmost tip of the Netherlands miners are facing the dilemma long faced by their counterparts in Wales and the Ruhr: mines are being closed and they must find other jobs.

HANOVER, N. H., Jan. 20 -- Dr. Ruth M. Adams, the president of Wellesley College since 1966, has been appointed a vice president of Dartmouth College, where she is to assist that all-male institution's transition to coeducational status next fall.
